{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Former FDA commissioner said he's 'not sure' about Biden's India travel ban because COVID-19 variants are already in the US","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/gottlieb-india-travel-ban-covid-variant-spreading-in-us-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608173dc4becb800190f677f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A Covid-19 patient gets admitted to a government hospital in Kolkata, India, 22 April, 2021. India reported 314,835 fresh coronavirus infections on Thursday according to an Indian media report.\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A COVID-19 patient gets admitted to a government hospital in Kolkata, India, on April 22, 2021. India reported 314,835 new coronavirus infections on Thursday.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Indranil Aditya/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb said he was &#34;not sure&#34; about Biden&#39;s India travel ban.</li>\n<li>Gottlieb said he didn&#39;t think the ban, slated to begin Tuesday, would be effective because variants are already spreading in the US.</li>\n<li>India is dealing with an ongoing surge of COVID-19 that has overwhelmed its healthcare system.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Former FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb on Sunday cast doubt on President Joe Biden&#39;s looming ban on travel with India as a method for preventing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-variants-uk-south-africa-brazil-us-facts-questions-2021-1\">COVID-19 variants</a> from being introduced in the US.</p><p>&#34;I&#39;m not sure what we&#39;re hoping to accomplish,&#34; Gottlieb said during an appearance on <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/transcript-scott-gottlieb-discusses-coronavirus-on-face-the-nation-may-2-2021/\">CBS News&#39; &#34;Face the Nation.&#34;</a> &#34;If the goal is to try to prevent the introduction of that new variant 617 that&#39;s circulating in India, I assure you it&#39;s here already.&#34;</p><p>&#34;So we&#39;re not going to be able to prevent its introduction,&#34; he added. &#34;These variants aren&#39;t just cropping up in one market and then migrating around the world. They&#39;re cropping up simultaneously in every market.&#34; </p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ron-desantis-wants-protect-free-speech-using-government-censorship-florida-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has a simple plan to &#39;protect&#39; free speech - by using government censorship</a></em></p><p>Gottlieb said this was known as &#34;convergent evolution.&#34; </p><p>&#34;There&#39;s probably a finite number of ways that this virus is going to try to mutate to evade our immunity, and it&#39;s testing us everywhere in the world,&#34; he said. &#34;So the same mutations that are arising in other parts of the world are arising here as well.&#34; </p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Face The Nation  (@FaceTheNation) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388877626450878464?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 2, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>The White House on Friday, citing several variants of the disease, announced it was barring most travel between the US and India because of the virus outbreak in the country. As Insider&#39;s John Haltiwanger previously noted, the travel restriction puts <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-bans-most-travel-india-once-said-bans-dont-work-2021-4\">Biden&#39;s actions at odds with his past statements about travel bans</a>, which he previously said would &#34;not stop the coronavirus.&#34; </p><p>Effective Tuesday, the ban will not apply to US citizens or permanent residents. Certain students, academics, and journalists will also be exempt from the travel ban, the <a href=\"https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/News/visas-news/presidential-proclamation-on-the-suspension-of-entry-as-nonimmigrants-of-certain-additional-persons-who-pose-a-risk-of-transmitting-coronavirus-disease-2019.html\">US State Department</a> said.</p><p>&#34;The CDC advises, based on work by public health and scientific experts, that these variants have characteristics of concern, which may make them more easily transmitted and have the potential for reduced protection afforded by some vaccines,&#34; The White House <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/04/30/a-proclamation-on-the-suspension-of-entry-as-nonimmigrants-of-certain-additional-persons-who-pose-a-risk-of-transmitting-coronavirus-disease-2019/\">said Friday in a statement</a> announcing the president had signed the proclamation banning travel.</p><p>Gottlieb said the US success in vaccinating its population was likely responsible for preventing the variants from having the same effect they&#39;re having on countries like India, which is reporting <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/india-first-country-to-record-400000-single-day-coronavirus-cases-2021-5\">more than 300,000 new cases</a> of COVID-19 every day. On Saturday, it became the first country to report more than 400,000 cases in a single day.</p><p>&#34;These travel restrictions could serve a purpose, but we need to be clear about what that purpose is right now. We still have restrictions in place against travel from China and the UK,&#34; Gottlieb said Sunday. &#34;That doesn&#39;t make a lot of sense. So I&#39;m not really sure what the overall strategy is around these continued travel restrictions that we have in place.&#34;</p><p>About 29% of the US population is fully vaccinated against COVID-19, according to <a href=\"https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/vaccines/us-states\">data analyzed by Johns Hopkins University.</a> More than 243 million doses of the vaccine have been administered in the US, according to the data.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2021 17:10:39 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608edc04f22c6b00185db2ba?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7e3ca9b55583d66398bf30a328ed4741","destWidth":954,"destHeight":716,"sourceBytes":37650,"destBytes":37650,"author":"insider@insider.com Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608173dc4becb800190f677f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-23-708_026a555d3cab4ae1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jh2nQVw3514:atsnspNw__0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn29@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-953_2743147257a103af.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jh2nQVw3514:atsnspNw__0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn17@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-22-559_d417dcd7c2e5f80e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jh2nQVw3514:atsnspNw__0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn75@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-27-437_8c5d7ddc57c0bbbd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jh2nQVw3514":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn31@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-893_19b957fb05efd22e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238427},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"The QAnon insurrectionist who filmed himself begging to be shot and inciting rioters to storm the Capitol told the FBI he was only there as a 'journalist'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-arrests-andrew-jackson-morgan-encouraged-rioters-claims-journalist-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c32b935c46f0018c0b9ae?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Andrew Jackson Morgan\" height=\"546\" width=\"729\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. records himself during the insurrection on January 6, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Political Trance Tribune</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. claimed to be at the insurrection as a civil rights auditor and journalist.</li>\n<li>Several now-deleted recordings show him encouraging the pro-Trump mob to storm the Capitol.</li>\n<li>An Insider investigation reveals that he was motivated by far-right, conspiratorial beliefs.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Wearing his trademark Harley Davidson beanie and an unauthorized &#39;PRESS ACCESS&#39; lanyard around his neck, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-rioters-insurrection-posing-journalists-legal-defenses-ap-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-rioters-insurrection-posing-journalists-legal-defenses-ap-2021-4\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr.</a> captured one of America&#39;s darkest days on camera.</p><p>Unlike legitimate reporters who kept a safe distance from the rioters, the 60-year-old YouTuber was in the midst of the chaos of January 6.</p><p>As the pro-Trump mob around him attacked police officers with stolen batons and riot shields, Morgan recorded himself and others whooping and cheering as the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-siege-module\">storming of the Capitol</a> took place.</p><p><strong>Watch Morgan&#39;s participation in the Capitol insurrection in a video obtained by Insider.</strong></p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/XdGnngGV-yyM9LDiu.html\" width=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" style=\"position:absolute;\" allow=\"fullscreen\"></iframe></div><p>&#34;Forward, march,&#34; he yelled several times in a <a href=\"https://archive.org/details/capitol-eviction-notice-opart-2\">since-deleted video</a> from his <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpvxrbz4mTyPO0AKR3gb4NQ/videos\">&#34;Political Trance Tribune&#34; YouTube page</a>.</p><p>&#34;Go through the windows,&#34; Morgan urged the mass of insurrectionists.</p><p>Now, the man who claimed to be there as an &#34;independent journalist&#34; is <a href=\"https://www.justice.gov/usao-dc/defendants/morgan-jr-andrew-jackson\">charged</a> with four counts for his role in the Capitol riots, including aiding and abetting the <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/all-the-us-capitol-pro-trump-riot-arrests-charges-names-2021-1\">deadly insurrection</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/60-minues-interview-justice-department-doj-capitol-riots-michael-sherwin-2021-3\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">A Trump-appointed prosecutor blindsided the Biden DOJ with a &#39;60 Minutes&#39; interview on the Capitol riot cases. Now a federal judge wants to talk about it.</a></em></p><h2>Morgan&#39;s work as a &#39;civil rights auditor&#39;</h2><p>Morgan traveled from Texas to attend the Capitol riot. His main source of income is tree removal which, according to his <a href=\"http://www.therovingarborist.com/About.html\">business&#39;s website</a>, he got into after struggling to keep a full-time job because of a &#34;sleep disorder.&#34;</p><p>He only became an arborist to bankroll the launch of his internet marketing career, he wrote on the website. This, so far, has been unsuccessful. Two businesses he set up now appear to be defunct.</p><p>In recent years, he has been dedicated to growing a YouTube following for his channel - <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/PoliticalTrance/about\">&#34;Political Trance Tribune</a>&#34; - posting &#39;civil rights audits&#39; on it for nine years. The page has nurtured a small but reasonably engaged following; 3,600 subscribers and over 100,000 views. </p><p>Civil rights auditing, or First Amendment auditing,  involves individuals recording government officials in action. Auditors go to <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SpS47ppUhA\">post offices</a>, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fSUH8iRuoAw\">city council meetings</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLrBM7m5Dds\">crime scenes</a> to test how officials react when they get the cameras rolling.</p><p>If officials allow filming to take place on public property, they pass the audit. If they refuse, they fail the audit and they end up being exposed on YouTube channels. Auditors say they are there to exercise their First Amendment rights but, as the <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-insane-new-path-to-youtube-fame-trigger-cops-and-film-it\">Daily Beast</a> reported in 2019, dramatic confrontations can lead to YouTube fame.</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/JOyaFHvFeDU\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p>Many of the run-ins published on Morgan&#39;s channel involve tense, dramatic interactions with police officers.</p><p>Morgan, who is described in his <a href=\"https://www.justice.gov/usao-dc/case-multi-defendant/file/1385531/download\">affidavit</a> as an &#34;independent journalist and a civil rights auditor,&#34; is often seen deliberately aggravating law enforcement officers. This aligns with his anti-cop views, as expressed in a now-deleted YouTube video seen by Insider. &#34;I happen to think we need to abolish the police,&#34; he said in the clip from January.</p><p>Other <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VtFd76K4j0Q\">clips</a> show him being threatened with prosecution for provoking officers. On one occasion, Texas&#39; Montgomery County Court records show that an incident led to his arrest.</p><p>He was placed in Montgomery County Jail on June 9, 202o, for &#34;interfering with traffic control and scene securement efforts,&#34; according to an arrest warrant seen by Insider.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608bf02834af8d001859a176?format=jpeg\" alt=\"andrew jackson morgan arrest\" height=\"180\" width=\"240\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Andrew Jackson Morgan was arrested for interfering with the public duties of a peace officer on June 9, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Montgomery County Jail</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>He believes that 9/11 was an &#39;inside false flag job&#39;</h2><p>Morgan&#39;s anti-police views are part of a wider set of conspiratorial and far-right views.</p><p>On his private Facebook page, Morgan shared posts that denied the climate crisis, challenged the fact that former President Barack Obama was born in the US, and called 9/11 an &#34;inside false flag job.&#34; He also frequently shared posts by the far-right publication Breitbart News and conspiracist website InfoWars.</p><p>More recently on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/PoliticalTrance\">Political Trance Tribune&#39;s Facebook page</a>, Morgan showed allegiance to QAnon - the disproven and discredited conspiracy theory. Some posts are captioned with the hashtag #WWG1WGA, which stands for the QAnon slogan &#34;Where we go one, we go all.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c2d3e34af8d001859a3a6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"post andrew jackson morgan\" height=\"960\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A post on the Facebook page for Andrew Jackson Morgan&#39;s YouTube page shows support for QAnon.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Facebook</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>A video of Morgan attending a rally for then-President Donald Trump in Houston in 2018 also uses this caption.</p><p>Despite attending Trump rallies, Morgan appears to have made a small donation to a Democratic cause a year later. A man of the same name and sharing the same zip code donated $5 to &#39;Friends of Andrew Yang&#39; on September 17, 2019, via left-leaning fundraiser ActBlue, according to data from the Federal Election Commission.</p><p>However, the vast majority of his posts are supportive of Trump and critical of former President Barack Obama.</p><p>Before the January 6 riots, his last post shows Morgan attending dinner with fellow civil rights auditors, several of whom are believed to have traveled with him to Washington, DC.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608bfca334af8d001859a18f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"civil rights auditors dinner\" height=\"931\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A facebook post of eight civil rights auditors having dinner together in Mobile, Alabama in December, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Facebook</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Unauthorized press passes are being used to mount legal defenses</h2><p>According to his affidavit, Morgan told an FBI special agent in March that he had traveled from Maxwell, Texas, to Washington, DC on January 6  to witness &#34;something unprecedented.&#34;</p><p>He claimed that he merely wanted to record the event, according to court documents.</p><p>&#34;Me and several other auditors, we were gonna go, and I said I really want to be there to report,&#34; Morgan claimed in a now-deleted video posted after January 6 and seen by Insider. </p><p>He traveled to the Capitol with five other civil rights auditors who sometimes referred to themselves as &#34;independent patriots,&#34; his wife, Sheila Morgan, told special agents.</p><p>One was Matthew Wrosch, also known as the Michigan Constitutional Crusader, who provided Morgan and several others with unofficial press lanyards before the riots.  This was to show that the men were &#34;journalists&#34; who were &#34;disseminating information to the public,&#34; he told Insider.</p><p>The passes, however, were not authorized by any recognized body and do not count as media credentials. Nonetheless, these homemade passes and claims of being journalists are being used as evidence by several defendants to mount <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-rioters-insurrection-posing-journalists-legal-defenses-ap-2021-4\">First Amendment free speech defenses in court</a>, Insider previously reported.</p><p>Wrosch said that he had no intentions of actively participating in the riots. &#34;In my eyes, we were just supposed to observe and record,&#34; he said. &#34;When it&#39;s a government unrest kind of thing, we&#39;re not supposed to say s--t. We&#39;re just supposed to watch what&#39;s happening and record it.&#34; </p><p>But while Wrosch stayed &#34;fifty feet away&#34; at all times and &#34;didn&#39;t get up close and get in the fray,&#34; Morgan joined the melee of rioters as they forced their way into one of the Capitol&#39;s entrances.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c333635c46f0018c0b9c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"capitol riots andrew jackson morgan\" height=\"528\" width=\"705\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Footage recorded by Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. shows rioters break a Capitol building window on January 6, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Political Trance Tribune</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In an hour of self-recorded videos seen by Insider, Morgan shows himself to be sandwiched between insurrectionists as they smash a Capitol window and fight with police officers. He can be heard throughout, encouraging them, yelling &#34;keep moving&#34; and &#34;send helmets forward.&#34;</p><p>Several times, Morgan can be heard begging to be shot and teargassed. &#34;I&#39;m here first, y&#39;all gonna slide in right behind me,&#34; he said. &#34;I&#39;m gonna take the bullet first. I want the bullet. Give me my bullet.&#34;</p><p>He urged people to &#34;hold the line&#34; and repeatedly asked to be let into the Capitol.<strong> &#34;</strong>Hell yeah, we&#39;re going over. We&#39;re going in that building,&#34; he said.</p><h2>&#39;I bought into the provocateurs&#39; trap.&#39;</h2><p>A couple of days after the deadly insurrection, Morgan did a two-hour-long live stream about why he joined in with the storming of the Capitol. Insider recovered the footage.</p><p>In the live stream, he explained to his subscribers what had initially inspired him to attend. &#34;I went on January 6 with the knowledge and belief that the election was rigged,&#34; he said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c392c34af8d001859a4c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. live stream capitol riots\" height=\"564\" width=\"752\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. does a live stream in the aftermath of the Capitol riots on January 6, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Political Trance Tribune</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>He then spoke, at length, about the media being a &#34;Nazi propaganda machine,&#34; and &#39;Q&#39; being right.</p><p>The 60-year-old did admit that he joined the mob in pushing their way into the Capitol.  &#34;When I got up to the doorway, I participated in the heave-ho, heave-ho,&#34; he said. It felt like the &#34;right thing at the moment,&#34; he added.</p><p>Morgan apologized several times for falling into &#34;antifa&#39;s trap&#34; and blamed his actions on &#34;emotion&#34; and &#34;herd mentality.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I was wrong,&#34; he said. &#34;When I went on that Capitol grounds and &#39;antifa&#39; sent that message out that what we&#39;re there for is to take the Capitol, I bought into it. I bought into the provocateurs&#39; trap.&#34;</p><p>There is <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/florida-teacher-falsely-told-students-antifa-behind-capitol-riots-video-2021-1\">no evidence</a> of &#39;antifa&#39; being responsible for the violence during the Capitol riots.</p><p>Morgan told his subscribers that he was prepared for any potential punishment. &#34;If I did something heinous and wrong and I have to pay for it, I&#39;m a grown man, I can pay for it,&#34; he said. &#34;I&#39;m not gonna scream and holler and cry. I did what I did out of a pure heart and pure intent. I wish I hadn&#39;t done it. I wish I hadn&#39;t fallen into antifa&#39;s trap.&#34;</p><h2>He is charged with aiding and abetting the insurrection</h2><p>Morgan may soon &#34;pay for it.&#34;</p><p>His videos were supplied to the FBI on January 19 and he was then identified by special agents. On April 9, he surrendered to Austin agents and was charged for his role in the insurrection.</p><p>Morgan is now accused of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building without lawful authority, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting. If convicted, he could face several years in jail.</p><p>Experts say that a legal defense claiming to be a journalist is unlikely to stand in court. </p><p>Lucy Dalglish, the dean of the University of Maryland&#39;s Philip Merrill College of Journalism, told the Associated Press that journalists need to be credentialed and cannot claim to be reporting if there is evidence to suggest they were encouraging the violent mob.</p><p>For Morgan, the lessons learned from the events of January 6 might have come too late.</p><p>&#34;I&#39;ve learned a lot,&#34; he said in his live stream. &#34;From this day on, my auditing is gonna be a lot different.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/capitol-arrests-andrew-jackson-morgan-encouraged-rioters-claims-journalist-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a id=\"slideshow\">\n\t9. \"PJ Masks\" (Disney Junior, 2015-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608afcc235c46f0018c0b4e4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pj masks\" height=\"689\" width=\"919\" 6-year-old kids who live normal lives during the day become superheroes at night, fighting crime as a team known as PJ Masks.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: N/A</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: N/A</p>\n\t8. \"Ginny and Georgia\" (Netflix original, 2021-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img data-uri=\"8f19b3896a9fc7a2f9d0c62f2381c430\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Free-spirited Georgia and her two kids, Ginny and Austin, move north in search of a fresh start but find that the road to new beginnings can be bumpy.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 68%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"The body of the series is a bantery young-adult soap, the head a woman-on-the-edge thriller, and the tail a race melodrama. The creator, Sarah Lampert, must have looked upon her handiwork with proud amusement.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2021/03/15/queen-latifah-obliterates-trumps-n-musks-in-the-equalizer\">New Yorker</a> (season one)</p>\n\t7. \"The Serpent\" (Netflix original, 2021)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070c0dea451820019b3a643?format=jpeg\" alt=\"the serpent netflix\" height=\"1104\" width=\"1330\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/80206099\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9d640cc4a0e3daed0bbbc0fe0a70366f\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"In the 1970s, merciless killer Charles Sobhraj preys on travelers exploring the \"hippie trail\" of South Asia. Based on shocking true events.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 68%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"The Serpent ends up being an infuriating blueprint for how bad storytelling choices, bad accents and an opaque central performance can thwart even the most inherently gripping of yarns.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/the-serpent-tv-review\">Hollywood Reporter</a></p>\n\t6. \"Nicky, Ricky, Dicky and Dawn\" (Nickelodeon, 2014-2018)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6078933c4206150018175bfc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"nicky, ricky, dicky and dawn\" height=\"1124\" width=\"1450\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nickelodeon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/80077508\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"047235780ea7fe86545514eca988ddd7\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Just because they're quadruplets, that doesn't mean these 10-year-olds always get along. But for all the bickering, they're loyal to the last.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: N/A</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: N/A</p>\n\t5. \"Cocomelon\" (YouTube, 2019-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b079a34af8d0018599fd0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"cocomelon netflix\" height=\"695\" width=\"927\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81273085\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"14b6d0b414f721b49b2904a58f207c56\">Description</a>:</strong>&#160;\"Learn letters, numbers, animal sounds and more with J.J. in this musical series that brings fun times with nursery rhymes for the whole family!\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: N/A</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: N/A</p>\n\t4. \"The Circle\" (Netflix original, 2020-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b07e134af8d0018599fd1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"michelle buteau the circle\" height=\"2142\" width=\"2857\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Michelle Buteau hosts &#34;The Circle.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81044551\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"db4d634170f68c129c5dabf99dfb0e8e\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Status and strategy collide in this social experiment and competition show where online players flirt, befriend and catfish their way toward $100,000.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 81%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"In a world where social media is an ever-present utility, we all make similar decisions daily, just without the promise of $100,000. The Circle may be a game show, but it's also a microcosm of society as a whole.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://thespool.net/reviews/season-2-of-the-circle-plays-a-more-cutthroat-game/\">The Spool</a> (season two)</p>\n\t3. \"Life in Color with David Attenborough\" (Netflix original, 2021-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608b0a1f35c46f0018c0b535?format=jpeg\" alt=\"life in color\" height=\"985\" width=\"1314\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81036559\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Using innovative technology, this docuseries explores nature from a fresh perspective as animals use color to survive and thrive in the wild.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: N/A</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"Informative and visually stunning.\" &#8212; 86%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"If Shadow and Bone doesn't provide quite the level of characterizing nuance and challenging chronological complexity of The Witcher &#8212; and it does 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"America is getting ready for its post pandemic glow-up","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/america-post-pandemic-glow-up-consumer-spending-shopping-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c142e35c46f0018c0b771?format=jpeg\" alt=\"eating restaurant spending reopening\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Americans need to spend to help the economy recover.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Taylor Hill/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>America is reopening, and coming out of its pandemic shell could mean an <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-stimulus-vaccines-gdp-growth-strongest-decades-fed-williams-2021-2\">economic boom</a>. It&#39;s a glow-up.</li>\n<li>They&#39;re already spending on outdoor activities, transit, restaurants, clothes, and beauty.</li>\n<li>But America will also look different, and spending in other areas is weak. We don&#39;t know what will emerge.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>America is getting ready for its post-pandemic glow-up.</p><p>Peak sweatpant has passed and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/peak-sweatpant-sweatpants-sales-pandemic-high-heels-retail-trends-2021-4\">high heels are hot again</a>, in the ultimate symbol of an economy ready to let loose. Americans are booking beauty services, buying going-out clothes again, and readying for a &#34;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/hot-vaxx-summer-pandemic-horniness-is-coming-blissful-release-2021-3#:~:text='Hot%20Vax%20Summer'%20Is%20Coming,interaction%2C%20or%20dismiss%20a%20notification.ication.\">hot vax summer</a>&#34; as they emerge from lockdown looking and feeling different than they entered, helping the economy roar back to life in the process.</p><p>It&#39;s the result of vaccination rates <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hitting-latest-vaccine-milestone-biden-pushes-shots-for-all-2021-4\">revving up</a>, big cities <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nyc-full-reopening-july-1-ready-bill-de-blasio-2021-4\">reopening</a>, and Americans sitting on a ton of cash. Between three stimulus checks and the decline in discretionary spending that accompanied a pandemic shutdown, Americans were holding <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/us-excess-savings-coronavirus-pandemic-power-economy-recovery-moodys-2021-4-1030318905\">$2.6 trillion</a> in excess savings as of mid-April, per Moody&#39;s Analytics.</p><p>And that&#39;s why so many economists are predicting that a lockdown lift will see the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-stimulus-vaccines-gdp-growth-strongest-decades-fed-williams-2021-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"090d7a96bbec5d8e360121a8c1a981bc\">biggest boomtime</a> in a generation, potentially ushering in a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economic-outlook-2020s-new-era-stimulus-vaccines-remote-work-2021-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"8422c75ec8cd77115075ef3d1f5fc402\">new era in the US economy</a>. Moody&#39;s Analytics expects the US economy to grow 6.4% in 2021 after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economy-shrank-35-in-2020-after-growing-4-last-quarter-2021-1?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">shrinking 3.5% in 2020</a>. </p><p>But to power such an economic transformation, Americans need to keep spending. </p><p>BofA&#39;s head of North America Economics, Ethan Harris, wrote in March that the US&#39; economic fate will depend on whether Americans view their excess savings as wealth or deferred income. His team sees the savings being treated as the latter, which should &#34;help support exceptional growth this year in addition to the tailwinds from fiscal stimulus and an improving virus picture.&#34;</p><p>Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody&#39;s Analytics, agrees. &#34;An unleashing of significant pent-up demand and overflowing excess saving will drive a surge in consumer spending across the globe as countries approach herd immunity and open up,&#34; he wrote in a note. He sees 20% of excess savings being spent in 2021, and another 20% next year. </p><p>Credit card spending is already up, but it&#39;s just the beginning. Inflation, unequal savings distribution, and an uneven economic recovery may prove to be challenges in spending enough to fuel an economic boom.</p><h2>Spending on outdoor activities and a &#39;hot vax summer&#39;</h2><p>&#34;The snooze is over,&#34; wrote BofA&#39;s Michelle Meyer, head of US economics, in a note published on Thursday. BofA&#39;s card spending showed a massive uptick in consumer spending for the week, up 45% year-over-year and by 20% over two years previous. </p><p>The third stimulus has already impacted Americans&#39; bank accounts, per <a href=\"https://www.bea.gov/news/2021/personal-income-and-outlays-march-2021\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bureau of Economic Analysis</a> data. As <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-income-march-spending-stimulus-economy-covid-checks-americans-biden-2021-4\">incomes climbed by 21.1%</a> last March - a record monthly income leap dating since 1946 - consumer spending rose with it, increasing by 4.2%. Americans haven&#39;t spent that much since June. Total consumer spending, not adjusted for inflation, has now exceeded pre-pandemic levels.</p><p><s></s>In consumer spending, still leading the way is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/wealthy-americans-doing-hobbies-alone-already-reshaping-economy-2020-6\">solitary leisure</a> <strong>-</strong> solo activities that Americans turned to in the social-distancing era as previous forms of leisure, especially hospitality and entertainment, fell off dramatically. Spending on sporting goods such as golf, campground, and bike equipment, is continuing its momentum with activity above pre-pandemic norms, per BofA. </p><p>But we&#39;re also starting to see a resurgence in the activities of pre-pandemic yore. Spending on transit, restaurants and bars, department stores, and clothing have all increased by over 100% on a daily basis over the past 10 days, per BofA.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c113134af8d001859a20a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"haircut\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Beauty services are seeing a flood of bookings.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Xinhua News Agency/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Retailers are gearing up for a &#34;peacocking effect&#34; and dress sales on the rise, while jeans are making a comeback, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/going-out-clothes-sales-rising-vaccines-retailers-vaccine-summer-2021-4\">Insider&#39;s Avery Hartmans reported</a>. Blazers, stylish tops, and brightly colored sandals are all <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/03/18/dresses-jeans-suits-shopping-again/\">seeing signs of life</a>. Retail CEOs everywhere from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gap-ceo-expects-sales-increase-after-covid-pandemic-2021-3\">Gap</a> to <a href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/urban-outfitters-ceo-sees-hope-220547599.html\">Urban Outfitters</a> have noted signs of an incoming retail boon, with the latter already seeing an uptick in purchases of <a href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/urban-outfitters-ceo-sees-hope-220547599.html\">going-out clothes</a>.</p><p>The post-pandemic beauty boom has also arrived, as <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2021/04/pandemic-beauty-salon-spa-botox-appointments/618520/\">The Atlantic&#39;s Amanda Mull reported</a>. From eyebrow threading and hairstyling to mani-pedis and cosmetic injections, she wrote, people are booking up beauty services for their own personal glow-up. Beauty sales increased by 31% for for the week ending April 24, per BofA, compared to 2019.</p><p>The start of this spending is already making a difference. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-q1-gdp-economic-output-recovery-reopening-stimulus-vaccination-recession-2021-4\">GDP grew at a 6.4% annualized rate</a> in the first quarter, the Commerce Department estimated on a preliminary basis.</p><p>Economists have thus upped their predictions for economic growth every month of the year, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-09/u-s-growth-expectations-keep-mounting-with-bigger-tailwind?sref=BLKWHazc\">according to Bloomberg&#39;s latest monthly survey</a>, forecasting an annualized pace of 8.1% GDP growth in the second quarter.</p><h2>An unequal recovery and unequal savings</h2><p>While Americans have already begun swiping their cards, there are still holes in the economy to fill and challenges to overcome.</p><p>Entertainment and airline spending are improving, but still weak, per BofA. More Americans <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/travel-returning-boom-airlines-hotels-restaurants-spending-vacation-2021-3#especially-the-elderly-cohort-which-has-already-been-taking-flight-2\">intend to travel</a> as the weeks go by, with some already booking vacation rentals and hotels, and airlines just saw their busiest weekend since pre-pandemic, but travel&#39;s comeback is a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/travel-returning-boom-airlines-hotels-restaurants-spending-vacation-2021-3#especially-the-elderly-cohort-which-has-already-been-taking-flight-2\">gradual one</a>.</p><p>That might partly be because the economic recovery across America hasn&#39;t been uniform. BofA spending analysis finds the South and parts of Midwest are faring better economically than the West and the Northeast. That&#39;s likely because the latter regions had longer lockdowns and a slower easing of restrictions in an attempt to curb the spread of the coronavirus.</p><p>Also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pandemic-widened-millennial-wealth-gap-economic-inequality-rich-poor-henry-2021-1?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">unequal</a> is the share of savings built up during the pandemic. Zandi said in the Moody&#39;s note that this would limit an even bigger boom in spending. &#34;Much of the excess saving has been by high-income, high-net-worth households who are likely to treat the saving more like wealth than income, and will thus spend much of less it, at least quickly,&#34; he wrote.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fda6c93c910a400192e7e6e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"thanksgiving travel 2020\" height=\"1447\" width=\"1930\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Airline spending has improved, but is still weak.\n<p class=\"copyright\">David Santiago/Miami Herald/Tribune News Service via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Nearly two-thirds of the excess savings in the US is by households in the top 10% of the income distribution, per Moody&#39;s data, and three-quarters is by those in the richest 20%.</p><p>Consumer spending accounts for 70% of the American economy, and half of that is from the top 10% of American households, per estimates from Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank, respectively. That means about one-third of US GDP comes from spending by the top 10%. In other words, the US needs spending from wealthy households the most.</p><p>But there&#39;s a side effect that may come with unleashing pent-up demand: inflation. While experts don&#39;t think the economy will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economy-rebound-goods-commodities-services-more-expensive-inflation-stimulus-2021-2#:~:text=It's%20a%20crucial%20next%20step%20for%20the%20US%20economic%20recovery.&text=The%20US%20economy%20is%20headed,things%20more%20expensive%20for%20Americans.&text=This%20is%20good%3B%20inflation%20like,and%20a%20healthy%20economic%20recovery.%20recovery.\">overheat like it did in the 1970s</a>, some goods and services have begun to get <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/everything-that-could-get-more-expensive-in-2021-inflation-2021-3\">more expensive</a> amid the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-expensive-goods-supply-shortage-congested-shipping-ports-texas-freeze-2021-3\">supply shortages</a> that have come with reopening. The unpredictability of inflation could cause consumers to curb their spending.</p><h2><strong>A world with baggy jeans and remote work</strong></h2><p>In a post-pandemic world, though, America will look a little different. The point of a glow-up, after all, is transformation.</p><p>And while Americans whiled away their quarantine days <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-pandemic-shaped-millennials-adulthood-growing-up-2021-3\">baking bread and reorganizing their closets</a>, new trends emerged. Clothes are <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/restricted/?return=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usatoday.com%2Fin-depth%2Flife%2Ffashion%2F2021%2F04%2F18%2Fpost-pandemic-fashion-sweatpants-brighter-clothes-comfortable-shoes%2F7220342002%2F\">brighter</a>, wide-legged jeans have <a href=\"https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2021/02/10306887/tiktok-skinny-jeans-uncool-millennials\">replaced skinny jeans</a>, side parts are <a href=\"https://www.thecut.com/2021/02/gen-z-middle-part-tiktok.html\">no longer cool</a>, and the &#34;ugly fashion&#34; movement has seen its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ugly-clothes-are-in-style-2018-2\">pre-pandemic popularity</a> accelerate as shoppers increasingly purchase things like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/walking-shoes-millennial-gen-z-status-symbol-covid-wfh-economy-2021-3\">grandpa shoes</a> and <a href=\"https://www.gq.com/story/crocs-are-grails-sorry\">Crocs</a></p><p>Urban areas too, will look a little different. While experts and the data are pointing to big cities like New York <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-city-exodus-florida-temporary-move-migration-manhattan-brooklyn-2021-4\">making a comeback</a>, they will likely function in new ways. Urban theorist Richard Florida <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economic-outlook-2020s-new-era-stimulus-vaccines-remote-work-2021-2\">previously told Insider</a> he thinks major cities will be reshaped and revived by a newfound focus on interpersonal interaction that facilitates creativity and spontaneity. He said the community or neighborhood itself will take on more of the functions of an office.</p><p>The work-from-home revolution could bolster new cities&#39; real-estate markets, as more broadly shared prosperity counteracts decades of increasing regional inequality, but spending within cities themselves could suffer. For instance, economists estimate spending in downtown areas will be <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-consumer-spending-drop-cities-work-home-commute-study-2021-4\">10% depressed</a> - or more in the case of Manhattan - because of the remote-working revolution. So the fashions on the street will look different, and the cities will probably be a bit emptier.</p><p>People are also buying more stuff for inside the home. Spending in home categories was up 50.3% over 2019 for the week ending April 24, according to BofA. Americans have learned to spend in a more private way during a year inside. The glow-up is on, but Americans will have to keep spending for a truly impressive makeover.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/america-post-pandemic-glow-up-consumer-spending-shopping-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nslyd3EBXEU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 12:50:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608c142e35c46f0018c0b771?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c9c7b36b310668ef9517641169aa4dfc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn54@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-18-583_b29d1c642f4bd6d7.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":346504,"destBytes":346504,"author":"hhoffower@businessinsider.com (Hillary Hoffower)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608c142e35c46f0018c0b771?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn54@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-18-583_b29d1c642f4bd6d7.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c113134af8d001859a20a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn1@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-25-014_8c070ab15ef65937.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fda6c93c910a400192e7e6e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn71@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-964_93e26f70adb894d0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nslyd3EBXEU:B9dc4wze1jg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn21@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-22-649_6104f70a3147b8a3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nslyd3EBXEU:B9dc4wze1jg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn42@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-28-303_e16fb37e5a7c399f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nslyd3EBXEU:B9dc4wze1jg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn91@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-24-701_a165f53bfad1ad59.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nslyd3EBXEU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn51@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-164_3aa45ee10d8cf9d6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238433},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"China's new nuclear submarine carries missiles that can hit more of the US, military source says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-new-nuclear-submarine-missiles-can-hit-more-of-us-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ebe8fa5f0f4195113119b2c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A Type 094B Jin-class ballistic missile submarine\" height=\"1915\" width=\"3830\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Type 094B Jin-class ballistic missile submarine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Artyom Ivanov\\TASS via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The JL-3 ballistic missile can deliver multiple warheads - including nuclear - 10,000 km, a navy source says.</li>\n<li>Naval engineer Rear Adm. Ma Weiming has led work to fix the problem of Chinese submarines being too noisy and easy to detect.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>China&#39;s newly commissioned nuclear-powered submarine is armed with the country&#39;s most powerful submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) capable of hitting the US mainland, according to a military source and analysts.</p><p>The Type 094A, or <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3082195/chinese-navy-puts-two-new-nuclear-submarines-service\" data-v-305157e4=\"\">Jin-class</a> nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarine (SSBN), was presented last Friday as part of the celebration to mark the <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3130879/chinese-navy-marks-72nd-anniversary-unveiling-no-new-warships\" data-v-305157e4=\"\">72nd anniversary of the PLA Navy</a>. It was capable of firing the JL-3, or Julang (Big Wave) SLBM with a range over 10,000km (6,200 miles), a source close to the navy said.</p><p>&#34;The Type 094A is an upgraded version of the Type 094 that overcame one of the key problems - noise - by improving hydrokinetic and turbulent systems, allowing it to carry the more powerful JL-3,&#34; said the source, who requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the subject.</p><p>&#34;Before the upgrade, the submarine was armed with the inferior JL-2 that could only hit the northeast United States, but now it&#39;s able to cover the whole American continent.&#34;</p><p>According to Forbes, before entering striking distance of the continental United States, the Type 094A subs would have to slip past a cordon of US military bases in the Pacific dubbed the first island chain - exposing the subs to detection and attack by American P-8 anti-sub patrol planes, surface warships and other undersea reconnaissance capabilities.</p><p>Chinese submarines have been dogged by the problem of being too noisy and easy to detect but that has largely been remedied in recent years by Chinese naval engineer Rear Adm. Ma Weiming, who is now taking the lead in a cutting-edge propulsion technology, according to state media.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ebe90b63f7370590417b3e8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chinese navy missile submarine Type 094A\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A nuclear-powered Type 094A Jin-class ballistic-missile submarine in the South China Sea, April 12, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Stringer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The JL-3 is able to deliver the same multiple warheads, including nuclear warheads like the JL-2 does, the source added without giving more detail.</p><p>Each JL-2 missile can be armed with either a single megaton-yield warhead 67 times more powerful than the Little Boy bomb dropped on Hiroshima - or three to eight smaller multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicles (MIRVs) that can each strike different targets, according to a Forbes report in May last year.</p><p>Macau-based military expert Antony Wong Tong said the news indicated that some technical breakthroughs had been achieved to make the JL-2 fit the silos of the Type 094A.</p><p>&#34;The original design and size of the JL-3 should be adjusted, but those changes do not reduce its firepower and range - a significant breakthrough,&#34; Wong said.</p><p>Former PLA instructor Song Zhongping did not say what type of SLBM the Type 094A was armed with but said it would boost China&#39;s second-strike capability - its ability to retaliate after a nuclear strike.</p><p>&#34;The new SLBM with MIRVs with a firing range over 10,000km is the basic technical requirement for an upgraded Type 094 SSBN to cause nuclear deterrence,&#34; he said. &#34;China promises not to use a nuke first but a powerful SSBN fleet will help the PLA strengthen their second-strike power against rivals.&#34;</p><p>China has six Type 094 and Type 094A SSBNs and plans to build a further two to replace the Type 092 SSBNs, according to the source.</p><p>Sources said last year that the PLA planned to arm the Type 096 submarine with JL-3 missiles, a process that could take years to complete.</p><p>Each Type 094 submarine is able to carry 16 JL-3 missiles, but the upgraded Type 096 could carry 24 JL-3s, according to a Pentagon report on China&#39;s military capabilities.</p><p>The Type 094A was one of the three new warships put into service on the same day. The others were the Type 075 amphibious helicopter assault ship and the Type 055 Renhai-class guided missile cruiser.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/china-new-nuclear-submarine-missiles-can-hit-more-of-us-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_BpmIDgTTl0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 15:13:57 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608ec09bf22c6b00185db29d?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"43c7be65e5f927b72971e10efc44cebf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn85@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-21-705_d0358fa71b715452.webp","destWidth":3189,"destHeight":2391,"sourceBytes":329934,"destBytes":329934,"author":"insider@insider.com (Minnie Chan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ebe8fa5f0f4195113119b2c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-23-923_6dff619f8f085243.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ebe90b63f7370590417b3e8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn81@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-26-797_9781ae642bb834a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn37@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-050_98a1fb35a44b8316.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn66@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-28-059_91201872878e22f1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_BpmIDgTTl0:BjpRUdz8Iis:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn24@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-24-790_0c5d74ba80da32d7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_BpmIDgTTl0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn97@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-128_cca268812f9e1ca2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Stimulus and COVID fears are keeping millions of Americans from rejoining the labor market, BofA says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/employment-outlook-stimulus-virus-fears-labor-market-recovery-participation-bofa-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ed86ef22c6b00185db2b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"hiring sign coronavirus\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">OLIVIER DOULIERY/AFP/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Some 2.5 million Americans won&#39;t rejoin the labor force until late 2021, Bank of America said.</li>\n<li>Virus fears and boosted unemployment benefits are keeping them from seeking work, the bank added.</li>\n<li>Retirements and COVID-19 deaths will leave a more permanent drag on participation, BofA said.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The rapidly accelerating economic recovery is running up against labor shortages. The snags are temporary, but they hint at permanent changes to the US job market because of the coronavirus pandemic, according to Bank of America economists.</p><p>Stimulus, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cities-and-states-incentivizing-covid-19-vaccines-2021-5\">COVID-19 vaccinations</a>, and reopening all helped hiring rebound in recent months. March job additions were the strongest since August, and consumer spending gauges suggest healthy demand will keep payroll growth robust into the summer. Yet as businesses rehire in preparation for a pickup in demand, some are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-labor-market-recovery-hiring-unemployment-crisis-stimulus-2021-4\">reporting difficulties in finding workers</a>.</p><p>While some 9.7 million Americans are officially tallied in the government&#39;s unemployment gauges, another 4.6 million workers exited the labor force during the pandemic, the team led by Joseph Song said in a note to clients. More than half of those workers will likely rejoin the labor force by the end of the year, but face a few obstacles before they do so.</p><p>For one, fears of catching COVID-19 and its more contagious variants still loom large. Those concerns are likely playing a role in<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-labor-market-recovery-hiring-unemployment-crisis-stimulus-2021-4\">keeping Americans from rejoining the workforce</a> and looking for jobs, the economists said.</p><p>Low-income Americans might also hold off on seeking work because of stimulus&#39;s disincentive effects, the bank added. The Biden administration&#39;s $1.9 trillion support package included a $300-per-week expansion to unemployment insurance through September. While smaller than the CARES Act benefit, the latest boost could be leading some Americans to stay on the sidelines for now, Bank of America said.</p><p>&#34;Our estimates suggest that those who previously made less than $32,000 would be better off in the near term to collect UI benefits than work,&#34; the team added.</p><p>Still, Bank of America expects those 2.5 million Americans will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/unemployed-workers-arent-returning-to-the-labor-force-jobless-benefits-2021-4\">rejoin the workforce</a> by the fall as vaccination continues and the stimulus benefit fades. The remaining 2.1 million will take much longer to join the job market, or may not rejoin at all.</p><p>About 700,000 Americans are expected to have left the workforce due to a mismatch between their skills and available job openings. Training programs can help close the gap but bringing those workers back will take some time, the economists said.</p><p>Separately, 1.2 million workers retired during the health crisis and are unlikely to seek work once the country fully reopens. Another 140,000 workers have been lost due to COVID-19 deaths, the team estimated.</p><p>These longer-term worker shortfalls will influence economic data in two ways. At first, accelerated hiring will see the unemployment rate fall throughout the year. Tighter labor-market conditions will then lead to faster wage growth as businesses pay more to fill their openings.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ee502f22c6b00185db2ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"BofA\" height=\"517\" width=\"1194\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Source: Bank of America Global Research\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bank of America</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Yet those encouraging readings will rest on a less optimistic foundation. The millions of Americans that are unlikely to rejoin the workforce until the fall will leave the labor force participation rate well below its pre-pandemic level.</p><p>There is a &#34;high risk&#34; the participation rate doesn&#39;t fully recover, and demographic trends could drag participation steadily lower over the next decade, the economists said.</p><p>Bank of America reiterated its forecast for the unemployment rate to fall to 4.2% by the end of the year. The benchmark will then return to its pre-pandemic low of 3.5% by the end of 2022, the team said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/employment-outlook-stimulus-virus-fears-labor-market-recovery-participation-bofa-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Winck)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ed86ef22c6b00185db2b7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn57@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-26-668_d6cf52b33cb21f47.webp","https://i.insider.com/608ee502f22c6b00185db2ca?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn35@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-26-145_53c4b46e6c656709.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CHqYNpAQdaI:tJiWaPhyrNM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn40@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-27-326_d5fec5447c950ade.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CHqYNpAQdaI:tJiWaPhyrNM:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CHqYNpAQdaI:tJiWaPhyrNM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn79@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-22-800_b965ddc6fdda725a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/CHqYNpAQdaI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn95@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-24-625_1fbd67921f7bf665.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238427},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Sen. Bernie Sanders says the US needs 'progressive taxation' on the wealthy to pay for Biden's infrastructure proposal","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sanders-progressive-taxation-biden-spending-proposals-infrastructure-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ede7734af8d001859a795?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bernie Sanders\" height=\"2544\" width=\"3816\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont) arrives at the House chamber ahead of President Joe Biden&#39;s first address to a joint session of Congress on April 28, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melina Mara/The Washington Post via AP, Pool</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sen. Bernie Sanders called for &#34;progressive taxation&#34; to fund Biden&#39;s spending proposals.</li>\n<li>&#34;Biden says the floor should be $400,000,&#34; he noted. &#34;Nobody under that should pay more in taxes.&#34;</li>\n<li>Sanders also brought up the need for health care reform and tackling student loan debt.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Independent Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Sunday said that the US needs to institute &#34;progressive taxation&#34; on inherited wealth to help fund President Joe Biden&#39;s spending proposals, notably a $2 trillion infrastructure plan.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/MeetThePress/status/1388850567485743104\">During an appearance</a> on NBC&#39;s &#34;Meet the Press,&#34; Sanders stressed that it was imperative that the country deals with pertinent and longstanding economic issues facing the country.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#34;We have massive income and wealth inequality,&#34; he said. &#34;Half our people live on paycheck to paycheck. We&#39;ve got to raise the minimum wage to a living wage. You&#39;ve got to do that.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Progressive legislators sought to include a $15 minimum wage bill provision in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-biden-signs-trillion-covid-relief-package-checks-direct-payments-2021-3\">the $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief package</a> while it was being debated in Congress earlier this year, but Senate parliamentarian Elizabeth MacDonough <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senate-parliamentarian-elizabeth-macdonough-trump-impeachment-trial-stimulus-minimum-wage-2021-2\">ruled</a> that it could not be included in the final bill under budget reconciliation rules. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Sanders, who has long said that the nation&#39;s infrastructure was in dire need of repair, stressed that Biden&#39;s spending plans would be beneficial to the American public.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#34;We have infrastructure that is collapsing,&#34; he said. &#34;We&#39;ve got to address the existential threat of climate change. When you make those investments, we create millions of good-paying jobs.&#34;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Meet the Press  (@MeetThePress) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388850567485743104?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 2, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p><strong><em>Read more: </em></strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-executive-orders-abortion-gender-lgbtq-transgender-rights-trump-2021-1\"><em>Here&#39;s how Biden is reshaping gender and reproductive rights with policies that are even more progressive than past Democratic presidents</em></a></p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Reminiscent of his 2016 and 2020 presidential campaigns, Sanders also brought up the need for health care reform <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/student-debt-cancelation-biden-civil-rights-organizations-loan-borrowers-2021-4\">and student loan debt</a>, issues that progressives in Congress have not forgotten about.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#34;We are the only major country not to guarantee health care to all people as a right, the only major country not to have paid family and medical leave,&#34; he said. &#34;We pay the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs. Hundreds of thousands of kids can&#39;t afford to go to college, and millions leave school deeply in debt. Well, you know what? You&#39;ve got to address those issues.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Sanders, who chairs the powerful Senate Banking Committee, then went after major corporations that he says haven&#39;t paid any federal income taxes and again called for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bernie-sanders-is-targeting-wealthy-with-two-new-tax-measures-2021-3\">instituting a progressive estate tax rate starting at 45%</a> on inherited wealth of more than $3.5 million. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#34;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/warren-buffett-charlie-munger-berkshire-hathaway-annual-meeting-live-updates-2021-5-1030373616\">Warren Buffett, one of the richest guys in the world</a>, reminds us that the effective tax rate for working families is higher than it is for the billionaire class,&#34; he said. &#34;I do think we need progressive taxation, which says to the very rich - Biden says the cap should be, the floor should be $400,000. Nobody under that should pay more in taxes.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">He added: &#34;The very rich and large corporations should start paying their fair share of taxes to help us rebuild America and create the jobs that we need.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When Sanders was asked if he would back the spending proposals if they don&#39;t come with the desired tax increases, the senator said that &#34;the devil is in the details.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#34;I think once we start discussing these issues in the Congress, there will be differences of opinion,&#34; he said. &#34;I think there is a consensus, at least within the Democratic caucus, that now is the time to start protecting working families and the middle class and not just the 1 percent.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
