VCs are taking note.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startups-boom-before-hot-vax-summer-2021-4","description":"<p><em>Hello!</em></p><p><em>Welcome to this weekly roundup of stories from Insider&#39;s Business co-Editor in Chief Matt Turner. </em><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-weekly\"><strong><em>Subscribe here to get this newsletter in your inbox every Sunday.</em></strong></a></p><p><em>What we&#39;re going over today:</em></p><ul><li>People are flocking to sextech startups, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startup-summer-market-booming-2021-4\">and VCs are taking note.</a> </li><li>Goldman Sachs&#39; CEO is shaking up the bank - <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-ceo-david-solomon-profile-why-partners-leaving-4-21\">and it&#39;s pushing some top execs to the exits.</a></li><li>Six families open up about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buy-a-home-during-pandemic-challenges-stories-bidding-wars-2021-4\">overpaying, losing bidding wars, and settling for fixer-uppers in a bonkers housing market</a>.</li><li>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-most-transformative-ceos-barra-bourla-narayen-huang-2021-4\">most transformative CEOs of 2021.</a></li></ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startup-summer-market-booming-2021-4\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3e0d34af8d001859a4e0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Sextech startups\" height=\"1334\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><p><em>What&#39;s trending this morning:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Google&#39;s push to bring employees back to offices is frustrating some employees:</strong> They <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/googles-resistance-to-going-fully-remote-is-frustrating-employees-2021-4\">say they&#39;ll quit if they can&#39;t be remote forever.</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/googles-resistance-to-going-fully-remote-is-frustrating-employees-2021-4\"></a><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/googles-resistance-to-going-fully-remote-is-frustrating-employees-2021-4\"></a><strong style=\"color: #222222;\">Investment banks are racing to staff up:</strong> One recruiting firm <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investment-banking-recruiters-hiring-goldman-jpmorgan-attrition-analyst-associate-vp-2021-4\">has even formed a &#34;SWAT team&#34; focused on hiring associates and VPs</a>.</li><li><strong><strong>WarnerMedia org chart: </strong></strong>We mapped out the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/warnermedia-org-chart-top-execs-ceo-hbo-max-cnn-2021-4\">112 most powerful people at WarnerMedia after CEO Jason Kilar&#39;s leadership shake-up</a>.</li><li><strong>Etsy is awash with illicit products : </strong>The online marketplace is overflowing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/etsy-sells-ivory-weapons-poisonous-plants-mass-produced-products-2021-4\">with listings for products it says it bans</a>.</li><li><strong>Your glassware is too big:</strong> And <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/your-drinking-alcohol-glasses-are-too-big-other-drinking-advice-2021-4\">other advice about drinking</a>.</li></ul><hr><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startup-summer-market-booming-2021-4\"><strong>Sextech startups are booming</strong></a></h3><p>As Americans prepare for a &#34;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/hot-vaxx-summer-pandemic-horniness-is-coming-blissful-release-2021-3\">hot vax summer</a>,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startup-summer-market-booming-2021-4\">people are flocking to sextech startups</a> for all things sexual wellness. We spoke with five startups that said they&#39;re seeing consumer spending habits change already - and that VCs are also getting in on the fun:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>The pandemic made getting it on more difficult for everyone.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But now that half of American adults have had at least one dose of the vaccine, that could spell the end of a year of celibacy for many. Some are turning to sexual health and wellness startups to have more titillating and safe sex in the summer of love, startup founders and investors say.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>The next several months could be boom times for companies in &#34;sextech&#34; and other sexual wellness businesses, from direct-to-consumer lingerie to birth-control delivery. </em></p><p>More on the red-hot sextech market:</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sextech-startup-summer-market-booming-2021-4\"><strong>People are flocking to sextech startups to stock up on lube and lingerie to prepare for a wild summer of hookups. And VCs are taking notice.</strong></a></li></ul><p>Also read:</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/omada-strategy-sean-duffy-livongo-teladoc-deal-digital-health-2021-4\">His biggest rival scored a $13.9 billion buyout. Now the CEO who helped pioneer the digital health industry is under pressure to make a big move.</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fintech-giant-marqeta-to-become-a-public-company-in-june-2021-4\">$4.3 billion fintech darling Marqeta is planning an IPO as early as June</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/basecamp-workers-flee-what-some-describe-as-autocratic-culture-2021-4\">About a third of Basecamp employees quit after the CEO banned politics and shuttered the DEI committee. Some describe an autocratic culture.</a><br><section></section></li></ul><hr><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-ceo-david-solomon-profile-why-partners-leaving-4-21\"><strong>Goldman Sachs&#39; CEO is changing the bank&#39;s DNA</strong></a></h3><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-ceo-david-solomon-profile-why-partners-leaving-4-21\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608adf9635c46f0018c0b436?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Two images of Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon in a picture frame on a red background.\" height=\"1800\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune; Kena Betancur/Getty Images; Samantha Lee/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><p>David Solomon, who <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-ceo-david-solomon-profile-why-partners-leaving-4-21\">took over as Goldman&#39;s CEO in October 2018</a>, has steered the bank to blowout profits and a record stock price. But with partners quitting and burnout soaring, some insiders say the executive&#39;s hard-charging style has come at a cost: </p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>&#34;David reviews businesses with a dispassionate, clinical eye,&#34; said Jim Esposito, the cohead of Goldman&#39;s investment banking division. &#34;There are no sacred cows.&#34;</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>On paper, it&#39;s working spectacularly. Goldman smashed analysts&#39; expectations and set a revenue record in the first quarter, its stock soared to an all-time high of more than $356, and its ambitious plan to slash $1.3 billion in costs is on track. Wall Street analysts are singing Solomon&#39;s praises, as are investors who laud the transparency Solomon has brought to Goldman&#39;s operations.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But Goldman&#39;s top ranks have seen almost unprecedented turnover, with six members of the management committee exiting over the past year. Among them were two Goldman lifers - Eric Lane and Gregg Lemkau, a potential CEO successor - whose departures stunned Solomon. </em></p><p>More on Solomon&#39;s hard-driving style - and why it may be pushing execs away:</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-ceo-david-solomon-profile-why-partners-leaving-4-21\"><strong>Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon is shaking up the bank with his hard-driving style. Here&#39;s what&#39;s pushing a herd of top execs to the exits.</strong></a></li></ul><p>Also read:</p><section><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rising-stars-top-young-equity-research-analysts-wall-street-2021\">Meet the rising stars of equity research, up-and-comers making calls on everything from the next big electric car maker to the return of live events</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fintech-headhunters-recruiters-hiring-staffing-tech-talent-startups-2021-4\">These 10 headhunters are helping fintechs like Coinbase, Stripe, and SoFi land big hires and stand out in the startup tech talent war</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hedge-funds-citadel-millennium-raiding-big-banks-hiring-volatility-traders-2021-4\">After a year of market shocks and monster trading profits, hedge fund giants like Citadel and Millennium are raiding investment banks for volatility traders</a><br><section></section></li></ul></section><section></section><hr><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buy-a-home-during-pandemic-challenges-stories-bidding-wars-2021-4\"><strong>Pandemic homebuyers open up about their experiences</strong></a></h3><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buy-a-home-during-pandemic-challenges-stories-bidding-wars-2021-4\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3d1334af8d001859a4d8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ilan and Sarah Harel\" height=\"1189\" width=\"1582\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ilan Harel Photography</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><p>Since the start of the pandemic, hopeful homebuyers have been subjected to a buying frenzy that&#39;s led to bidding wars, all-cash sales, sight-unseen purchases, and other leaps of faith - and they did it all in the name of achieving <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buy-a-home-during-pandemic-challenges-stories-bidding-wars-2021-4\">the American dream of homeownership</a>:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>After more than a decade renting in Queens, Ilan and Sarah Harel decided to leave the city and buy for the first time. They ultimately scored a $329,000 property in Pleasant Valley, New York, a Hudson Valley town with fewer than 10,000 residents that is just 90 minutes north of their former digs in Queens.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But snagging their dream home was no easy feat. It was the long-labored-over result of checking listing websites all day long for three months, making offers on properties for thousands of dollars over asking price, and competing with hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers like them who fled the city for greener pastures around the same time.  </em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Their story illuminates a broader reality: The pandemic upended the real-estate market and, as a result, has pushed homeownership further out of reach. </em></p><p>Read their stories here:</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buy-a-home-during-pandemic-challenges-stories-bidding-wars-2021-4\"><strong>Confessions of pandemic homebuyers: 6 families open up about overpaying, losing bidding wars, and settling for fixer-uppers in a bonkers housing market</strong></a></li></ul><p>Also read:</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/single-family-rental-investors-squeeze-regular-homebuyers-cerberus-invitation-homes-2021-4\">Want to buy a home right now? You might have to outbid a $50 billion private equity firm first.</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/real-estate-investing-florida-climate-change-flooding-home-prices-insurance-2021-4\">Betting on Florida real estate could be a big mistake</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/aaron-kirman-real-estate-agent-los-angeles-compass-listing-impossible-2021-4\">A day in the life of LA superbroker Aaron Kirman, who has hit $7 billion in career sales by selling Southern California&#39;s most expensive mansions, estates, and ranches</a><br><section></section></li></ul><hr><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-most-transformative-ceos-barra-bourla-narayen-huang-2021-4\"><strong>Meet the most transformative CEOs of 2021</strong></a></h3><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-most-transformative-ceos-barra-bourla-narayen-huang-2021-4\"><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/606fc16b4d3e410018b70261?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Most impressive CEOs collage including Shantanu Narayen of Adobe, Albert Bourla of Pfizer, Mary Barra of GM, Jensen Huang of NVIDIA\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2501\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>From left: Shantanu Narayen, the CEO of Adobe; Albert Bourla, the CEO of Pfizer; Mary Barra, the CEO of GM; Jensen Huang, the CEO of Nvidia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Adobe; Crystal Cox/Insider; Steve Fecht/General Motors; Courtesy of Nvidia; Skye Gould/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></a></p><p>Leadership in 2021 is marked by transformation - of business models, of workforces, and of organizations themselves. Insider&#39;s inaugural <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-most-transformative-ceos-barra-bourla-narayen-huang-2021-4\">list of the Most Transformative CEOs</a> celebrates four executives who are best meeting the needs of their many stakeholders:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Insider arrived at this list by way of both quantitative and qualitative analysis. We considered the 100 CEOs of the largest publicly traded US companies by market capitalization on the S&#38;P 500 who have been in their positions since at least January 2019. We ruled out executives who are stepping down.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>We evaluated companies and CEOs across measures of recent financial performance, ratings on employee review sites Comparably and Glassdoor, typical employee compensation and the CEO-to-median-pay ratio, and the 2021 Just Capital ranking of companies&#39; commitment to social responsibility.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>We believe the following CEOs exemplify the traits and achievements needed to survive and thrive in that challenging environment.</em></p><p>Read the full profiles of each CEO here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/albert-bourla-profile-pfizer-ceo-leadership-operations-vaccine-pandemic-2021-4\">Albert Bourla is ushering in a new era at Pfizer after leading a historic triumph with a COVID-19 vaccine</a></strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jensen-huang-nvidia-ceo-management-leadership-graphics-ai-cars-2021-4\">CEO Jensen Huang has evolved the $300 billion Nvidia from video-game hardware to AI to autonomous car tech - here&#39;s how he sees around every corner</a></strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mary-barra-gm-management-style-ceo-strategy-pivot-to-electric-2021-4\">How Mary Barra is leading GM as it pivots out of the pandemic and into electric</a></strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/adobe-ceo-shantanu-narayen-leadership-people-centric-policies-strategic-mindset-2021-3\">Here&#39;s how Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen has used people-centric policies and a strategic mindset to lead the software giant</a></strong></li></ul><hr><p>Finally, here are some headlines you might have missed last week.</p><p>- Matt</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/henry-kissenger-interview-politics-after-pandemic-china-europe-2021-4\">INTERVIEW: Henry Kissinger on the political consequences of the pandemic, China&#39;s rise, and the future of the European Union</a><br><section></section></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uber-lyft-drivers-stimulus-labor-workforce-unemployment-2021-4\">Uber and Lyft asked Congress to bail out their drivers. They share 5 stocks they&#39;re bullish on for the long-term - including one they &#39;very comfortably predict&#39; will surge at least 300%.</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/resume-template-college-student-get-a-job-at-spotify-2021-4\">Read the résumé a college senior used to land her dream internship at Spotify and praise from CEO Daniel Ek</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/miss-excel-microsoft-tiktok-instagram-influencer-six-figures-2021-4\">A Microsoft Excel influencer quit her day job and is making 6 figures from her unconventional way of teaching spreadsheet hacks, tips, and tricks</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cnn-business-opens-investigation-into-the-treatment-of-women-employees-2021-4\">CNN Business has launched an internal investigation into the treatment of female employees</a></li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/healthcare-delivery-strategies-unitedhealth-humana-cigna-anthem-cvs-2021-4\">Big insurers like UnitedHealth, Humana, Cigna, and Anthem are moving beyond paying for care. 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Obama thanked Navy SEAL McRaven for overseeing the bin Laden raid by gifting him a tape measure","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/obama-gifted-bin-laden-raid-navy-seal-a-tape-measure-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fb814b032f2170011f705e9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"In this May 6, 2011, file photo President Barack Obama talks with U.S. Navy Vice Admiral William H. McRaven, commander of Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC), at Campbell Army Airfield in Fort Campbell, Ky., just days after McRaven led operational control of Navy SEAL Team Six&#39;s successful mission to get Osama bin Laden\" height=\"2000\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Barack Obama with Navy Vice Adm. William McRaven.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Charles Dharapak</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former President Barack Obama thanked Adm. William McRaven, the Navy SEAL who oversaw the bin Laden raid, with the gift of a tape measure, according to Obama&#39;s 2020 book, &#34;A Promised Land.&#34;</li>\n<li>The gift was an inside joke from the mission and perhaps the first light-hearted moment in a very tense period for everyone involved.</li>\n<li>McRaven also wrote a little about the situation in his book &#34;Sea Stories<strong>,&#34; </strong><strong>which was</strong> published in 2019.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider&#39;s homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As president, Barack Obama thanked Adm. William McRaven, the Navy SEAL who oversaw the raid that took down Osama bin Laden, by giving the military leader a tape measure.</p><p>While the <a href=\"https://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/09/obama-fills-a-gap-in-the-seals-tool-kit/\">unusual gift was reported in 2011</a> a few days after the May mission, both the former president and the retired admiral recounted the inside joke in more detail in their respective memoirs.</p><p>The bin Laden raid was executed by members of SEAL Team Six, who, after a great deal of planning and preparation, slipped into Pakistan early on May 2 (local time) and eliminated the man behind the 9/11 terrorist attacks.</p><p>When the SEALs returned to Jalalabad, Afghanistan, with bin Laden&#39;s body after the early-morning raid on his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, McRaven, who was then the head of Joint Special Operations Command, contacted Obama via video teleconference.</p><p>&#34;McRaven explained that he was looking at the body as we spoke, and that in his judgement it was definitely bin Laden,&#34; Obama wrote in his 2020 book, &#34;A Promised Land<em>.</em>&#34; &#34;To further confirm, McRaven had a six-foot-two member of his team lie next to the body to compare his height to bin Laden&#39;s purported six-foot-four frame.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Seriously, Bill?&#34; Obama recalled himself joking to the admiral. &#34;All that planning and you couldn&#39;t bring a tape measure?&#34; He wrote that it was the first light-hearted thing he&#39;d said all day.</p><p>McRaven wrote in his book &#34;Sea Stories&#34; that when he and some fellow SEALs pulled bin Laden&#39;s body out of the bag in Afghanistan after the Operation Neptune Spear raid, he took a look at the remains, noting to himself that the dead man was tall, just as bin Laden was said to be.</p><p>He turned to one of the special operators nearby, a tall sniper, and asked, &#34;Son, how tall are you?&#34; He caught the SEAL off guard and had to repeat the question, to which the SEAL replied, &#34;Six foot two.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Good,&#34; McRaven said. &#34;Lie down next to the body.&#34;</p><p>Apparently confused, the operator asked, &#34;You want me to lie down next to the body?&#34; The admiral repeated it, and the SEAL did as told. It was visibly clear the dead man was roughly 2 inches taller.</p><p>Talking to Obama over video afterward, he told the president: &#34;Sir, I can&#39;t be 100 percent sure until we do the DNA tests, but it certainly looks like him, and all the physical features match.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;While his face was contorted from the impact of the rounds, I did have a SEAL, who was over six foot two, lie down beside the body, and the remains were at least six foot four.&#34;</p><p>He said there was a noticeably long pause after he made his remarks.</p><p>&#34;So let me get this straight, Bill,&#34; McRaven recalled Obama saying at the time. &#34;We could afford a sixty-million-dollar helo, but we couldn&#39;t afford a tape measure.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I had no comeback and I didn&#39;t need one,&#34; McRaven wrote. &#34;The smile on the President&#39;s face said it all. It had been a good night, and just for a moment we could laugh about it.&#34;</p><p>After returning to the US, the admiral visited the Oval Office, where Obama, according to his book, offered him not only a &#34;heartfelt thanks for his extraordinary leadership&#34; but also a tape measure that the president had mounted to a plaque.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/obama-gifted-bin-laden-raid-navy-seal-a-tape-measure-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a (Ryan Pickrell)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fb814b032f2170011f705e9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-211_26fa28e440000302.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kMNvQXOQObE:ihmise0Xbwg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn82@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-22-187_fd41388162675bf6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kMNvQXOQObE:ihmise0Xbwg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn42@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-26-736_bb814d87cb0849bc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=kMNvQXOQObE:ihmise0Xbwg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn74@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-22-066_2d0ca2a700f00713.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/kMNvQXOQObE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn72@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-450_0ae64b7e36e0f571.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238428},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Biden remembered 'the courage and skill' of US forces on 10-year anniversary of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-bin-laden-death-10-year-anniversary-afghanistan-raid-obama-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c98d1282c500018c78ddb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Obama during Osama Bin Laden campaign.\" height=\"2731\" width=\"4096\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, along with members of the national security team, receive an update on the mission against Osama bin Laden in the Situation Room of the White House on May 1, 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pete Souza/The White House</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Joe Biden issued a statement to mark 10 years since the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.</li>\n<li>&#34;We followed bin Laden to the gates of hell - and we got him,&#34; Biden said.</li>\n<li>Biden has committed to withdrawing troops from Afghanistan by September 11, 2021, the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It has been ten years since US Special Forces conducted a raid in Pakistan that resulted in the death of Osama bin Laden, the mastermind behind the September 11, 2001, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-happened-on-911-why-2016-9\">terror attacks</a>.</p><p>On Sunday, <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/05/02/statement-by-president-joe-biden-on-the-10th-anniversary-of-the-osama-bin-laden-raid/\">President Joe Biden marked the 10-year anniversary of bin Laden&#39;s death</a>, which represented a huge victory for Americans in the fight against terrorism.</p><p>At the time of the raid, Biden was serving as vice president under then-President Barack Obama.</p><p>&#34;Ten years ago, I joined President Obama and members of our national security team, crowded into the Situation Room to watch as our military delivered long-awaited justice to Osama bin Laden,&#34; Biden said in a statement. &#34;It is a moment I will never forget - the intelligence professionals who had painstakingly tracked him down; the clarity and conviction of President Obama in making the call; the courage and skill of our team on the ground.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;It had been almost ten years since our nation was attacked on 9/11 and we went to war in Afghanistan, pursuing al Qaeda and its leaders. We followed bin Laden to the gates of hell - and we got him.&#34;</p><p>After the 9/11 terror attacks, the US invaded Afghanistan to bring down the terrorist organization Al Qaeda. The execution of bin Laden in a compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, on May 2, 2011, was a major accomplishment for the Obama administration.</p><p>&#34;We kept the promise to all those who lost loved ones on 9/11: that we would never forget those we had lost, and that the United States will never waver in our commitment to prevent another attack on our homeland and to keep the American people safe,&#34; Biden continued in his statement.</p><p>Since bin Laden&#39;s death, the US has reduced the number of troops stationed in Afghanistan, and Biden has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-plan-withdraw-us-troops-afghanistan-911-report-2021-4\">committed to withdrawing troops</a> from the country by September 11, 2021, the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks.</p><p>&#34;As we bring to an end America&#39;s longest war and draw down the last of our troops from Afghanistan, al Qaeda is greatly degraded there,&#34; Biden said. &#34;But the United States will remain vigilant about the threat from terrorist groups that have metastasized around the world.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;We will continue to monitor and disrupt any threat to us that emerges from Afghanistan. And we will work to counter terrorist threats to our homeland and our interests in cooperation with allies and partners around the world.&#34;</p><p>Biden ended his statement by thanking the service members that have valiantly fought to protect the US.</p><p>&#34;We will continue to honor all the brave women and men, our military, our intelligence and counterterrorism professionals, and so many others, who continue their extraordinary work to keep the American people safe today,&#34; he said. &#34;They give their best to our country, and we owe them an incredible debt of gratitude.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-bin-laden-death-10-year-anniversary-afghanistan-raid-obama-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/mscqdQbdr0c\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 18:26:40 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f7c98eb94fce90018f7b5f1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7ff7495c6aaa6b89047e24c46cbdf4dd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn62@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-685_cfcb75d04376dd80.webp","destWidth":3640,"destHeight":2730,"sourceBytes":603948,"destBytes":603948,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7c98d1282c500018c78ddb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn88@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-010_bec21539aded86ce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn3@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-250_a2a85011b48e669d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn92@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-27-316_e8d0203f859e3d49.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mscqdQbdr0c:oAIFlU30wUs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn95@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-998_68ead7b4f945efc8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/mscqdQbdr0c":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn22@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-28-144_2eb08c465f268366.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238426},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Sen. Bernie Sanders says US drug companies should relinquish intellectual property rights to COVID-19 vaccines because 'millions of lives are at stake around the world'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sanders-drug-companies-should-relinquish-ip-rights-to-covid-19-vaccines-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ebcd134af8d001859a778?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bernie Sanders\" height=\"970\" width=\"1941\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders during an appearance on NBC News&#39; &#34;Meet the Press.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Meet the Press/NBC</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sen. Bernie Sanders repeated calls for pharmaceutical companies to relinquish intellectual property rights to COVID-19 vaccines.</li>\n<li>If companies like Pfizer and Moderna relinquished IP rights, their vaccines could be produced globally. </li>\n<li>But the companies have opposed these calls, claiming risks to vaccine safety.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders on Sunday called for drug companies to waive intellectual property rights to their COVID-19 vaccines so that the inoculations can be produced by various countries in an effort to slow the spread of the deadly disease in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/india-first-country-to-record-400000-single-day-coronavirus-cases-2021-5\">hard-hit nations, like India.</a></p><p>&#34;We have got to obviously make sure that every American gets vaccinated as quickly as possible,&#34; Sanders said during an appearance on <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/meet-the-press/video/full-portman-there-s-a-way-forward-for-a-bipartisan-agreement-on-infrastructure-111204933909?cid=sm_npd_nn_tw_mtp\">NBC News&#39; &#34;Meet the Press.&#34;</a> &#34;But not only do we have a moral responsibility to help the rest of the world, it&#39;s in our own self-interest. If this pandemic continues to spread in other countries, it&#39;s going to come back and bite us at one point or another.&#34; </p><p>Sanders, an Independent, also weighed in on the debate over whether US pharmaceutical companies should relinquish their intellectual property rights to allow other <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-says-millions-of-americans-skipping-second-covid-19-dose-2021-4\">companies across the world to produce vaccines.</a></p><p>&#34;The second thing we should do is not only make sure that excess vaccines in the United States get around to countries that need it. We should deal with this issue through the World Trade Organization.</p><p>&#34;And I think what we have got to say right now to the drug companies - when millions of lives are at stake around the world - yes, allow other countries to have these intellectual property rights so they can produce the vaccines that are desperately needed in poor countries,&#34; he said. </p><p>Sanders and nine other Senate Democrats urged President Joe Biden last week to put his support behind a temporary patent waiver that would allow vaccines to be produced locally by other manufacturers, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/senators-urge-biden-back-temporary-wto-waiver-ip-rights-speed-vaccine-access-2021-04-16/\">Reuters</a> reported.</p><p>Pharmaceutical companies, including Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson &#38; Johnson, and the US Chamber of Commerce have opposed such calls.</p><p>They argue that allowing other manufacturers to produce their vaccines could lead to issues with safety. More than 80 WHO members have backed a proposal by India and South Africa to temporarily wave the IP rights of the companies. The issue will be discussed by the WTO this month, according to Reuters.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-to-help-india-with-covid-19-crisis-through-vaccine-production-supplies-2021-4\">Biden administration last week</a> said it would send supplies to India so it could <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vaccine-manufacturer-fled-india-covid-19-threats-2021-5\">ramp up more vaccines</a> as it deals with its ongoing surge.</p><p>&#34;There is something morally objectionable about rich countries being able to get their vaccines, yet millions and billions in poor countries are unable to afford it,&#34; Sanders said Sunday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/sanders-drug-companies-should-relinquish-ip-rights-to-covid-19-vaccines-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=O37FYGtjXdY:0TSRG_4S29o:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ebcd134af8d001859a778?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-27-423_7743a3e99d813b80.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O37FYGtjXdY:0TSRG_4S29o:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn75@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-24-172_a6a437e3211de9cb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O37FYGtjXdY:0TSRG_4S29o:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn30@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-27-856_cc19706b9890d993.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O37FYGtjXdY:0TSRG_4S29o:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn8@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-928_f4681de971db56d6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/O37FYGtjXdY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn47@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-26-127_f2aa20b1e49b3518.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"The leader of one of the world's biggest vaccine manufacturers said he fled India because of menacing threats","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/vaccine-manufacturer-fled-india-covid-19-threats-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e968e34af8d001859a741?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serum Institute of India&#39;s CEO Adar Poonawalla.\" height=\"1999\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serum Institute of India&#39;s CEO Adar Poonawalla.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/serum-institute-of-indias-ceo-adar-poonawalla-gestures-news-photo/1230727609?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">-/AFP via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Adar Poonawalla, the leader of a major vaccine manufacturer, said he fled India due to threats.</li>\n<li>Poonawalla leads the Serum Institute, the world&#39;s largest vaccine manufacturer.</li>\n<li>The COVID-19 situation in India is so dire that Poonawalla said people have been hurling threats at him, accusing him of delaying vaccines on purpose.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The CEO of the Serum Institute, a vaccine manufacturer in India, said he fled the country because of incessant threats against him. </p><p>In an <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/adar-poonawalla-aggression-over-covid-vaccines-is-overwhelming-everyone-expects-to-get-theirs-first-bfqbgcm96?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=16198538343834\">interview</a> with the Times of London, Adar Poonawalla said he went to England to escape threats from people claiming he&#39;s holding up vaccines.</p><p>&#34;&#39;Threats&#39; is an understatement,&#34; Poonawalla said. &#34;The level of expectation and aggression is really unprecedented.&#34;</p><p>&#34;It&#39;s overwhelming. Everyone feels they should get the vaccine. They can&#39;t understand why anyone else should get it before them,&#34; he added. &#34;They are saying if you don&#39;t give us the vaccine it&#39;s not going to be good. It&#39;s not foul language. It&#39;s the tone. It&#39;s the implication of what they might do if I don&#39;t comply.&#34;</p><p>The Serum Institute is the world&#39;s largest vaccine manufacturer, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-55748124#:~:text=What%20about%20Covishield%3F,60%20million%20doses%20a%20month.\">producing more than 60 million doses</a> of the AstraZeneca and Oxford vaccine every month. </p><p>At the time of his interview, Poonawalla said he&#39;d stay in England for &#34;an extended time, because I don&#39;t want to go back to that situation.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Everything falls on my shoulders, but I can&#39;t do it alone,&#34; he added. </p><p>Hours after the interview was published, Poonawalla backtracked and wrote on Twitter that he&#39;d return to India &#34;in a few days.&#34;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Adar Poonawalla  (@adarpoonawalla) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388559173219016704?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 1, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>The news of his departure from India comes as the country experiences deep surges in positive COVID-19 cases.</p><p>The nation reported a record high of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/india-first-country-to-record-400000-single-day-coronavirus-cases-2021-5\">401,993 new cases of COVID-19</a> on Saturday. No other country has breached 400,000 daily cases.</p><p>Crematoriums across India are overwhelmed with bodies. Patients are <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-05-01-21/h_3485a084f1fa06acfc2aa0d1cd2046fd?tab=India\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"3f80235c5114f2d0f480969fa1ccea63\">dying</a> as hospitals run out of oxygen. The country had reported more than 300,000 new cases each day for nine consecutive days before hitting the 400,000 mark.</p><p>India also reported more than 3,500 deaths on Saturday - the fourth day in a row that death counts have surpassed 3,000. Those numbers are likely an undercount. A<strong> </strong><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/24/world/asia/india-coronavirus-deaths.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-vars-link-text=\"New York Times\" data-vars-click-url=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/24/world/asia/india-coronavirus-deaths.html\" data-vars-event-category=\"story\" data-vars-sub-category=\"story\" data-vars-item=\"in_content_link\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"76b978d023a8ef58b150bbda8b10509f\">New York Times</a> investigation published this week found &#34;mounting evidence&#34; that suggested fatalities are being &#34;overlooked or downplayed&#34; by the government. </p><p>The situation has gotten so bad that people have surrounded his company multiple times and called him a &#34;profiteer&#34; of the COVID-19 vaccines.</p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t think even God could have forecast it was going to get this bad,&#34; Poonawalla said in the interview.</p><p><em>Insider&#39;s Morgan McFall-Johnsen contributed to this report.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"AstraZeneca has drawn criticism for saying it can't share its vaccine tech with the WHO because it has no engineers available 'to brief people and train them'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/astrazeneca-no-engineers-available-to-share-covid-19-vaccine-tech-with-who-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/601f431acca90200129b6dce?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astrazeneca vaccine\" height=\"1312\" width=\"1749\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>AstraZeneca recently took part in a shareholder Q&#38;A.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters/Dado Ruvic</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>AstraZeneca recently said it had no engineers to assist in the transfer of vaccine technology.</li>\n<li>The statement by the company&#39;s CEO was made during a shareholder Q&#38;A.</li>\n<li>It has drawn criticism from campaign groups and other industry observers.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Health industry observers and social justice groups have criticized recent comments by AstraZeneca&#39;s CEO about sharing its vaccine technology. </p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-astrazeneca-vaccine-side-effects-not-as-bad-as-trials-2021-4\">AstraZeneca</a> said it could not share such technology with the World Health Organization (WHO) because it had no engineers available to assist in the technology transfer. </p><p>The comments were made by chief executive Pascal Soriot during a shareholder Q&#38;A on Friday.</p><p>The People&#39;s Vaccine Alliance, a global coalition of civil society organizations, pressed AstraZeneca on providing access to its technology.</p><p>&#34;There is no way, even if we give access to the technology and we told people &#39;here is the recipe&#39;,&#34; Soriot responded during the Q&#38;A, &#34;there is no way we could train these people to manufacture the vaccine because our engineers are flat out working with our existing partners.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;The solution is to increase the yield in the existing plants, not to create more plants, because we have no engineers to brief people and train them.&#34;</p><p>The CEO&#39;s response has been met with criticism. Heidi Chow, the lead campaigner at Global Justice Now, a social justice organization, accused the company of &#34;making excuses for their complicity in vaccine apartheid,&#34; after the firm dismissed efforts to join the <a href=\"https://www.who.int/initiatives/covid-19-technology-access-pool\">WHO&#39;s COVID-19 Technology Access Pool.</a></p><p>The comment was &#34;utterly unacceptable,&#34; Chow said, adding that it was proof of why governments &#34;should never have trusted a small number of companies to vaccinate the world.&#34;</p><p>Katie Mellor, an Oxford vaccine trial volunteer, said she found the comments to be &#34;deeply offensive&#34; as people across the world continue to die in the absence of vaccines. </p><p>An AstraZeneca spokesperson told Insider in a statement: &#34;Vaccine manufacturing is highly complex, and accelerating production at this scale and speed requires partners around the world with capabilities to manufacture using our standard process to ensure consistency and quality of the vaccine.&#34;</p><p>The spokesperson said AstraZeneca was the first company to sign up to COVAX, &#34;for which our vaccine has provided 98% of all supply to date. The majority of doses supplied through COVAX are for low and middle-income countries.&#34;</p><p>The statement continued. &#34;To deliver on our commitment to broad and equitable access and accelerate vaccine production, we have enabled technology transfer to more than 20 different supply partners across more than 15 countries around the globe.&#34;</p><p>It added: &#34;Vaccine manufacturing is highly complex, and accelerating production at this scale and speed requires partners around the world with capabilities to manufacture using our standard process to ensure consistency and quality of the vaccine.&#34;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The call to share technology and expertise for vaccine production through the WHO&#39;s technology pool comes amid vaccine shortages in many developing countries. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Countries that have been hit hard in recent weeks include <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/india-coronavirus-crisis-who-europe-head-warns-could-happen-anywhere-2021-4\">India, which has been battling an unprecedented COVID-19 surge</a> that was overwhelming hospitals and crematoria. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">At the time of writing, India has reported more than 19 million COVID-19 cases and more than 216,000 deaths. </p><div Craig Longley’s YouTube channel dedicated to physical therapy. The page has since been deleted.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CRAIG LONGLEY YOUTUBE VIDEO/ Vice News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Prominent QAnon influencer &#39;InevitableET&#39; has been identified as Craig Longley, <a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/7kvzmq/this-crossfit-chiropractor-is-secretly-one-of-qanons-leading-influencers\">Vice</a> reported.</li>\n<li>The antisemitic conspiracy theorist works as a chiropractor in Denver, Colorado.</li>\n<li>He runs one of the most famous QAnon Telegram channels. It has over 200,000 subscribers.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>One of QAnon&#39;s most openly antisemitic influencers has been hiding in plain sight as a chiropractor in Denver, a <a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/7kvzmq/this-crossfit-chiropractor-is-secretly-one-of-qanons-leading-influencers\">Vice investigation</a> revealed.</p><p>Craig Longley, originally from Texas, has been living a double life for several years; running a popular <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/qanon-history-who-is-q-conspiracy-theory-what-does-believe-2021-2\">QAnon</a> channel on Telegram, and working as a healthcare professional in Colorado.</p><p>Known to his far-right followers as InevitableET, Longley has gone to great lengths to protect his true identity since 2017.</p><p>But he has now been identified through images of him used on his social media channels and by those in Denver who know him, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/daithaigilbert\">Vice&#39;s David Gilbert said.</a></p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/qanon-into-the-storm-cullen-hoback-ron-jim-watkins-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">&#39;QAnon: Into the Storm&#39; director Cullen Hoback talks about how 2 random guys trolled the entire world and inspired a deadly insurrection</a></em></p><p>A former client of Longley at his <a href=\"https://www.tmpdenver.com/\">downtown Denver clinic</a>, who asked to be referred to as Maria, is one of the people who helped identify Longley. She told Vice that she met him at a CrossFit gym in 2016.</p><p>She later signed up to chiropractic sessions with him and told the media outlet that Longley spoke to her about Jeffrey Epstein, Hillary Clinton, and the Obamas - popular boogeymen in the QAnon world.</p><p>&#34;He was effectively trying to red pill me,&#34; Maria said.</p><p>Longley has also been identified via content he shared on his QAnon accounts. Three individuals, who were granted anonymity, told Vice that a profile picture of him used on his InevitableET Twitter account and an Instagram video of him reciting the QAnon Oath match the image of Longley.</p><p>A Vice review of content posted on his InevitableET pages shows that Longley has embraced many far-right views for at least four years. He has supported <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/voter-fraud-debunked-isaac-saul-viral-election-thread-conspiracy-theories-2020-11\">election fraud myths</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/experts-explain-why-virus-deniers-ignore-covid-19-warnings-2020-9\">COVID-19 denial</a>, and the popular QAnon lie that Democratic politicians are part of a shadowy cabal of pedophiles, Vice said.</p><p>Much of the conspiracy theorist&#39;s content has also focused on vicious antisemitism, Gilbert reported. He has taken part in the &#34;Blue the Jew&#34; movement, where antisemites photoshop notable Jews blue to identify them, Vice added.</p><p>He has also claimed in Instagram posts that Jews are attempting to enslave the world and has endorsed material from the &#34;Protocols of the Elders of Zion&#34; - an infamous antisemitic conspiracy theory from the early 20th century.</p><p>In 2019, Vice reported, Longley achieved any QAnon influencer&#39;s dream; he was retweeted by then-President Donald Trump. In that tweet, he falsely claimed that &#34;Trump has not been impeached.&#34;</p><p>But, following the January 6 insurrection, his Twitter account was suspended.</p><p>His banishment led him to establish the &#34;We The Media&#34; Telegram channel - one of the most popular forums for hardcore adherents of the discredited QAnon movement. It now has over 200,000 subscribers.</p><p>Longley&#39;s clout in the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lin-wood-attorney-makes-qanon-gestures-receives-standing-ovation-2021-4\">QAnon world</a> has also provided him with an opportunity to speak at an upcoming conference in Dallas, Texas.</p><p>The now-identified influencer will be speaking at the &#34;For God &#38; Country Patriots Roundup&#34; Memorial Day weekend event alongside controversial attorney <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/trump-promoted-sidney-powell-in-november-despite-calling-her-crazy-2021-1\">Sidney Powell</a>, former national security advisor <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/michael-flynn-trump-pardon-qanon-2020-12\">Michael Flynn</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-not-stopping-louie-gohmert-gop-from-fundraisers-2020-7?utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=sf-bi-main&utm_source=facebook.com&fbclid=IwAR0fZBGUwrjzdBcUmPLTRaYBX9AjlGfPOfbarUFSX9GDXDa9amrroZli--c9amrroZli--c\">Rep. Louie Gohmert</a>, and Texas GOP chair <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/allen-west-obama-united-nations-islam-2012-9\">Allen West</a>, <a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/dyvg8z/a-huge-qanon-conference-is-happening-in-a-dallas-hotel-owned-by-the-city\">Vice said</a>.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"CNN's Jake Tapper questions why Biden is still wearing a mask outside even after a change in CDC src=\"https://i.insider.com/608eb34e34af8d001859a76d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jake tapper cnn\" height=\"714\" width=\"1429\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>CNN host Jake Tapper and senior Biden advisor, Anita Dunn.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CNN/YouTube</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>CNN&#39;s Jake Tapper said Friday that Biden &#34;doesn&#39;t seem to be following&#34; the newest CDC guidelines.</li>\n<li>Tapper asked Biden&#39;s senior advisor Anita Dunn why the president was still wearing a mask outdoors.</li>\n<li>Dunn responded that &#34;extra precautions&#34; have to be taken for Biden because he is the president.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>CNN anchor Jake Tapper questioned why President Joe Biden was still wearing a face covering outdoors despite a recent change in mask guidelines for fully-vaccinated people.</p><p>In an <a href=\"https://www.mediaite.com/tv/jake-tapper-questions-biden-adviser-on-whether-the-presidents-being-over-cautious-with-mask-wearing/\">interview</a> with Biden&#39;s senior advisor <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/book-biden-advisor-says-he-got-lucky-during-election-covid-2021-3\">Anita Dunn</a> on Friday, Tapper asked why the president &#34;doesn&#39;t seem to be following&#34; the latest guidelines, which were announced by The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on Tuesday. </p><p>The agency said that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/chart-cdc-new-mask-guidance-for-fully-vaccinated-explained-2021-4\">outdoor activities are now considered safe</a> without face masks as long as people stay in their own household. They also said fully vaccinated people can gather <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-fully-vaccinated-americans-can-go-maskless-outside-some-situations-2021-4\">indoors without masks</a> in small groups. The new guidance only applies to those who&#39;ve allowed their shot(s) two full weeks to take effect.</p><p>Biden, who is 78 years old, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-hit-goal-100-million-vaccines-100-days-ahead-schedule-2021-3\">received the Pfizer vaccine</a> in December last year.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-staff-center-for-american-progress-podesta-tanden-think-tank-2021-3\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">Center for American Progress alumni are filling the Biden administration. Almost 100 days in, the roster is 60 and counting.</a></em></p><p>&#34;Should the president start following these guidelines and stop wearing a mask outdoors, stop wearing a mask indoors when with small groups of other vaccinated Americans, to show the American people there is a benefit to getting the vaccine, you can take the mask off?&#34; Tapper asked Dunn, <a href=\"https://www.mediaite.com/tv/jake-tapper-questions-biden-adviser-on-whether-the-presidents-being-over-cautious-with-mask-wearing/\">according to Mediaite.</a></p><p>The CNN host also made reference to a quote from former health commissioner of Baltimore, Dr. Leana Wen, who told the network on Friday that being &#34;overly cautious&#34; with face masks could actually discourage people from getting vaccinated.</p><p>&#34;I think over-caution also has a price and that masks somehow become a performative act rather than a life-saving act when it&#39;s really needed, and also, it&#39;s really underselling the power of the vaccine,&#34; Wen said, according to Tapper.</p><p>Dunn said Biden &#34;takes the CDC guidelines very seriously.&#34;</p><p>&#34;We do take some extra precautions for him because he is the president of the United States,&#34; she said, according to Mediaite. &#34;But I would say that people should follow the CDC guidelines and they should take advantage of getting the vaccine, getting fully vaccinated, and taking that mask off, particularly as the weather grows so beautiful and we all want to be outside.&#34; </p><p>This is the third time the CDC has adjusted its guidance for the fully vaccinated. In March, the CDC said it was acceptable for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-guidance-what-can-covid-19-vaccinated-people-do-2021-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"5f1b2a4ef13dc40ef34a2967dd1651d7\">fully vaccinated people to gather indoors</a> and hug without masks.</p><section><p>More than 243 million doses have already been administered to Americans so far. In the last week, an average of 2.55 million doses per day were administered, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/\">according to a Bloomberg vaccine tracker.</a></p></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Sophia Ankel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608eb34e34af8d001859a76d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn83@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-809_8bcbb5e33623fdff.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2lDjPJy4EQ:2YZeq5bCbeU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-22-978_bb46defc8113c1ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2lDjPJy4EQ:2YZeq5bCbeU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn70@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-28-046_901d8eae7c3ba41e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Q2lDjPJy4EQ:2YZeq5bCbeU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn19@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-766_a05d84f5f67618c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Q2lDjPJy4EQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn85@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-26-741_946ec6b2926a5d3f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"A petition urging the government to give $2,000 monthly stimulus checks to every American has surpassed 2 million signatures","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/petition-monthly-stimulus-checks-2000-signed-2-million-people-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608eb498f22c6b00185db28e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"protest stimulus\" height=\"2854\" width=\"5708\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Protesters rally demanding economic relief during the coronavirus pandemic in New York City on August 5, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Angela Weiss/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A petition calling for $2,000 monthly stimulus checks has reached more than 2 million signatures.</li>\n<li>The petition argues the three stimulus checks released over the course of a year have not been sufficient to deal with the financial repercussions brought on by the pandemic.</li>\n<li>Senate Democrats have been urging both Congress to pass recurring relief checks to stave off financial difficulty.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>More than 2 million people have so far signed a petition calling for monthly stimulus checks in the amount of $2,000 to support Americans as the pandemic continues. </p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.change.org/p/give-2000-month-to-every-american-moneyforthepeople-covid19?source_location=petitions_browse\">petition</a>, which was first posted on Change.org last year, was started by Colorado restaurant owner Stephanie Bonin. </p><p>&#34;I&#39;m calling on Congress to support families with a $2,000 payment for adults and a $1,000 payment for kids immediately, and continuing regular checks for the duration of the crisis,&#34; Bonin wrote on the petition. &#34;Otherwise, laid-off workers, furloughed workers, the self-employed, and workers dealing with reduced hours will struggle to pay their rent or put food on the table.&#34;</p><p>In the petition, Bonin urges Congress to issue &#34;immediate checks and recurring payments.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Congress needs to make sure that we won&#39;t be financially ruined for doing our part to keep the country healthy,&#34; she wrote.</p><p>There have been three rounds of stimulus checks in the last 15 months since the onset of the pandemic. </p><p>The last stimulus check was passed under President Joe Biden in the amount of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/1400-stimulus-checks-already-landing-in-peoples-bank-accounts-2021-3\">$1,400</a> to eligible Americans. Congress has been slow to issue stimulus checks because of partisan disagreements between Republicans and Democrats. Each party has had different visions of the amount allocated per check and other relief measures the overall spending package would include.</p><p>The Trump administration issued two stimulus checks - the first in the amount of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/coronavirus-stimulus-check-questions-answers-2020-4\">$1,200</a> and the second in the amount of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/second-stimulus-check\">$600</a>. Nine months passed between both rounds.</p><p>Bonin criticized the amount of time it took Congress to come to an agreement. </p><p>&#34;Another single check won&#39;t solve our problems - people are just too far behind,&#34; Bonin wrote on the petition. &#34;Like we&#39;ve been saying from the beginning of this pandemic, people need to know when the next check is coming. And the best thing our government can do right now is send emergency money to the people on a monthly basis.&#34;</p><p>Bonin&#39;s petition has garnered so much support that Change.org recognized it in its <a href=\"https://www.change.org/l/us/change-org-releases-top-ten-petitions-that-changed-2020\">list</a> of top 10 petitions that changed 2020. </p><p>Senate Democrats have been urging both Congress and the Biden administration to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/10-senate-dems-tell-biden-implement-recurring-stimulus-checks-2021-3\">pass recurring relief checks</a> to help stave off the financial devastation brought on by the coronavirus. </p><p>&#34;Supplying Americans with monthly support until they can get back on their feet can save our communities from financial ruin,&#34; Bonin wrote.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/petition-monthly-stimulus-checks-2000-signed-2-million-people-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
