border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/TBoJqEKgRQE\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 14:36:05 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608ea8ee34af8d001859a760?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"95390840c234e7657b97b16c715ab778","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn35@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-670_fa1232bbb0e8d080.webp","destWidth":4996,"destHeight":3747,"sourceBytes":257012,"destBytes":257012,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608eb498f22c6b00185db28e?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TBoJqEKgRQE:htPaeDYlKX4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn76@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-22-808_fcbb420d985d8681.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TBoJqEKgRQE:htPaeDYlKX4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn40@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-712_eff799872b49b80c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TBoJqEKgRQE:htPaeDYlKX4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn42@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-22-220_8b72cb41ad01d503.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/TBoJqEKgRQE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn17@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-25-560_b4792c1feafb1452.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"7 mentally tough people and the tactics they used to build resilience and perform under pressure","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/building-mental-strength-resilience-to-perform-under-pressure-2021-5","description":"<p><a href=\"https://www.laurenjohnsonandco.com/\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ad08134af8d0018599e68?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kobe Bryant\" height=\"2757\" width=\"4142\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mental performance coach Lauren Johnson says Kobe Bryant created the alter ego &#34;Black Mamba&#34; to give him confidence on the court.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Harry How / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Mentally strong people often use specific practices to build their resilience, says writer Polina Marinova.</li>\n<li>At least two of them - Kobe Bryant and David Goggins - created alter egos to build confidence.</li>\n<li>Mental performance coach Lauren Johnson says these tactics can help you overcome fear and defeat.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.laurenjohnsonandco.com/\">Lauren Johnson</a> is a mental performance coach who most recently worked with the New York Yankees, where she helped develop strategies for athletes and sports professionals to help them cultivate mental resilience.</p><p>In this conversation, Johnson and I deconstruct the strategies and tactics of seven mentally tough people and how they learned to perform under pressure. Below is a summary of our conversation, <a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/7-mentally-tough-people-on-tactics-they-use-to-build/id1554109805?i=1000510318492\">but you can listen on Apple Podcasts</a>.</p><h2>1. David Goggins, the toughest athlete on the planet</h2><p>David Goggins grew up living in fear. At school, he experienced incessant bullying and racism. At home, he suffered physical and emotional abuse at the hands of his own father.</p><p>By the time Goggins was in his early 20s, he had asthma, a learning disability, a stutter, and crushingly low self-esteem. He was earning less than $1,000 a month spraying for cockroaches.</p><p>One night, he came home with a 42-ounce shake from Steak and Shake and sat down in front of the TV. He stumbled upon a documentary on the US Navy SEALs  that changed the trajectory of his entire life.</p><p>Through a relentless determination and grit, Goggins went on to complete three Navy SEAL &#34;hell weeks,&#34; more than 50 endurance races, and holds the Guinness World Record for most pull-ups (4,030) in 24 hours.</p><p>He used a number of mental strategies to help him become mentally unshakeable.</p><p><strong>Create an alter ego:</strong> Goggins believes he was built, not born. He intentionally created <a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/why-the-worlds-most-confident-people\">a separate identity</a> that separated him from his past of bullying, fear, and abuse. &#34;I had to create &#39;Goggins,&#39; because &#39;David Goggins&#39; was a weak kid. So I created &#39;Goggins,&#39;&#34; he said. &#34;I wanted to be proud of who I was.&#34;</p><p>Johnson says that self-distancing is a helpful strategy in helping us manage our emotions better. &#34;When you create an alter ego, it actually feels like we have a choice, and we&#39;re not identifying with who we are in that very moment but that we have a choice to be who we want to be. When we distance slightly, we give ourselves the ability to choose.&#34;</p><p><strong>Follow the 40% rule:</strong> There&#39;s a reason why even though most people hit a wall at mile 16 during a marathon, they&#39;re still able to finish. Goggins explains it through his 40% rule: When your mind is telling you that you&#39;re done, that you&#39;re exhausted, that you cannot possibly go any further, you&#39;re only actually 40% done.</p><p>&#34;Your brain is wired to protect you,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;Most of the time our brain will show up to protect us when we don&#39;t need protecting.&#34; If you do one difficult task per day, you can increase your threshold for discomfort.&#34;</p><p><strong>Face the accountability mirror:</strong> When Goggins decided to become a Navy SEAL, he looked at his reflection in the mirror and said, &#34;You&#39;re fat, you&#39;re lazy, and you&#39;re a liar.&#34; This sounds harsh, but Goggins says that he needed to face his insecurities head on in order to overcome them. He created something he called the &#34;Accountability Mirror.&#34; He pasted sticky notes around the outside of the mirror outlining the practical steps he needed to take to achieve his goals. They would say things like, &#34;Go one day without lying for external validation&#34; and &#34;Go on a 2-mile run.&#34; If you&#39;re not happy with your reflection, Goggins suggests asking yourself, &#34;What am I going to do today to change what I see in the mirror?&#34;</p><p>Johnson says this strategy is so powerful because you are the only person in the world you can&#39;t lie to and get away with it. &#34;The same way we earn trust with others by doing the things we say we&#39;re going to do is the same way we earn trust with ourselves,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;When you talk to yourself in the mirror, it opens up your blind spots and the things you may not want to admit to yourself. It may hurt, but it&#39;s so necessary to get to that next level.&#34;</p><h2><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-courtney-dauwalter\">2. Courtney Dauwalter, the ultra-runner who personifies pain</a></h2><p>In 2017, Dauwalter dominated the headlines after she won the Moab 240, a 240.3 mile footrace through some of Utah&#39;s most challenging terrain. It took her 58 hours, and she beat the second place finisher by more than 10 hours. In 2018, she won the Western States Endurance Run, which is 100 miles, in 17 hours and 27 minutes. The list of impressive achievements goes on and on.</p><p>Dauwalter credits her success to being able to master the art of suffering. She has managed to stay calm even through bouts of severe nausea, a bleeding head injury, and temporary blindness. &#34;I don&#39;t think those types of pain and suffering are signs you should stop,&#34; she said. &#34;I mean, I troubleshoot and try to fix what&#39;s causing it, but my solution is usually to just keep going.&#34; Here&#39;s how she does it:</p><p><strong>Embrace the &#34;pain cave:&#34;</strong> Dauwalter talks about pain as an actual place: the pain cave. The reason it&#39;s helpful to personify pain is that it serves as a reminder that you&#39;re in control when you enter and equally as aware that you can leave. &#34;It&#39;s not a place I&#39;m scared to enter,&#34; she said. &#34;It&#39;s a place I&#39;m excited to find the entrance to.&#34;</p><p>Johnson says there&#39;s an important distinction between listening to yourself and talking to yourself. You should avoid the former and encourage the latter. When you listen to yourself, you hear all the negativity and all the reasons why you can&#39;t go on, she said, but when you talk to yourself, you can tell yourself the things you need to hear in order to overcome the challenge ahead of you. Johnson adds: &#34;Courtney approached it with a challenge mindset instead of a threat mindset. That&#39;s why she&#39;s performing from a place of power instead of a place of fear.&#34;</p><p><strong>Stay motivated with a &#34;carrot&#34; goal: </strong>In one ultra-race, Dauwalter&#39;s goal was to complete 200 miles in 48 hours. But she had a rough race, and another competitor passed her for first place in the very last stretch. She needed to find another reason to continue pushing her body, so her new goal became: &#34;If you&#39;re not going to get first place, then try to finish under the 50-hour mark.&#34; It became a new &#34;carrot to dangle.&#34;</p><p>Same goes for everyday life. If you fall short of a goal, you can find another carrot that will keep you motivated and get you closer to the goal for your next attempt. &#34;Be committed to the outcome that you want,&#34; Johnson said, &#34;but stay flexible in your approach.&#34;</p><h2><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-tara-westover\">3. Tara Westover, the relentless student who overcame it all</a></h2><p>Tara Westover was 17 years old when she set foot in a classroom for the first time. Born to survivalist Mormon parents in the mountains of Idaho, she grew up isolated from mainstream society. Her father had a severe mistrust of the government to the point where he forbade the family from visiting hospitals or attending school.</p><p>She taught herself enough algebra to pass the college entrance exams and became a competitive applicant to Brigham Young University. There, she studied history and learned for the first time about world events like the Holocaust and the civil rights movement.</p><p>&#34;For some people, education is self-determination, and that&#39;s what it was for me, and for other people, it&#39;s like predetermination and it&#39;s something that keeps them down,&#34; she said. &#34;It&#39;s like the difference of education being a ladder or being a fence.&#34;</p><p>Here&#39;s what she learned along the way:</p><p><strong>Don&#39;t mistake your reality as the only truth:</strong> When Westover was growing up, she considered her father&#39;s opinion as &#34;the truth.&#34; After she began to attend school, she realized that there is no universal, absolute truth. Our version of the world is not the only version - it is simply one of many, many perspectives. It takes strength and courage to start questioning your own family&#39;s beliefs and opinions in order to adopt ones more in line with your own path.</p><p>&#34;At first people are going to tell you that you can&#39;t do something out of their own fears,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;But the second you start doing what you want to do and you start doing it well, they&#39;re going to tell everybody how they met you.&#34;</p><p><strong>Break your patterns:</strong> When Westover used to return to her family&#39;s home, she felt herself falling right back into the same identity she once had - that fearful and insecure 16-year-old girl. As kids, some of us learn unhealthy patterns from our parents.</p><p>The second we venture out on our own, we feel liberated and changed, but as soon as we get back in that familiar environment, we repeat the same patterns. &#34;The environment is that invisible hand that shapes us, which is why it&#39;s so important to pay attention to who you&#39;re surrounding yourself with,&#34; Johnson said. Spend your time with people who challenge your existing beliefs and teach you to be more resilient.</p><h2><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-anthony-ray-hinton\">4. Anthony Ray Hinton, the man who survived death row</a></h2><p>In 1985, Anthony Ray Hinton was arrested and wrongfully charged with two counts of capital murder in Alabama. Hinton knew it was a case of mistaken identity and naively believed that the truth would prove his innocence and set him free.</p><p>But as a poor black man in the South, Hinton was sentenced to death by electrocution. He maintained his innocence through the entire duration of the 30 years he served on death row, which makes him one of the longest serving death row prisoners in Alabama history.</p><p>In his time on death row, Hinton watched 54 men walk past his cell to be executed. Another 22 took their own lives. &#34;My cell was 30 feet from the chamber, and I could smell the burning flesh,&#34; he writes. Yet he managed to maintain hope and befriend those society had given up on.</p><p><strong>Visualize a better reality:</strong> On death row, Hinton figured out a technique that was able to get him out of his tragic circumstances: Daydreaming. While in his cell, Hinton traveled the world, married Halle Berry, had tea with Queen Elizabeth, and won Wimbledon - all in his mind. &#34;I never used my mind for garbage,&#34; he said. &#34;I used it to cope through some lonely days.&#34; Hinton started a book club for fellow inmates who also wanted to experience the power of visualization.</p><p>&#34;The cool thing about visualization is that our brain doesn&#39;t know the difference between imagination and reality,&#34; Johnson says. &#34;It&#39;s the same as watching a movie - we&#39;re not part of the movie, but we&#39;re having an emotional reaction to it.&#34; Mental toughness is easy when things are going well, but the true test comes if you can train yourself to use mental strategies like visualization in moments of crisis, panic, and disaster.</p><p><strong>Find the good in the awful: </strong>It&#39;s hard to imagine you&#39;d be able to forgive those who abused the system and sentenced you to death, but Hinton sees it differently. &#34;I&#39;ve never had an apology, but I forgave those involved in my conviction long before I left prison. I didn&#39;t forgive them so they can sleep well at night. I did it so I can.&#34;</p><p>Research shows that people who are good at framing negative life events in positive ways have better mental health. &#34;I&#39;m sure there are a million things Anthony could tell you about his misery and the things that were awful and unjust,&#34; Johnson says. &#34;But when you look back and you choose to find the good in the bad, your experience of it changes. It&#39;s not for anyone else - it&#39;s for you.&#34;</p><h2>5. Emily Harrington, the climber who befriended her fear</h2><p>Emily Harrington became the first woman to free climb El Capitan&#39;s notoriously difficult Golden Gate route in under 24 hours. She attempted it in 2019, <a href=\"https://cnn.com/2019/11/26/sport/emily-harrington-climbing-fall-el-capitan-spt-intl/index.html\">but it ended in disaster</a> after Harrington fell 50 feet, hit her head on a ledge, and suffered a concussion. &#34;It&#39;s definitely a mental struggle, coming over that hurdle, coming back into this year and trying again,&#34; she said.</p><p>Here&#39;s how she learned to accept fear:</p><p><strong>Learn how to accept fear:</strong> Rather than push away the things she&#39;s fearful of, she&#39;s learned to befriend them. &#34;I work through it by just accepting it and trying to understand why it&#39;s there and then taking steps to move forward,&#34; she said. &#34;In a lot of ways, we can use fear as fuel and as strength.&#34; But how can people learn not to fear the things they&#39;re afraid of?</p><p>Johnson says it&#39;s possible to think and feel one way, but act in a totally different way. &#34;Your feelings and actions don&#39;t have to match to co-exist,&#34; she said. &#34;So yes, you can feel fear and do it anyway. [Emily] is not ignoring the fact that she feels fearful, but it&#39;s accepting it and choosing to act anyway.&#34;</p><p><strong>Use mantras in times of panic:</strong> Harrington uses mantras when she&#39;s in difficult situations in order to soothe the panic in her brain. She says this to herself over and over again: &#34;Be vulnerable, accept failure, and embrace fear.&#34;</p><p>Passion is the result of identifying what makes you uncomfortable and scares you most. &#34;Feelings aren&#39;t facts. They&#39;re data points,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;Fear is often a good indication that this is something you care about.&#34;</p><h2><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-sara-blakely\">6. Sarah Blakely, the founder who used failure as a weapon</a></h2><p>Sara Blakely is no stranger to failure.</p><p>Growing up, she wanted to be a trial attorney, but then she bombed the LSAT. After college, she auditioned to be Goofy at Disney World, but she was too short to wear the costume. After a stint as an Epcot ride greeter at &#34;the happiest place on earth,&#34; Blakely returned home and moved in with her mom.</p><p>One night, she decided to wear her new white pants to a party, but her underwear left unflattering panty lines. So she cut the feet off a pair of pantyhose and turned them into a slimming undergarment. &#34;The moment I saw how good my butt looked, I was like, &#39;Thank you, God, this is my opportunity,&#34; she said.</p><p>That moment changed the trajectory of her entire life. In 2000, Blakely used her $5,000 in savings to start her company Spanx, and by 2012, she was named the youngest self-made female billionaire.</p><p>The key to her success has been that Blakely sees an opportunity in every failure or disappointment. &#34;Spanx wouldn&#39;t exist if I had aced the LSAT,&#34; she said.</p><p><strong>Learn to celebrate failure:</strong> When Blakely was growing up, her family would go around the dinner table and share their biggest failure of the week. &#34;If I didn&#39;t have something to share, [my father] would actually be disappointed,&#34; she said. The exercise re-defined failure in Blakely&#39;s mind. &#34;Instead of failure becoming an outcome, it simply became about not trying,&#34; she said. &#34;And that truly is the only failure - to not try.&#34;</p><p>In reflecting on Blakely&#39;s story, Johnson explains that we could never know how much we could achieve unless we go so far that we reach the point of failure. She adds:&#34;How will you know how far you can go if you don&#39;t risk losing it to some degree?&#34; If you frame failure as a data point, you can get a lot of great feedback on how you can improve in the future.</p><p><strong>Diffuse difficult situations with humor:</strong> Life can be heavy, Blakely said, and having someone who can lighten the mood or make you laugh is one of the most important things. For example, when she and her husband get in a heated argument, he extends his hand, and they slow dance.</p><p>Johnson explains: &#34;Sometimes we can take ourselves too seriously. When we joke and laugh, it brings us back down to reality.&#34;</p><h2><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/kobe-bryant\">7. Kobe Bryant, the player who turned greatness into an obsession</a></h2><p>One year ago, Kobe Bryant&#39;s life came to an end in a sudden and tragic manner. The 18-time NBA All-Star who had a 20-year career with the Los Angeles Lakers, died in a helicopter crash on January 26, 2020. His 13-year-old daughter Gianna and seven others also died in the crash.</p><p>But Bryant&#39;s legacy continues to live on. On and off the court, he was best known for his obsessive pursuit of precision and excellence, which he dubbed &#34;the Mamba Mentality.&#34; Bryant&#39;s life and career remind us that the only answer to surviving unimaginable hardship is to keep moving forward and drawing on our own resilience.</p><p><strong>Use an alter ego to summon confidence:</strong> Bryant created his &#34;Black Mamba&#34; alter ego as a way to get through the lowest point of his career. His nickname was inspired by the movie &#34;Kill Bill,&#34; in which the snake, known for its agility and aggressiveness, was used as a code name for a deadly assassin. At a time when people were chanting &#34;Kobe sucks,&#34; while he was playing, Bryant said that using an alter ego gave him emotional distance from his real self.</p><p>&#34;Kobe and the Black Mamba - both of them were him,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;But there was a time in competition when he could turn it on and use [the identity] that was appropriate for the situation.&#34;</p><p><strong>Remember that life only moves forward:</strong> To Bryant, the antidote to listlessness and defeat was drive and relentlessness. He never believed in &#34;go with the flow.&#34; Rather, he believed in moving forward with intent. Instead of shying away from adversity, bring this Bryant quote to the forefront of your mind: &#34;I&#39;m reflective only in the sense that I learn to move forward…I reflect with a purpose.&#34;</p><p>That&#39;s because he knew that action is the only thing that leads to confidence and improvement. &#34;Kobe would gain an understanding around the unknown,&#34; Johnson said. &#34;When we can prepare for something and gain competence, we actually gain confidence.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Polina Marinova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ad08134af8d0018599e68?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn61@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-433_77eb3c7b11920f2e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsh-2F7zlHw:TiFaC-_NYJs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn7@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-23-179_1b6a64b306c5d4eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsh-2F7zlHw:TiFaC-_NYJs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn57@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-22-056_6712efc3ce50935b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsh-2F7zlHw:TiFaC-_NYJs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn38@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-26-669_ac3f36810b8f9352.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/wsh-2F7zlHw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn33@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-27-714_a2e95e068bce15b0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238433},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"This tiny $4,400 EV with 23 horsepower that can seat 4 is outselling the Tesla Model 3 in China","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-model-3-outsold-china-hong-guang-mini-ev-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c9034af8d001859a607?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1420\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV is about as long as a Smart ForTwo.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Wuling <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-model-3-saic-motor-hong-guang-electric-vehicle-china-2021-2\">Hong Guang Mini EV</a> is outselling Tesla&#39;s most popular car in China. </li>\n<li>The tiny electric car starts at around $4,400 at current exchange rates. </li>\n<li>It can go just over 100 miles on a charge and hits a top speed of 62 mph. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tA tiny bargain-bin electric car is outselling the Tesla Model 3 in one of the US carmaker's most crucial markets.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6ca534af8d001859a609?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn March, the Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV was China's most popular EV, selling 39,745 units, according to the China Passenger Car Association.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/603777ddd920880018591eb4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SAIC GM\" height=\"3348\" width=\"4812\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Costfoto/Barcroft Media via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThat's compared to just over 25,000 of Tesla's best-selling Model 3 sedans sold over the same period.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6e37f22c6b00185db158?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1878\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Mini EV was launched in July through a joint venture between GM and two Chinese companies: Wuling and SAIC.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6ca534af8d001859a60a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe model starts at the equivalent of around $4,400, but a fully-loaded version will run you closer to $6,000.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6e7034af8d001859a616?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1878\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe tiny hatchback is just under 115 inches long and roughly 59 inches wide.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6037779ed920880018591eb3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SAIC GM\" height=\"3168\" width=\"4776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Costfoto/Barcroft Media via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tFor reference, a Fiat 500 is around 140 inches long. The Mini EV is closer to the size of a Smart ForTwo.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c8df22c6b00185db144?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt has around 26 cubic feet of cargo space, roughly the same as a Fiat 500. Wuling says it can fit a stroller or two small suitcases.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6ca7f22c6b00185db148?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThat's with the rear seats folded down. Yes - believe it or not, the Mini EV does have room for four passengers.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c8ff22c6b00185db145?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Hong Guang Mini EV can only go around 105 miles on a charge, but it's meant more for urban driving than long road trips.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6caaf22c6b00185db149?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt makes a claimed 27 horsepower and has a top speed of 62 mph.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c99f22c6b00185db146?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1407\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Hong Guang Mini EV, of course, isn't in the same league as Tesla's premium electric sedans and SUVs.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c9a34af8d001859a608?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Model 3 delivers almost 300 miles of range in its base configuration.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6c9ff22c6b00185db147?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Tesla also costs almost 10 times more than the Hong Guang Mini EV, retailing for right around $39,000 in China at current exchange rates.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c709f34af8d001859a62d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1878\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tTesla hasn't indicated it has any plans to go after China's budget-EV market, but it is developing a $25,000 EV at its Shanghai plant.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c6cb5f22c6b00185db14c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\" height=\"1406\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wuling Hong Guang Mini EV.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Wuling Motors</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"GOP Sen. Roger Marshall, who voted to overturn the 2020 presidential election, says he's 'so ready to move on'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/republican-roger-marshall-overturn-presidential-election-move-on-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608f0f4834af8d001859a7af?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Roger Marshall\" height=\"2000\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sen. Roger Marshall of Kansas.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Leigh Vogel/Pool via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>GOP Sen. Roger Marshall said that he wanted to &#34;move on&#34; from discussing his challenge of the election results.</li>\n<li>&#34;I made a decision based upon the facts that I knew at that point in time,&#34; he said.</li>\n<li>Former President Trump and his campaign spent months trying to overturn President Biden&#39;s victory.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>GOP Sen. Roger Marshall of Kansas on Saturday said that he was &#34;ready to move on&#34; when asked about <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/01/07/us/elections/electoral-college-biden-objectors.html\">his support</a> of former President Donald Trump&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-lawsuits-election-results-2020-11\">efforts to overturn</a> the 2020 presidential election results.</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/Acyn/status/1388628699688292353\">During an interview</a> with CNN&#39;s Pamela Brown, Marshall was questioned about whether his actions played a role in continued Republican distrust of the 2020 election.</p><p>Brown referred to <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/30/politics/cnn-poll-voting-rights/index.html\">a recent CNN poll</a> conducted in late April which showed that 70 percent of Republicans believe that President Joe Biden didn&#39;t legitimately win last year&#39;s presidential race. The same poll revealed that only 23 percent of Republicans think Biden won the election fairly.</p><p>&#34;Republicans continue to believe in the lie that this election, the last election was stolen,&#34; Brown said. &#34;You voted to toss out millions of votes in Arizona and Pennsylvania. You also joined the Texas lawsuit attempting to throw out votes cast in four states.&#34;</p><p>She added: &#34;I&#39;m curious. Looking back, do you have any regrets about your actions and any concern that they contributed to misinformation about the election?&#34;</p><p>&#34;We&#39;re just so ready to move on,&#34; Marshall replied. &#34;I made a decision based upon the facts that I knew at that point in time. I was concerned then, and I still am today that six states broke their own laws or their own constitution. But it&#39;s time to move on. It&#39;s time for this country to heal. It&#39;s time for a spirit of forgiveness to be happening.&#34;</p><p><strong><em>Read more:</em></strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/merrick-garland-top-aides-advisors-inner-circle-justice-department-doj-2021-3\"><em>Meet Merrick Garland&#39;s inner circle of 18 officials. They&#39;ve got a packed plate investigating major police departments and even Rudy Giuliani.</em></a></p><p>Days before the January 6 certification of Biden&#39;s 306-232 Electoral College <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-vs-2016-electoral-college-maps-trump-biden-clinton-president-2020-11\">victory</a>, Marshall <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cruz-leading-effort-to-object-electoral-college-certification-2021-1\">joined</a> a group of GOP senators led by Sens. Josh Hawley of Missouri and Ted Cruz of Texas who sought to challenge the results.</p><p>&#34;I cannot vote to certify the electoral college results on January 6 without raising the fact that some states, particularly Pennsylvania, failed to follow their own state election laws,&#34; Hawley said at the time.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-fox-interview-bartiromo-debunked-fraud-allegations-election-2020-11\">The repeated maligning</a> of the vote count by Trump and his campaign fueled the deadly insurrection at the US Capitol on January 6, which disrupted lawmakers as they sought to certify the results.</p><p>Later in the interview, Brown continued to press Marshall about how his challenge of the election results adhered to his ideological support of states&#39; rights.</p><p>&#34;We want voting to easier, cheating to be harder,&#34; he said. &#34;By us standing up to our concerns about those elections, about the election integrity ... it has forced those states with their problems to come to back to the table and have those legislatures work together to make sure we have safer elections with higher integrity.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;In my heart, I did what I thought was the right thing. I think the country is moving in a better direction.&#34; </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/republican-roger-marshall-overturn-presidential-election-move-on-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/b6hLL9FGmZs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 20:50:01 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608f0d3634af8d001859a7ae?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c1de24fa71d75639b54febcde2acfb0e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn66@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-21-585_d37452d959bb9f67.webp","destWidth":3501,"destHeight":2626,"sourceBytes":231118,"destBytes":231118,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608f0f4834af8d001859a7af?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn95@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-23-161_abd67a03ded5f9ad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn89@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-27-967_9284acfec86babce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn79@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-848_6077f1f406dac792.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=b6hLL9FGmZs:sZx2JR62o0Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/b6hLL9FGmZs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn23@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-27-077_094efdfe320bab62.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238435},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Leon Cooperman made a bearish stock forecast, said rich people should pay more taxes, and addressed his Elizabeth Warren feud in a recent interview. Here are the 10 best quotes.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/leon-cooperman-best-quotes-stock-market-forecast-outlook-fed-warren-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c50af34af8d001859a568?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 472141044\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Leon Cooperman decried the public and politicians &#34;attacking the wealthy&#34;.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CNBC/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Leon Cooperman said the stock market will be lower a year from now and the Fed will be &#34;surprised&#34; at inflation.</li>\n<li>He also said wealthy individuals should pay more in taxes but he disagrees with Sen. Warren&#39;s wealth tax plan. </li>\n<li>The billionaire detailed his &#34;modest&#34; taste and said he recently traded in a 2002 Lexus for a Hyundai.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\"></a><strong><a href=\"https://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/10-things-opening-bell?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestmp;utm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sign up here for our daily newsletter, 10 Things Before the Opening Bell</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>In a 22-minute <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/video/2021/04/30/full-interview-with-billionaire-lee-cooperman-on-taxing-the-rich-investing-and-more.html\">interview with CNBC</a> on Friday, Leon Cooperman said the stock market will be lower a year from today, defended capitalism, and discussed <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/billionaire-leon-cooperman-wealth-tax-elizabeth-warren-education-department-cnbc-2021-4\">his ongoing back-and-forth with Sen. Elizabeth Warren over the wealth tax</a>. The investor, whose estimated net worth is $2.5 billion according to Forbes, also discussed his &#34;modest&#34; lifestyle choices.<br><br><strong>Here are his 10 best quotes:</strong></p><p>(1) On his bearish long-term market outlook:</p><p>&#34;Let&#39;s face it. The market is facing the fact that taxes are going up, interest rates are going up, and inflation is going up. And we have a reasonably richly appraised market. So cyclically I&#39;m engaged. But I got an eye on the exit,&#34; said Cooperman, who also told CNBC <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/leon-cooperman-stock-market-outlook-tax-rising-inflation-risk-fed-2021-4-1030371636\">the stock market will be lower a year from today.</a></p><p>(2) On inflation that could surprise the Federal Reserve:</p><p>&#34;I think that Mr. Powell will be surprised by inflation. It&#39;s not going to be as quiescent and transitory as he thinks. I think the Fed will be forced to say something before the end of 2022.&#34;</p><p>(3) On the &#34;self-correcting&#34; nature of the current market:</p><p>&#34;The market has been very self corrective, in the sense that the FAANG stocks are not expensive, but the aspiring FAANG stocks are very expensive, and they&#39;ve been corrected in a serious way. The whole slowdown in the SPAC area is self-correcting.&#34;</p><p>(4) On the fixed income market being &#34;overvalued.&#34; </p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t understand why someone would want to buy a bond if you&#39;re going to give away 40% to 50% of the coupon to the government and then you have inflation, you&#39;re getting your capital confiscated. I&#39;d rather take my chance on a common stock.&#34;</p><p>(5) On the rapid pace of economic growth:</p><p>&#34;If you spoke to a hundred economists today and  asked them what their view is of the potential real growth of the US economy, the response would be centered around 2%,&#34; Cooperman said. &#34;We&#39;re growing this year four to five times potential, yet the Fed is persistent in keeping interest rates at near zero. That doesn&#39;t make any great sense to me. It&#39;s just pushing people out on the risk curve.&#34;</p><p>(6) On his on-going back and forth with Sen. Elizabeth Warren:</p><p>Cooperman said he thinks that Warren&#39;s wealth tax is &#34;probably&#34; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/is-elizabeth-warrens-wealth-tax-constitutional-law-professors-billionaires-inequality-2021-3\">unconstitutional</a>.  &#34;I don&#39;t know her. I don&#39;t vote in Massachusetts, but I think she&#39;s very wrong-minded,&#34; he said.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-economic-growth-rising-yields-credit-suisse-2021-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Buy these 14 high-quality stocks poised to beat the market as the economy enters a new phase of rapid growth, Credit Suisse says</a></em></p><p>(7) On the wealth tax: </p><p>&#34;I do believe in the progressive income tax structure, I do believe rich people should pay more. The wealth tax makes no sense to me, for lots of reasons. In all the countries it&#39;s been introduced, I think 14 out of 17, it&#39;s been eliminated. And there are so many better ways of going about what [Warren is] looking to accomplish.&#34;</p><p>(8) On the success of wealthy individuals:</p><p>&#34;How do you get to be very wealthy? You develop a product or service the world wants. Is the world better off or worse off because of Jeff Bezos, Bill Gates, Bernie Marcus, Ken Langone? I think the world is better off.&#34;</p><p>(9) In defense of capitalism, and mega-cap companies like Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and Facebook:</p><p>&#34;I&#39;m a capitalist with a heart. I don&#39;t have much use of money. I respect money. I lived very modestly, but I believe that what has made America great is our commitment to capitalism. And the fact that we are turning our back in many respects on capitalism is wrong...God knows what we would be going through if we didn&#39;t have those companies in the last few years to help us with this pandemic.&#34; Cooperman said.</p><p>(10) His view that material possessions bring &#34;aggravation.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I just bought a new car the other day and the car I traded in was a 2002 Lexus- I kept the car for 20 years! And I bought a Hyundai. I&#39;m not a collector of things.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/leon-cooperman-best-quotes-stock-market-forecast-outlook-fed-warren-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1KO6IvViGXI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 14:57:22 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608c50b935c46f0018c0baf4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"38e016579fdf310a0fdedd31b3b68442","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn81@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-21-692_20ddadfd3e2f3ae0.webp","destWidth":2668,"destHeight":1999,"sourceBytes":130578,"destBytes":130578,"author":"egraffeo@businessinsider.com (Emily Graffeo)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608c50af34af8d001859a568?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn50@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-22-274_bfda595282546783.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-24-517_35fbef54d47cc380.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn54@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-25-290_67ef553f8f49e5ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1KO6IvViGXI:HfrNKMbt5Jo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn91@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-892_5ceab981fccb6f26.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1KO6IvViGXI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn51@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-414_f6d5ff40398691a6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238435},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Why declaring racism a public health crisis is an important step to closing racial gaps in healthcare","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/declaring-racism-epidemic-help-close-racial-gaps-health-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c3e1234af8d001859a4e1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Racism is a virus AAPI stop the hate protest\" height=\"682\" width=\"910\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Racism is as much a public health issue as it is a social justice issue.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jason Redmond/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>On April 8, CDC Director Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky declared racism a public health threat.</li>\n<li>This declaration will create a sharper focus on healthcare inequality, says Dr. Paul Halverson.</li>\n<li>Treating racism as a disease will also boost public health funding and lead to healthier communities. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has joined hundreds of <a href=\"https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/health-equity/racism-and-health/racism-declarations\">cities and counties across the country</a> in declaring racism a public health threat. On April 8, 2021, CDC Director Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky called racism an epidemic that affects &#34;<a href=\"https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2021-04-09/racism-a-serious-public-health-threat-cdc-says\">the entire health of our nation</a>.&#34;</p><p>Declaring racism a public health threat will create a sharper strategic and operational focus on understanding and combating racism. Walensky said the CDC will <a href=\"https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2021-04-09/racism-a-serious-public-health-threat-cdc-says\">invest more in communities of color</a> and will work to create more diversity within the CDC.</p><p>The agency will create a portal on the CDC site called &#34;Racism and Health&#34; to help provide resources and to educate people.</p><p><a href=\"https://fsph.iupui.edu/about/directory/halverson-paul.html\">As a professor</a> and founding dean of the Fairbanks School of Public Health at Indiana University, I agree drawing attention to the racial gaps in healthcare is an important step in addressing them.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/harvard-law-school-students-racism-anti-black-policy-2020-7\">As Black Harvard Law School students, we&#39;ve encountered racism at Harvard and elsewhere. But anti-Blackness goes far beyond our privileged Ivy League experiences - it&#39;s deeply rooted in American law and policy.</a></em></p><h2>Bringing up the rear</h2><p>Acknowledging racism as a public health threat allows for the creation of workforce training programs in public health, medicine, nursing, and other fields. It also may require all health-related professional training programs to include structural racism identification and implied bias and anti-racism strategies within the curriculum. This will put a sharper focus on the measurement of the factors that influence racism. <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0408-racism-health.html\">Designating racism as a public health emergency</a> can create institutional focus on actions taken to address this long-overlooked issue.</p><p><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1377/hlthaff.2018.05144\">The US pays more per capita for healthcare</a> than any other industrialized nation in the world, but look at the <a href=\"https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/health-rankings\">health statistics</a> and you&#39;ll see the US brings up the rear. Canada, Japan, Malta, New Zealand, Singapore, and Switzerland do better. Among the industrialized countries, the US&#39;s health system is currently <a href=\"https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/nejmp0910064\">ranked 37th in the world</a>.</p><p>The reality is that health is a result of many factors. The most striking one has nothing to do with intelligence, diet, or job status. Instead, it&#39;s a person&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/blogs-stories/life-expectancy.html\">ZIP code</a>. Where someone lives is the greatest predictor of <a href=\"https://www.rwjf.org/en/library/interactives/whereyouliveaffectshowlongyoulive.html\">health and life expectancy</a>. A person&#39;s ZIP code is also a good predictor of their race and ethnicity. Those things too have a <a href=\"https://theconversation.com/the-key-to-your-health-could-be-in-your-zip-code-46304\">major impact on how long someone lives</a> and, maybe even more importantly, <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6617e1.htm\">how well</a>.</p><p>I live in Indiana. Here, a baby born today in a southern urban neighborhood will <a href=\"https://www.savi.org/report/worlds-apart/\">live 14 years less</a> than another baby born in the northern suburbs, less than 20 miles away. How a nation protects the health of its children tells you an enormous amount about that society. In the US, our infant mortality - babies who die before their first birthday - is among the <a href=\"https://www.americashealthrankings.org/learn/reports/2019-annual-report/international-comparison\">highest in the world</a>, with the highest rates in the <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr69/NVSR-69-7-508.pdf\">Midwestern and Southern states</a>. And across the board, infant mortality affects Black communities at a rate higher than other races.</p><h2>Higher risks across the board</h2><p>If you are an African American mother in Indiana, your baby is <a href=\"https://www.in.gov/isdh/27470.htm\">three times more likely to die</a> before its first birthday. Being born Black also means you&#39;re twice as likely to suffer from <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4108512/\">high blood pressure and have a stroke</a>. Black Americans are also more than <a href=\"https://www.sentencingproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/The-Color-of-Justice-Racial-and-Ethnic-Disparity-in-State-Prisons.pdf?eType=EmailBlastContent&eId=ced15dff-ec72-413f-9c9d-eb191b5931e731e7\">five times as likely to serve prison time</a> and will <a href=\"https://www.epi.org/blog/black-white-wage-gaps-are-worse-today-than-in-2000/\">earn substantially less money than their white neighbors</a>. And people of color are up to <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6929e1.htm\">10 times more likely</a> to test positive for COVID-19.</p><p>Where you live, how much you earn, your access to transportation, and your ability to shop at a supermarket in your neighborhood are all part of the <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/socialdeterminants/index.htm\">social determinants of health</a>, the most powerful predictor of how long and how well people live.</p><p>In the past century, US life expectancy went up 30 years. New medicines or gadgets had little to do with it. Most of those extra years came because of the protection afforded by the <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6019a5.htm\">public health system</a>. That includes clean water, a food supply that&#39;s safe, and an improved environment.</p><p>Decades of discriminatory housing practices have burdened Black communities with poverty, substandard housing, and environmental hazards. Unfortunately, most federally assisted housing is located in segregated areas at a greater risk of <a href=\"https://scholar.harvard.edu/files/alixwinter/files/sampson_winter_2016.pdf\">lead poisoning</a>, exposure to <a href=\"https://www.lung.org/clean-air/outdoors/who-is-at-risk/disparities\">air pollution</a>, or lack of access to <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ypmed.2013.10.010\">healthy food</a>.</p><p>Nearly 18% of the US economy <a href=\"https://www.cms.gov/Research-Statistics-Data-and-Systems/Statistics-Trends-and-Reports/NationalHealthExpendData/NationalHealthAccountsHistorical\">goes toward healthcare spending</a>. That is many times the investment <a href=\"https://data.oecd.org/healthres/health-spending.htm\">of many other countries</a> that enjoy substantially better health - such countries as France, Italy, Singapore, Colombia, Saudi Arabia, and Denmark.</p><p>Of the $3.8 trillion spent on healthcare, public health and prevention is allocated less than 3% of this gigantic budget. However, a 2018 report showed a <a href=\"https://academyhealth.org/sites/default/files/roi_public_health_spending_june2018.pdf\">3-1 return on investment</a> on public health funding.</p><p>Treating racism like the disease that the CDC says it is suggests boosting our investment in public health funding would be money well spent.<!-- Below is The Conversation's page counter tag. Please DO NOT REMOVE. --><!-- End of code. If you don't see any code above, please get new code from the Advanced tab after you click the republish button. The page counter does not collect any personal data. More info: https://theconversation.com/republishing-guidelines --></p><p><em><a href=\"https://theconversation.com/profiles/paul-k-halverson-1139274\">Paul K. Halverson</a>, dean, Fairbanks School of Public Health, <a href=\"https://theconversation.com/institutions/iupui-2368\">IUPUI</a></em></p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><figure>\n\t<img 2021 13:25:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608c3e1234af8d001859a4e1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"41c59539871d896f8999f5b81f76eb18","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-18-631_5fef32f813992a09.webp","destWidth":910,"destHeight":682,"sourceBytes":36048,"destBytes":36048,"author":"insider@insider.com (Paul K. Halverson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608c3e1234af8d001859a4e1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-18-631_5fef32f813992a09.webp","https://counter.theconversation.com/content/143330/count.gif?distributor=republish-lightbox-advanced?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn59@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-24-412_3bf3f490f9b66838.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zTekGLWtYRs:0G8aZVbs6K8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn33@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-636_4da21a146279a7bd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zTekGLWtYRs:0G8aZVbs6K8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn76@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-511_0815c32bb2c2ddeb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zTekGLWtYRs:0G8aZVbs6K8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn77@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-28-004_f9b33f650256001f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/zTekGLWtYRs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-25-433_5a858e4d554de0ad.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238432},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Meet the KHive: Kamala Harris' army of online fans who are fiercely loyal but can also turn nasty, critics say","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-the-khive-kamala-harris-fiercely-loyal-group-online-fans-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608d698ef22c6b00185db1ff?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kamala\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A supporter holds up a sign as  Kamala Harris speaks before the start of the Liberty and Justice Celebration on November 01, 2019 in Des Moines, Iowa.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Scott Olson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The so-called &#34;KHive&#34; is Vice President Kamala Harris&#39; fiercely loyal online fan group.</li>\n<li>Although it is loosely organized, the group is united in celebrating as well as defending Harris.</li>\n<li>But the KHive has also been accused of bullying and harassment.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>When New York Post reporter Laura Italiano <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-post-reporter-resigned-says-ordered-false-story-migrant-2021-4\">tweeted this week she was resigning</a> because of an inaccurate article she was allegedly asked to write about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kamala-harris-to-move-into-official-residence-of-vice-president-2021-4\">Vice President Kamala Harris</a>, angry Harris supporters swarmed her.</p><p>&#34;I think I missed your apology to the Vice President,&#34; one person commented on her tweet. </p><p>&#34;You shouldn&#39;t wrote the damn story on the first place. Where you trying to get clicks and likes?&#34; another <a href=\"https://twitter.com/iamchanteezy/status/1387218876119846912\">wrote</a>. </p><p>Italiano was experiencing the sting of the so-called &#34;KHive&#34; - Harris&#39; fiercely loyal online fan group that has been celebrating as well as defending the vice president ever since she became <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/who-is-kamala-harris-bio-age-family-key-positions-2019-3\">California&#39;s senator in 2017.</a></p><p>&#34;She broke so many barriers as a Black, South Asian woman,&#34; KHive member Lecia Michelle from New Orleans told Insider. &#34;So we must be here to defend her for who she is as a biracial woman.&#34; </p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-staffers-making-their-mark-in-the-biden-administration-2021-3\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">15 Gen Zers in the Biden administration share what inspires them and how to get a leg up in Washington</a></em></p><p>Even though the &#34;KHive&#34; is loosely organized - it has no leader, and it is unclear exactly how many members there are - the online group makes sure its presence is felt.</p><p>Members are especially active on Twitter, marking their devotion to the vice president by using the #KHive hashtag or adding yellow hearts and bee emojis to their profile descriptions. </p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-jen psaki’s hair tuck before she slays 😷🧼💛🐝  (@emiranda_writes) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1387877391956160523?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 29, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>They share videos of the vice president&#39;s speeches, comment on the different outfits she&#39;s wearing, and post selfies in yellow and purple merchandise with her name on it.</p><p>They also organize virtual &#34;cooking Sunday&#34; parties and meet up on Zoom to watch major political events - most recently, they gathered online to watch <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-address-congress-republicans-shake-their-heads-live-tweet-2021-4\">President Joe Biden&#39;s first joint address to Congress</a> together.</p><p>The group is united in its celebration of the vice president and amplifies the policies she promotes: KHive members speak out in favor of racial, gender equality, and LGBTQ inclusion. They support the right to an abortion and have applauded Harris on her carbon-neutral climate plan.</p><p>The KHive&#39;s support was obvious in the run-up to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-election-results\">the 2020 election</a> when many members felt they had to act as defenders for Harris.</p><p>As <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kamala-harris-makes-history-first-woman-black-vice-president-elect-2020-11\">the first Black and first South Asian woman to be nominated for vice president</a> by either major party, Harris was a primary target in Washington and often faced an onslaught of racist and misogynistic harassment. </p><p>Members of the KHive tell Insider they have to be outspoken because of the historical significance of Harris&#39;s position.</p><p>Eric Chavous, the 31-year-old attorney behind one of the most popular KHive accounts @flywithkamala, told Insider: &#34;She sits at the intersection of race and gender, which is the root cause of her unparalleled criticism. People are not used to seeing Black people with a seat at the table, but definitely not Black women.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608d5cda34af8d001859a6be?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kamala harris\" height=\"2007\" width=\"4015\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Vice President Kamala Harris attends a virtual roundtable event with participants from local Black Chambers of Commerce on February 5, 2021 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>&#34;The KHive has to work around the clock to overcome stereotypes surrounding Black women so that people can see the truth - that Kamala Harris has the experience and knowledge to lead the United States of America,&#34; Chavous added.</p><p>The 31-year-old attorney became a supporter of the vice president in 2009 when he attended Howard University, Harris&#39;s alma mater.</p><p>He was also one of the first people who helped coin the term &#34;KHive&#34; back in 2017, which is loosely modeled on <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/interesting-things-you-didnt-know-about-beyonce-fun-facts\">Beyoncé&#39;s equally fervent &#34;Beyhive&#34;</a> (multiple KHive members also credited Twitter users Biana Delarosa and Elizabeth Blumberg for helping form the group).</p><p>Since Chavous first tweeted the hashtag, it has taken on a life of its own. Harris herself has addressed the group on multiple occasions and her husband and Second Gentleman Douglas Emhoff even identifies as a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/douglasemhoff\">member of the #KHive in his Twitter biography</a>.</p><p>But some members of Harris&#39;s digital army have also been accused of taking their loyalty too far.</p><p>Last year, a <a href=\"https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/kamala-harris-khive-toxic-side_n_5f4fa573c5b69eb5c037473e?ri18n=true\">Huffington Post investigation</a> found nearly a dozen people who said they had been threatened or harassed by some self-identified members of the KHive.</p><p>Multiple people told the Post their personal information had been published online after some fans instigated harassment campaigns against them for previously backing Democratic candidates other than Harris.</p><p>One person claimed they were forced to temporarily move their family to a different location for fear they were in physical danger, while two women claimed that KHive members even made veiled threats toward their children. </p><p>&#34;People are ugly and disrespectful all over the internet. The KHive, in particular, simply wants to set the record straight,&#34; Chavous said when asked by Insider about the allegations.</p><p>Chantay Berry, a 34-year-old graduate student at Brooklyn College and KHive member who has previously engaged in online arguments, admitted to Insider that the online world of politics can get toxic.</p><p>&#34;Some of us do play a part in going back and forth with people. I don&#39;t start stuff, but like, you&#39;re not just going to bully me online either. It&#39;s just what the internet is,&#34; Berry said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e409634af8d001859a718?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kama harris supporters\" height=\"3648\" width=\"4864\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Supporters of Kamala Harris look on as she speaks during a &#34;For the People&#34; rally in Davenport, Iowa, on August 12, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the past, KHive members have specifically targeted people who criticize Harris&#39;s record during her time as a prosecutor or have attacked her shift away from Sen. Bernie Sanders&#39; &#34;Medicare for all&#34; bill.</p><p>Briahna Joy Gray, the press secretary for Sanders during the 2020 presidential primary, has accused the group of harassing her on multiple occasions.</p><p>&#34;They&#39;re vicious,&#34; she told the <a href=\"https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2021-04-08/politicians-dread-sting-khive-fervent-online-fans-of-kamala-harris\">Los Angeles Times</a> last month. She did not respond to Insider&#39;s request for comment.</p><p>But the group also aggressively targets right-wing outlets, like the New York Post, who have spent the last few 100 days frequently criticizing Harris on multiple issues, including <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pictures-trumps-half-built-border-wall-and-ruined-landscape-2021-2\">immigration</a>.</p><p>&#34;I want to know from the right where the hell was that energy when Donald Trump basically wrecked everything in our country and wrecked everything?&#34; Berry told Insider.</p><p>&#34;We all know they&#39;re only attacking her because they know she&#39;s gonna be the president one day,&#34; she added.</p><p>Berry told Insider that the KHive has no plans to go anywhere, especially considering Harris&#39; increasing chances of becoming president in 2024.</p><p>&#34;I think that now that she&#39;s in office, we&#39;re still all stans, but now we&#39;re all stans watching for the next four years, hoping that she becomes president,&#34; she said. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608d696d34af8d001859a6c4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"607d30ee5db54776c50bd4a341247599","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn73@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-21-663_af5c537162fe6388.webp","destWidth":2666,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":79122,"destBytes":79122,"author":"sankel@businessinsider.com (Sophia Ankel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608d698ef22c6b00185db1ff?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn5@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-28-018_539e6a0e2510fb24.webp","https://i.insider.com/608d5cda34af8d001859a6be?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn80@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-23-151_6bc4891442910329.webp","https://i.insider.com/608e409634af8d001859a718?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn29@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-22-235_01893739ad02095b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xYB-k4IhKk8:tCwhBqZu7Ds:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-253_999195fb944c635a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xYB-k4IhKk8:tCwhBqZu7Ds:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-581_0da286ad4261bd06.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xYB-k4IhKk8:tCwhBqZu7Ds:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-323_332a47c3dcb6717f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/xYB-k4IhKk8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn92@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-24-959_d8321d4d3c963a5e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says Americans can expect a 'big return' from Biden's $4.1 trillion spending proposal","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-infrastructure-care-plans-janet-yellen-promise-big-return-economy-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ef90af22c6b00185db2d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AP21049840179506\" height=\"1990\" width=\"3980\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Treasury secretary Janet Yellen pushed for stimulus checks\n<p class=\"copyright\">Andrew Harnik/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Biden&#39;s spending plans can offer a &#34;big return,&#34; Tres. Sec. Janet Yellen said Sunday.</li>\n<li>The measures should be paid for while interest rates sit at historic lows, she added.</li>\n<li>If inflation rises more than expected, the government &#34;has the tools to address it,&#34; Yellen said.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen reiterated her support for President Joe Biden&#39;s spending plans on Sunday, pitching the measures as strong investments in the country&#39;s future.</p><p>The president on Wednesday rolled out a $1.8 trillion spending proposal that includes funding for paid family and medical leave, universal pre-K, and childcare. The measure follows the March passage of Biden&#39;s $1.9 trillion stimulus package and joins the president&#39;s $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan as his latest step in big-government economic policy.</p><p>Republicans and some moderate Democrats have balked at the follow-up plans cost, saying the measures would dangerously inflate the government&#39;s debt pile. Yellen countered on NBC&#39;s &#34;<a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/meet-the-press/video/full-janet-yellen-interview-over-the-long-run-deficits-need-to-be-contained-111205957834\">Meet The Press</a>,&#34; saying it&#39;s a better time than ever to spend on such projects.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;re in a good fiscal position. Interest rates are historically low... and it&#39;s likely they&#39;ll stay that way into the future,&#34; the Treasury Secretary said. &#34;I believe that we should pay for these historic investments. There will be a big return.&#34;</p><p>That&#39;s not to say the government shouldn&#39;t <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sanders-progressive-taxation-biden-spending-proposals-infrastructure-2021-5\">offset the multitrillion-dollar price tag</a>. The Biden administration rolled out a handful of tax hikes and stronger enforcement to cover the spending, but those proposals were swiftly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-speech-gop-response-delivered-by-sen-tim-scott-2021-4\">rejected by Republicans.</a> The GOP has <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/senate-republican-infrastructure-plan-breakdown-biden-2021-4-1030334674\">criticized Biden&#39;s public-works plan and a proposed corporate tax increase,</a> calling it a &#34;slush-fund&#34; and a &#34;Trojan horse&#34; for Democratic priorities.</p><p>The economy is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/employment-outlook-stimulus-virus-fears-labor-market-recovery-participation-bofa-2021-5\">poised to rebound from the coronavirus pandemic throughout 2021</a> and, in turn, bring in greater tax revenues. That stronger growth justifies some spending, but the safest and most sustainable way to spend on infrastructure and care involves equitable tax increases, Yellen said.</p><p>Stricter tax compliance would also play a critical role. The country is currently estimated to lose $7 trillion through tax underpayment over the next decade. Stepping up compliance efforts and adequately funding the IRS can also boost tax collection, Yellen added.</p><p>The Treasury Secretary also rebuffed concerns of the massive spending fueling a sharp rise in inflation.</p><p>Administration officials and the Federal Reserve already anticipates the latest stimulus and economic reopening to drive a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-inflation-could-impact-the-stock-market-investing-experts-explain-2021-4\">sharp but temporary bout of stronger inflation</a>. While Biden&#39;s latest proposals are far larger than the March stimulus, plans to spend them over eight to 10 years cuts down on the risk of rampant inflation, Yellen said.</p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t believe that inflation will be an issue, but if it becomes an issue, we have tools to address it,&#34; she added. &#34;These are historic investments that we need to make our economy productive and fair.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-infrastructure-care-plans-janet-yellen-promise-big-return-economy-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
