2021 20:35:18 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608ef91634af8d001859a7a8?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3e370a1dea28da09ec34657c1887fa34","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn94@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-670_47369ee2debcc4d1.webp","destWidth":3537,"destHeight":2652,"sourceBytes":1016948,"destBytes":1016948,"author":"bwinck@businessinsider.com (Ben Winck)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ef90af22c6b00185db2d1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn61@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-26-800_3c0c30bfe4cd0d2f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=z_OkI4vSMak:Wdx7RW1U5hU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-22-072_dcc09791d7d9ebe4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=z_OkI4vSMak:Wdx7RW1U5hU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn79@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-25-715_3575cbb6d97cef70.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=z_OkI4vSMak:Wdx7RW1U5hU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn94@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-22-556_fdc108843137cc4e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/z_OkI4vSMak":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn99@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-133_dbbbdaf13f430256.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238430},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"US GDP will exceed its pre-pandemic peak by the end of June, Atlanta Fed model says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-us-gdp-growth-estimate-atlanta-federal-reserve-forecast-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e9fe834af8d001859a754?format=jpeg\" alt=\"restaurants\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Noam Galai/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Atlanta Fed&#39;s GDPNow estimate sees economic growth reaching 10.4% in the second quarter.</li>\n<li>Such an expansion would place US GDP above its pre-pandemic record and mark a full recovery.</li>\n<li>First-quarter growth reached 6.4% as stimulus and vaccination allowed the economy to reopen.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>By at least one popular measure, the US economy will fully recover and exceed its pre-pandemic strength in the second quarter.</p><p>US gross domestic product is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 10.4% through the quarter that ends in June, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.atlantafed.org/cqer/research/gdpnow\">GDPNow model</a>. Growth at that pace would place economic output at a new record high, surpassing the peak seen during the fourth quarter of 2019. It would also be the second-strongest rate of growth since 1978, exceeded only by the record-breaking expansion seen through the third quarter of 2020.</p><p>The central bank&#39;s nowcast is a type of projection that is updated as new economic data is published. GDPNow isn&#39;t an official forecast from the Atlanta Fed, and is instead used to narrow down where quarterly growth is likely to land. The model also ignores the pandemic&#39;s impact beyond its influence on source data <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/america-post-pandemic-glow-up-consumer-spending-shopping-2021-4\">such as retail sales</a> and global trade, according to the Fed.</p><p>The first GDPNow reading for the second quarter was published on Friday, just one day after the Commerce Department published its initial estimate of first-quarter growth. US GDP expanded <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-q1-gdp-economic-output-recovery-reopening-stimulus-vaccination-recession-2021-4\">at an annualized rate of 6.4%</a> in the first three months of the year, missing the median estimate of 6.7% but still showing a sharp acceleration from the prior period. The jump was primarily fueled by widespread vaccination, gradual reopening, and stimulus passed by former President Donald Trump and President Joe Biden.</p><p>To be sure, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economy-rebound-goods-commodities-services-more-expensive-inflation-stimulus-2021-2\">last quarter&#39;s expansion</a> came in softer than the Atlanta Fed&#39;s final first-quarter estimate of 7.9%.</p><p>Though some individual indicators have already surpassed their pre-pandemic levels and signal a strong recovery, GDP remains just below its previous peak. Following the first-quarter reading, GDP has retraced about 96% of its pandemic-era decline. With data tracking consumer spending and hiring trending higher as the economy reopens further, the US is largely expected to complete its GDP recovery in the next two months.</p><p>Economists outside the Fed also see growth accelerating through the current quarter. The consensus estimate from a survey of forecasters calls for annualized growth of just under 9% in the second quarter. The most bullish estimates see GDP expanding at a rate of more than 11%, while the least optimistic expect growth to land at about 6%.</p><p>The estimates underscore the fact that, should vaccination continue and case counts decline further, the US is on track for its strongest rate of annual growth in decades. The International Monetary Fund estimates GDP will grow 6.4% through all of 2021, exceeding global growth of about 6% and marking the fastest rate of expansion since the early 1980s. Separately, Federal Reserve officials hold a median estimate of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-reserve-economic-outlook-gdp-unemployment-rate-stimulus-vaccinations-fomc-2021-3\">6.5% growth</a> this year.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the 2021 14:11:15 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608eac4034af8d001859a767?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d4391d3c0f8a10a42a91122f25876831","destWidth":2353,"destHeight":1764,"sourceBytes":273958,"destBytes":273958,"author":"bwinck@businessinsider.com (Ben Winck)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608e9fe834af8d001859a754?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn5@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-30-299_47fc80eb06bbe509.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hL4VXNl3cU4:tGnX7l4tEqw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn59@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-751_aeef0e459f2642b8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hL4VXNl3cU4:tGnX7l4tEqw:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=hL4VXNl3cU4:tGnX7l4tEqw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn87@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-945_01013ae10e79bfe0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/hL4VXNl3cU4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn76@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-746_5d71226a0f771337.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238430},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"The Air Force's brand-new F-15EX fighter jet is about to have its first major exercise","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-air-force-f15ex-fighter-jet-first-major-exercise-2021-5","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604f81bed2836f0018d47bf2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Air Force F-15EX fighter jet\" height=\"798\" width=\"1597\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   The first F-15EX is delivered to its new home at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, March 11, 2021. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Air Force/Tech. Sgt. John McRell</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>The US Air Force is sending its new F-15EX fighter to a large-scale exercise around Alaska.</li> \n <li>The top commander in Alaska said the F-15EX will try out its Eagle Passive/Active Warning Survivability System, designed to increase its threat assessment and survivability.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>The US <a href=\"http://www.military.com/air-force\">Air Force</a> is sending its new F-15EX fourth-plus generation fighter to participate in a large-scale exercise in and around Alaska next month.</p>\n<p>The 53rd Wing out of <a href=\"http://www.military.com/base-guide/eglin-air-force-base\">Eglin Air Force Base</a>, Florida, announced Thursday that the F-15EX, now <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2021/04/07/its-official-air-forces-new-f-15ex-fighter-will-be-called-eagle-ii.html\">known as the Eagle II</a>, will conduct operational tests while flying in Exercise Northern Edge 21, a joint Indo-Pacific Command drill incorporating approximately 15,000 service members from each branch, multiple <a href=\"http://www.military.com/navy\">Navy</a> ships and roughly 240 aircraft.</p>\n<p>\"The unique range assets in place at Northern Edge provide a different, unfamiliar, complex, and operationally realistic environment for the technology and the tactics we're testing,\" said Lt. Col. Mike Benitez, 53rd Wing director of staff, <a href=\"https://www.53rdwing.af.mil/News/Article/2590089/53rd-wing-gears-up-for-northern-edge-21/\">in a news release</a>. The service's first two F-15EX fighters belong to the 53rd as they undergo test and evaluation. The Boeing-made jets were delivered to the Air Force earlier this month.</p>\n<p>The wing will also test other equipment during the exercise, such as the Infrared Search and Track sensor pod on the F-15C model and communication node <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2020/12/16/air-force-u-2-surveillance-plane-flies-first-mission-ai-copilot.html\">gateways</a> on the <a href=\"http://www.military.com/equipment/u-2-dragon-lady\">U-2 Dragon Lady</a> spy plane, the release states.</p>\n<p>In a discussion with the Air Force Association this week, Lt. Gen. David Krumm, Pacific Air Forces' 11th Air Force commander, said the <a href=\"https://www.airforcemag.com/brand-new-f-15ex-to-participate-in-northern-edge-exercise-jadc2-experiments/\">F-15EX will try out its</a> Eagle Passive/Active Warning Survivability System, an advanced electronic warfare technology designed to increase its threat assessment and survivability.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604f7d9287891e0019850cca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Air Force F-15EX fighter jet\" height=\"1259\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   The F-15EX arrives to Eglin Air Force Base, March 11, 2021. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Air Force/Samuel King Jr</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Exercise locations include <a href=\"https://www.military.com/base-guide/joint-base-elmendorf-richardson\">Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson</a>, <a href=\"http://www.military.com/base-guide/eielson-air-force-base\">Eielson Air Force Base</a> and Allen Army Airfield, along with King Salmon, Cold Bay, Fairbanks International Airport, Ted Stevens International Airport and Juneau International Airport in Alaska; and <a href=\"https://www.military.com/base-guide/fairchild-air-force-base\">Fairchild Air Force Base</a> and <a href=\"https://www.military.com/base-guide/joint-base-lewis-mcchord\">Joint Base Lewis-McChord</a> in Washington state, according to another release.</p>\n<p>Aircraft will fly within the Joint Pacific Alaska Range Complex, which encompasses more than 77,000 square miles of airspace. Pilots <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2020/05/14/remote-alaska-changes-coming-how-air-force-prepares-war/\">often practice aggressor training</a> there - simulating friendly \"blue air\" against enemy fighters in advanced air-to-air training.</p>\n<p>Ships and aircraft, including the <a href=\"http://www.military.com/topics/joint-strike-fighter\">F-35 Joint Strike Fighter</a>, will operate in the Gulf of Alaska for the exercise, the release adds.</p>\n<p>The Air Force is in the process of building up its fighter fleet at Eielson, including the <a href=\"http://www.military.com/equipment/f-35a-lightning-ii\">F-35A</a> conventional takeoff and landing version, to support missions in both the Pacific and Arctic. A total of 54 F-35s <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2020/04/23/us-intensifies-advanced-fighter-buildup-near-arctic-1st-f-35s-arrive-alaska.html\">are scheduled to arrive</a> at Eielson by December 2021.</p>\n<p>Major units participating in the exercise include the Theodore Roosevelt Carrier Strike Group and Carrier Air Wing 11; the Makin Island Amphibious Ready Group and embarked 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit; the 4th Infantry Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division, from Elmendorf-Richardson; 17th Field Artillery Brigade from Lewis-McChord; and the 3rd Expeditionary Air and Space Task Force.</p>\n<p>\"Typically, training happens within your units, within your services, but you never really get the volume or the complexity you would expect to see in a modern-day conflict,\" said Lt. Col. Mike Boyer, Pacific Air Forces Northern Edge lead planner, in the release.</p>\n<p>\"Northern Edge allows the joint force to put all the pieces of the puzzle together in the big picture and allows our younger generation within the <a href=\"http://www.military.com/join-armed-forces\">armed forces</a> to experience what future conflict could feel like in the complexities associated with it,\" he said.</p>\n<p>The exercise will run from May 3 to 14.</p>\n<p><em>-- Oriana Pawlyk can be reached at <a href=\"mailto:oriana.pawlyk@military.com\">oriana.pawlyk@military.com</a>. Follow her on Twitter at @oriana0214</em>.</p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a (Oriana Pawlyk)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/604f81bed2836f0018d47bf2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn84@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-23-868_92aebf6e067e4a8e.webp","https://i.insider.com/604f7d9287891e0019850cca?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn29@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-29-934_20cfb3d719e1d1ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ojLD0WITSho:P_OQAwhd2QA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn83@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-375_4ec48a38287c899c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ojLD0WITSho:P_OQAwhd2QA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn12@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-915_522af6598a548d1a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ojLD0WITSho:P_OQAwhd2QA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn6@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-554_429269e63043b9f1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ojLD0WITSho":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn100@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-24-115_83fe1a09223f5a94.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238434},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Dermatologists debunk 13 Botox myths","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/dermatologists-debunk-13-myths-about-botox-and-injectables-2021-4","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/GXgzU3n9-jZbcmOYf.html\" width=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" style=\"position:absolute;\" allow=\"fullscreen\"></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Board-certified dermatologists <a href=\"https://rvlskincare.com/\">Dr. Rita Linkner</a> and <a href=\"https://www.drherschthal.com/\">Dr. Jordana Herschthal</a> debunk 13 myths on Botox.</li>\n<li>They talk about why pregnant people shouldn&#39;t get Botox and if patients can exercise afterwards.</li>\n<li>They also give tips for choosing the right injector and why experience matters. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Rita Linkner:</strong> &#34;The Botox chemical is physically addictive.&#34; I think Botox is like getting your hair colored or your nails done. It&#39;s not like you have to, but you&#39;re going to want to. </p><p><strong>Jordana Herschthal:</strong> &#34;Botox is so simple, anyone can give an injection.&#34; My 2-year-old can push a plunger, but it&#39;s also very easy to mess someone&#39;s face up.</p><p>&#34;Botox will make you look emotionless.&#34; Rita, can you tell I&#39;m happy right now?</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> That&#39;s you happy?!</p><p>Hi, my name is Dr. Rita Linkner. I am a board-certified dermatologist from New York City. I spend the majority of my day doing injectables and lasers.</p><p><strong>Herschthal:</strong> Hi, I&#39;m Dr. Jordana Herschthal, and I&#39;m a board-certified dermatologist in Boca Raton, Florida, and I love talking with patients about their aesthetic goals and helping them see the full picture. And we&#39;re here today to debunk myths about Botox.</p><p>Myths from social media.</p><p>&#34;Botox is toxic to your body.&#34; This is not true, but it&#39;s good to know the history of Botox.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>Botox gets that name recognition. It was the first neuromodulator that was FDA approved, so it&#39;s a household name, like Kleenex and Xerox. And so today we&#39;re going to be referring to Botox as that umbrella term when we&#39;re discussing all of the neuromodulators that are currently FDA approved.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>So, Botox contains a purified protein known as botulinum toxin, which is derived from a bacteria that causes botulism, which is toxic to your body. However, Botox used appropriately in appropriate dosing is very safe and very effective. There are over 3,000 studies proving its efficacy and safety. The other reason it is very safe to use is we know that it stays where we inject it. So it&#39;s not like you&#39;re getting Botox in your forehead and it&#39;s going all over your body. Botox is limited to where it is injected, and it is safely metabolized and excreted by your body in a few months.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>I always tell patients if Botox was dangerous, I literally wouldn&#39;t have a pulse. I&#39;m someone who puts, like, 100 units of Botox into my face and neck every four and a half months. And I have so for over a decade.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>So, there are certain medical conditions that are contraindicated to the use of Botox. So you should have a very thorough discussion with your provider before you receive a Botox treatment.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>&#34;Botox is permanent.&#34; So, let&#39;s debunk this one. Botox is not permanent. Everybody metabolizes Botox differently.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>One of the great things about Botox is if you don&#39;t like the way it looks, it&#39;s completely out of your system in three to six months. But it&#39;s also the worst thing, because if you like the way it looks, you have to do it again.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>There is a super-Botox that&#39;s out on the horizon, though, that&#39;s looking to get FDA approved later this year. It&#39;s going for FDA approval for 11s in between the eyebrows, and I can tell you confidently that it works and it&#39;s going to have an indication that&#39;s going to be longer than three to five months.</p><p><strong>Herschthal:</strong> &#34;Some creams and serums work like Botox.&#34; This is absolutely false. Botox works at the muscular level, at specifically the neuromuscular junction, to prevent the muscle from contracting. There is currently no serum, cream, or facial that can penetrate the skin deep enough to exert action at the level of the muscle. And if it were true, it would have to have FDA approval and it would not be available over the counter.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>I completely agree. I like to tell patients, you&#39;re genetically programmed to move your muscles in a certain way, and over time you get what we call dynamic wrinkles, which are lines associated with muscle movement. And the way Botox works is it builds in resistance so that you can&#39;t overutilize those muscles anymore, you can&#39;t crease them, and it basically helps to smooth everything out.</p><p>So, next myth, &#34;Getting Botox is super painful.&#34; I would have to say this one&#39;s false.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>The pain of a Botox needle is pretty minimal, but it is similar to if you got, like, a splinter in your finger or perhaps a beesting. Everybody&#39;s experience with pain is different.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> They&#39;re insulin needles. They&#39;re as small as you can get. And it goes faster than people think, also. Though I think location on the face does make a big difference in terms of sensitivity.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>And this relates to how important it is for your provider to really have a deep understanding of anatomy when you&#39;re getting any sort of injectable on your face.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>I mean, I can do a full face, a full neck of Botox in probably under four minutes. And if people are really averse to needles, you could always topically numb someone to help that pain dissipate.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>There are other little tricks, like vibration devices and also ice. And even for patients who are really sensitive, we break out the Pro-Nox, which is half-dose laughing gas, and that always calms patients down immediately and leaves your system within five minutes.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> &#34;The Botox chemical is physically addictive.&#34; I think Botox is like getting your hair colored or your nails done. This is how I like to explain it to patients who ask me, &#34;If I do this once, do I have to keep doing this for the rest of my life?&#34; It&#39;s not like you have to, but you&#39;re going to want to.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>So, I always liken aesthetic treatments like Botox, fillers, and lasers to maintaining any organ in your system. You get your teeth cleaned two to four times a year or whatever it is; you get your aesthetic treatments because you&#39;re always aging. These treatments do not stop the aging process, but these treatments will help you age the way you want to age.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> Myth experts hear the most.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>&#34;Botox is so simple, anyone can give an injection.&#34; On the one hand, giving an injection is very easy. Anyone can push a plunger, my 2-year-old can push a plunger, but it&#39;s also very easy to mess someone&#39;s face up. So it&#39;s really critical that your provider has a deep understanding of anatomy and how these medicines affect anatomy to give you reproducible, great aesthetic outcomes.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>So, Jordana and I are board-certified dermatologists. It took each of us over a decade to get to the point where we were able to put a syringe in our hands and utilize the medicine in it to create facial aesthetics. Both Jordana and I, still to this day, we take courses religiously where we&#39;re learning from the best international patients and doing dissection courses. And we&#39;re still reading every day to really be the best teachers that we can be for our patients.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>&#34;Botox and fillers are the same.&#34; I love this myth, because I probably address it at least once a day. Almost every line on your face can be addressed with filler, but not every line can be addressed with Botox. Botox works at the level of the muscle to relax muscles of contraction. It is preventing and diminishing those static lines, or lines at rest. Fillers, on the other hand, are used to address volume loss that occurs in our face as we age. So, we all have fat compartments all over our face. And as we age, they deflate and descend with time, so we use fillers to restore that lost volume and give a more youthful shape to the face.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>&#34;Botox injections need a lot of recovery time.&#34;</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>The only issue with Botox is if you get a bruise, but there really isn&#39;t downtime. There&#39;s about an hour after the procedure where you will see little bumps under the skin, and that&#39;s the solution of the Botox that was placed under the skin.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>You are taking a needle and putting it into your skin, so you just want to make sure that you&#39;re not doing anything to really thin your blood, which would increase the chances of getting a bruise. So ideally not drinking alcohol the night before or even caffeine the morning of really helps. If you have really high tendency towards bruising, it&#39;s nice to take oral arnica.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>I can always tell when I&#39;m injecting a patient. I call it the booze ooze. It&#39;s like this slow ooze after you inject, and I know that they&#39;ve had a glass of wine or a martini the night before.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> My only rule that I have for my patients when Botox goes in is no exercising for six hours.</p><p><strong>Herschthal:</strong> My only rule is don&#39;t touch the Botox, because I don&#39;t want you spreading it to a different area in the forehead or the glabella area, because you could get into trouble with dropping somebody&#39;s lid. So, the muscles that keep the brow elevated will drop, and then the patient will appear to have a heavier lid. Again, these are not permanent side effects, but they are undesirable side effects.</p><p>&#34;Botox accumulates in the body.&#34; I wish that was true, but unfortunately it does not.</p><p><strong>Linkner</strong>: Every week that your Botox is in, it incrementally decreases. It&#39;s not like it just turns off overnight. I will tell you, in this pandemic, I&#39;m noticing people are exercising more, and that&#39;s making their Botox metabolize a little bit faster. So I get that question a lot. You know, &#34;How do we make my Botox last longer?&#34; And it is dose dependent. So if you put more in, it might not look so natural for those first few weeks, but it should get you to last a couple of weeks longer than when you were using a lower dose.</p><p><strong>Herschthal</strong>: Myths from pop culture. &#34;Botox will make you look emotionless.&#34; I&#39;m hearing the hate, but I&#39;m not seeing the hate. Rita, can you tell I&#39;m happy right now?</p><p><strong>Linkner</strong>: That&#39;s you happy?!</p><p><strong>Herschthal</strong>: So, I think &#34;emotionless&#34; is a little bit of a strong word to describe the effects of Botox. If you have an open conversation with your provider about what your desires are for your Botox treatment, you can easily get a treatment that is more natural looking where you still preserve some movement in the upper face.</p><p><strong>Linkner</strong>: It&#39;s been exactly eight days since Jordana put my Botox in. It hasn&#39;t peaked out yet, but it&#39;s starting to get tighter on me every single day. Do I love how it looks? I mean, I do. Do I love how my children can&#39;t tell what I&#39;m thinking? I love that. So you really have to figure out where you want to run on that spectrum.</p><p><strong>Herschthal:</strong> &#34;Botox is only used cosmetically.&#34; So, Botox was actually first FDA approved in 1989. And that was for the use of two medical disorders of the eye, which is called strabismus and blepharospasm. It wasn&#39;t actually until 2002 that Botox got its first FDA approval for cosmetic indication.</p><p><strong>Linkner</strong>: Well, thank goodness those oculoplastic surgeons were trying to treat these overexercising eye muscles, because that&#39;s when they saw that the 11s in between the eyebrows were disappearing. So it&#39;s because of strabismus that all of us don&#39;t have lines on our face anymore.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>So, Botox has actually been around for over 30 years, and it has over 27 indications, most of which are medical.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> A very common use is for oversweating. So in the underarms, hands, and feet are places, because Botox does attack that little muscle on every sweat gland that helps you to sweat. It can turn that off so that you can decrease sweating. I&#39;ve also used it medically for migraines. The list of FDA indications for medical Botox is so long.</p><p>&#34;Only older women get Botox.&#34; Ugh! No, that&#39;s so false. I was 27 the first time that I put Botox into my crow&#39;s-feet. And I will tell you, it&#39;s something that I do religiously and have done every four and a half months for the past decade.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>So, I like to say that Botox is not gender nor is it age specific. There&#39;s also a huge increase in male patients coming in, specifically for their crow&#39;s-feet. People are wanting to look their best, feel their best. So Botox is not age and it is not gender specific.</p><p><strong>Linkner:</strong> &#34;Botox works right away.&#34;</p><p>Fiona: [sighs] It&#39;s the Botox. I can&#39;t show emotion for another hour and a half.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>So, truthfully, Botox can take, it takes a couple of days to kick in. So let&#39;s say your Botox goes in Friday; you&#39;re not going to start to really feel those results into Sunday, into Monday. It takes a full two weeks to peak out. And at that two-week period, incrementally every single week you&#39;ll gain a little bit of movement back. Everybody metabolizes this stuff differently.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>I think we look natural. I think we&#39;re doing a good job of looking natural.</p><p><strong>Linkner: </strong>We have code words with each other. So if, like, Jordana tells me the code word, then I know I&#39;ve gone to over the line.</p><p><strong>Herschthal: </strong>Yeah, we&#39;ve gone over the edge.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the roundup of Investing stories from deputy editor Joe Ciolli. Feel free to drop me a line at <a href=\"mailto:ddefrancesco@businessinsider.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">jciolli@insider.<wbr>com</wbr></a> or on Twitter <a href=\"https://twitter.com/JoeCiolli\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://newsletter.businessinsider.com/click/22701216.10885/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9kYW5kZWZyYW5jZXNjbz9ucl9lbWFpbF9yZWZlcmVyPTEmdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1TYWlsdGhydSZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPWVtYWlsJnV0bV9jb250ZW50PUluc2lkZXIlMjBGaW5hbmNl/5bd0c4d12ddf9c61941dda0bB0830adc0&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1611419675839000&amp;usg=AFQjCNEGYQ82VywLxbdnhW_p9VAiZzg0ww_p9VAiZzg0ww\">@JoeCiolli</a>.</p>\n<hr>\n <h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/crypto-investing-arca-cio-shares-10-tokens-special-situations-strategy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">10 top crypto tokens</a></h2>\n <h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/crypto-investing-arca-cio-shares-10-tokens-special-situations-strategy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\n   <figure> \n    <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608181e8354dde0018c0696f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Arca CIO Jeff Dorman, CFA\" height=\"377\" width=\"755\" charset=\"\"> \n     <figcaption> \n      <p class=\"copyright\">Arca</p> \n     </figcaption> </img>\n   </figure></a></h2>\n <p>Jeff Dorman is the chief investment officer of the $200 million crypto asset manager Arca. He shares <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/crypto-investing-arca-cio-shares-10-tokens-special-situations-strategy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">3 themes and 10 tokens he's betting on in crypto</a>, and also walks through an example of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/crypto-investing-arca-cio-shares-10-tokens-special-situations-strategy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">how to execute special situations investing in digital assets</a>.</p>\n <p><strong>Read the full story here:</strong></p>\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/crypto-investing-arca-cio-shares-10-tokens-special-situations-strategy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The investing chief of crypto asset manager Arca shares the 3 themes and 10 tokens he's betting on - and explains how to execute his special-situations investing strategy in digital assets</a></h3>\n <hr>\n  <h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rising-stars-top-young-equity-research-analysts-wall-street-2021\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The rising stars of equity research</a></h2>\n  <p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rising-stars-top-young-equity-research-analysts-wall-street-2021\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\n    <figure> \n     <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c1c3235c46f0018c0b7e6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"rising stars in equity research 2x1\" height=\"1200\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\"> \n      <figcaption>\n       From left to right: Edison Yu, Emily Chieng, Rajat Gupta, and Aga Zmigrodzka \n       <p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Deutsche Bank; Courtesy of Goldman Sachs; Courtesy of JPMorgan; Courtesy of UBS; Marianne Ayala/Insider</p> \n      </figcaption> </img>\n    </figure></a></p>\n  <p>For our Rising Stars of Equity Research feature, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rising-stars-top-young-equity-research-analysts-wall-street-2021\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">we selected 19 young analysts 35 and under covering a wide range of sectors</a> from gaming to natural gas. The group hails from top Wall Street firms including Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley.</p>\n  <p><strong>Read the full story here:</strong></p>\n  <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rising-stars-top-young-equity-research-analysts-wall-street-2021\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Meet the rising stars of equity research, up-and-comers making calls on everything from the next big electric car maker to the return of live events</a></h3>\n  <hr>\n   <h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacs-bet-against-short-sellers-made-millions-profits-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The 10 most profitable SPAC shorts right now</a></h2>\n   <p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacs-bet-against-short-sellers-made-millions-profits-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\n     <figure> \n      <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/603839fdd9208800185921f0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SPACs and hedge funds 2x1\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\"> \n       <figcaption> \n        <p class=\"copyright\">Brian Snyder/Reuters; Michael Loccisano/Getty Images; Samantha Lee/Insider</p> \n       </figcaption> </img>\n     </figure></a></p>\n   <p>SPAC short-sellers have raked in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacs-bet-against-short-sellers-made-millions-profits-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">more than $500 million in mark-to-market profits</a> over the past 30 days. Their bearish bets have paid off amid a steep decline in SPAC market sentiment and overall performance.</p>\n   <p>Exclusive data from S3 Partners details <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacs-bet-against-short-sellers-made-millions-profits-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the 10 most profitable SPAC shorts in the market right now</a>.</p>\n   <p><strong>Read the full story here:</strong></p>\n   <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacs-bet-against-short-sellers-made-millions-profits-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SPAC short-sellers have taken home $500 million in 30 days. These are the 10 most profitable blank-check companies to bet against right now.</a></h3>\n   <hr>\n    <h2><strong>Stock pick central</strong></h2>\n    <p>Seeking experts who are willing to name names? Look no further:</p>\n    <ul>\n     <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-now-innovative-firms-upside-jabusch-deems-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Garvin Jabusch and Jeremy Deems returned 141% to investors over the last year by betting on innovation. They share 5 stocks they're bullish on for the long-term - including one they 'very comfortably predict' will surge at least 300%.</a></li>\n     <li><a booming NFT opportunity as digital collectibles continue to become more mainstream despite the recent price slump</a></li>\n     <li><a to benefit from the worldwide growth boom as the pace in the US begins to slow</a></li>\n     <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/small-cap-growth-stocks-to-buy-before-they-rebound-oppenheimer-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Buy these 12 stocks that are spring-loaded for powerful comebacks as investors rush into smaller companies again, Oppenheimer says</a></li>\n     <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stocks-to-buy-crypto-blockchain-stock-picks-outperformance-sp500-goldman-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Goldman Sachs names 19 crypto-exposed stocks that have piggybacked on bitcoin's surge to achieve returns that have nearly quadrupled the S&amp;P 500</a></li>\n    </ul>\n    <div class=\"read-original\">\n     Read the original article on \n href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=wYW6mM66CzA:-_Qe-FFs1FU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n     <a </hr>\n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 20:18:57 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/604bd13e10c8760018b93056?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7726b873f7d58162f2fb73e08bd40c63","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn10@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-21-661_2294e1de890821c3.webp","destWidth":712,"destHeight":534,"sourceBytes":56744,"destBytes":56744,"author":"jciolli@businessinsider.com (Joe Ciolli)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/604bd13310c8760018b93055?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn9@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-513_5642b01cf7ca1ee5.webp","https://i.insider.com/608181e8354dde0018c0696f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn53@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-361_580b2ff164ff5799.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c1c3235c46f0018c0b7e6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-24-262_b98ff0bef973aad6.webp","https://i.insider.com/603839fdd9208800185921f0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn5@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-067_95cab6688c6607e4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wYW6mM66CzA:-_Qe-FFs1FU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn54@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-296_437b926a5dd74d89.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wYW6mM66CzA:-_Qe-FFs1FU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn45@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-23-342_8335e4b25c45a2a5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wYW6mM66CzA:-_Qe-FFs1FU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn86@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-22-465_009776b5e41a1bad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/wYW6mM66CzA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-009_ecb195e659e4d752.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238426},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Marines scored direct hit on target at sea in first live-fire test using Navy missile and unmanned vehicle","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/marines-fire-antiship-missile-unmanned-truck-target-at-sea-2021-5","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cd5904ce9f08a0f045f47eb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"naval strike missile NSM konsberg\" height=\"640\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   A Naval Strike Missile is launched from USS Coronado in September 2014. \n   <p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_Strike_Missile#/media/File:Naval_Strike_Missile_launch_from_USS_Coronado_%28LCS-4%29_in_September_2014.JPG\" target=\"_blank\">US Navy photo by Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Zachary D. Bell</a></p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>The Navy Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System has been tested successfully against a target at sea.</li> \n <li>NMESIS combines two existing technologies - Naval Strike Missiles and modified Joint Light Tactical Vehicles - for a deadly new way to hit targets offshore.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>Marines scored a direct hit in a first-ever live-fire test in which they launched a <a href=\"http://www.military.com/navy\">Navy</a> missile from the back of an unmanned tactical vehicle to strike a surface target at sea.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.military.com/marine-corps\">Marine Corps</a> has combined two existing technologies to produce a deadly new way to hit targets offshore. Coined NMESIS, the Navy Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System can launch Naval Strike Missiles from the back of a modified <a href=\"http://www.military.com/equipment/joint-light-tactical-vehicle-jltv\">Joint Light Tactical Vehicle</a>, or JLTV, to destroy targets on land or at sea.</p>\n<p>Raytheon Missiles and Defense, which makes the Naval Strike Missile, announced Wednesday that the Marine Corps used NMESIS to hit a target in the water from Point Mugu Sea Range in California. The missile can take out targets from more than 100 nautical miles away.</p>\n<p>Commandant Gen. David Berger showed a photo of the test launch to lawmakers Thursday when discussing the need for funding for ground-based anti-ship missiles. He called the test the result of the \"brilliance of a couple of young officers\" and Oshkosh Defense, a Wisconsin-based company that makes the JLTV.</p>\n<p>\"The people at Oshkosh and these couple of majors thought, 'We can do this,' so they took the cab off the back and they put a missile in the back with a fire-control system,\" Berger said. \"Now, we can move this around on vessels or put it ashore and hold an adversary's navy at risk ... to ensure that the lines on the sea are kept open.</p>\n<p>\"This is the speed at which we have to move,\" he added.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ebafcf22c6b00185db297?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Navy Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System\" height=\"534\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   NMESIS can launch naval strike missiles from the back of a modified Joint Light Tactical Vehicle at targets on land or at sea. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Navy</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Getting funding for ground-based long-range precision fires out of the next budget will be crucial for the Marine Corps' mission, Berger told lawmakers. He wrote in his 2019 planning guidance that the service had fallen \"woefully behind\" in the development of ground-based long-range precision fires.</p>\n<p>\"We must possess the ability to turn maritime spaces into barriers so we can attack an adversary's sea lines of communication ... while defending our own in support of the Fleet or Joint Force,\" Berger wrote.</p>\n<p>In 2021, the Marine Corps requested $125 million to buy nearly 50 Tomahawk missiles it could launch from land. Congress ultimately did not fund the move. Adm. Phil Davidson, the head of US Indo-Pacific Command, told lawmakers in March that the decision to slash those funds hurt the military's ability to deter China.</p>\n<p>The JLTV used in the test at Point Mugu is an unmanned version known as a ROGUE - or remotely operated ground unit for expeditionary - fires vehicle. The Naval Strike Missile fired from the back carries a 500-pound class warhead, according to Raytheon. The Navy uses the missile on <a href=\"http://www.military.com/equipment/littoral-combat-ship-lcs\">littoral combat ships</a>.</p>\n<p>Combined, the missile and ROGUE fires vehicle form NMESIS, which is operated by artillery Marines, Lt. Gen. Eric Smith, the deputy commandant of Combat Development and Integration, told reporters this month.</p>\n<p>Berger said using a modified JLTV and a proven strike missile gives commanders flexibility since they can fire the munition from a ship or ashore.</p>\n<p>\"It's the same missile, so as needed, the commander can move the ordnance where it's needed most,\" he said. \"... [It also] speeds up our ability to field it. It's a proven missile. ... This is not a new missile system - we know how it performs. So we're riding on the backs of something that is already developed and putting it on a platform that we're very confident in.\"</p>\n<p><em>- Gina Harkins can be reached at <a href=\"mailto:gina.harkins@military.com\">gina.harkins@military.com</a>. Follow her on Twitter<a href=\"http://www.twitter.com/ginaaharkins\"> @ginaaharkins</a>.</em></p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=aL-AZx1Rg9w:JM0Cs6F29k4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aL-AZx1Rg9w\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 14:58:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608ebd1234af8d001859a779?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c7ca736074de715b2532bb116f2749e3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn28@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-656_86b0217272ea7dc0.webp","destWidth":712,"destHeight":534,"sourceBytes":15000,"destBytes":15000,"author":"insider@insider.com (Gina Harkins)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5cd5904ce9f08a0f045f47eb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn42@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-667_fc7aef36db730fe8.webp","https://i.insider.com/608ebafcf22c6b00185db297?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-27-427_bef2fc65db80ffa7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aL-AZx1Rg9w:JM0Cs6F29k4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn87@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-22-806_f1f9589b05e3c4b5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aL-AZx1Rg9w:JM0Cs6F29k4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn54@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-26-860_2caaa176a583c03d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aL-AZx1Rg9w:JM0Cs6F29k4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn70@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-22-777_7d27a36217094aa1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aL-AZx1Rg9w":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238429},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Huge US amphibious tank craft from World War II discovered buried 30 feet underground in an English field","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-buffalo-us-amy-craft-wwii-unearthed-english-field-decades-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e8c47f22c6b00185db25d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"crowland tank buffalo unearthed\" height=\"903\" width=\"1806\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A 26-foot-long Buffalo tank is extracted from the earth in Crowland, Lincolnshire, on April 29, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Joe Giddens/PA Images via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A number of Buffalo LVT landing craft were swept away by floods in Lincolnshire, England, in 1947.</li>\n<li>This weekend, one of the US-made craft was dug up by a group of volunteers after a five-day dig.</li>\n<li>The armed craft were used to ferry supplies and cross water bodies in conflicts in the Pacific and Europe.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Excavators in England have unearthed a huge World War II-era US landing craft from a field, 74 years after it went missing.</p><p>In 1947, more than a dozen Buffalo LVT were transported to Crowland, Lincolnshire, to help the British Army build flood defenses, but five were swept away in high waters.</p><p>This weekend, a group of local military enthusiasts succeeded in their mission to unearth one of the 26-foot-long craft after a five-day dig, which they found buried 30 feet below the earth, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-56944032\">the BBC reported</a>.</p><p>Watch drone footage of the craft - which weights 18 tonnes - being pulled from the excavation pit here:</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/dxlaJ4kvnWY\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p>The Buffalo LVT was a US-made landing craft used to transport supplies and crosses water bodies in Europe and the Pacific region. It saw action inWorld War II&#39;s greatest battles, including the Battle for Iwo Jima and D-Day.</p><p>The group behind the excavation believes that this Buffalo LVT was also previously used to cross the River Rhine in Germany in March 1945, <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/wartime-lvt-4-buffalo-dug-up-in-fens-after-74-years-underground-fwxs0z09b\">The Times of London reported.</a> The BBC said the Buffalo LVT was also key in getting allied troops across the Elbe river, also in Germany, the same year.</p><p>The craft appears to be in good condition, the volunteers said, due to the nature of the clay and peat soil that has surrounded it for 74 years .</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e8a3334af8d001859a739?format=jpeg\" alt=\"tank ww2 england crowland\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A man seen after uncovering a 26-foot-long Buffalo tank in Crowland, Lincolnshire, on April 29, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Joe Giddens/PA Images via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>&#34;I&#39;m over the moon with what we&#39;ve achieved - it&#39;s very exciting. We&#39;ve spent five days digging,&#34; Daniel Abbott, chairman of the Crowland Buffalo LVT Association, told The Times.</p><p>&#34;We found the gun mount first and it&#39;s in fantastic condition for its age. The tank seems to have been well preserved in the clay.&#34;</p><p>The volunteers told the BBC they wanted the craft to stay in the town and become a memorial for the 1947 floods. </p><div (Bill Bostock)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608e8c47f22c6b00185db25d?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/608e8a3334af8d001859a739?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn39@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-306_693ed4b1bb746547.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qKr_oZLUyCQ:Sm_i4OVQyZM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-28-088_a7857781e016617c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qKr_oZLUyCQ:Sm_i4OVQyZM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn20@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-23-946_a45b2df325b9b8e0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qKr_oZLUyCQ:Sm_i4OVQyZM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn24@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-23-273_aaea1029a28f8ad5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qKr_oZLUyCQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-22-536_c3ff9d88cfab873e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238430},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"I'm a dating coach whose inbox is flooded with requests from newly vaccinated singles. Here's what I predict will be popular on dating apps post-pandemic.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/dating-industry-dating-coach-apps-post-covid-pandemic-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5faeaa124652d400197443a9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Meredith Golden photo credit Sam Khan\" height=\"2288\" width=\"3051\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Meredith Golden launched her dating app ghostwriting service in 2015.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Sam Khan</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Meredith Golden is a professional dating coach and dating profile ghostwriter.</li>\n<li>Recently, she says her inbox has been flooded with inquiries from the newly vaccinated.</li>\n<li>Darma, her new app, provides post-date feedback and includes a &#39;closure&#39; button to prevent ghosting.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A few weeks ago, my inbox suddenly started filling up with inquiries about my <a href=\"https://spoonmeetspoon.com/packages/\">dating profile and coaching services</a>, prompted by the combination of warmer weather and the COVID-19 vaccine rollouts. </p><p>While everyone who&#39;s spent the past year at home alone is eager to make up for lost time, those on the vaccination priority list - the 65+ age group and those with pre-existing medical conditions - are like bulls rushing out of the gate ready to get back into the dating arena.</p><h2><strong>These days, &#39;vaccinated&#39; is the hottest detail you can add to your dating app bio. </strong></h2><p>Now I see vaccine status updates on every three to four profiles out there. It&#39;s become a badge of honor as well as a great conversation starter.</p><p>People are not only mentioning they&#39;ve been vaccinated, they&#39;re also going into detail as to which vaccine they got and whether they&#39;re half or fully vaccinated. Some even include an eye-catching 💉 emoji. </p><p>Sharing these types of details has become an easy way to convert a conversation to the next stage of the dating process. It&#39;s truly become the ultimate pre-pandemic icebreaker to say, &#34;Oh, look at us, we&#39;re both vaccinated, we should go out and celebrate.&#34; </p><p>As research continues to emerge regarding <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vaccines-reduce-coronavirus-transmission-early-research-2021-2\">whether or not the vaccines fully prevent transmission of the virus</a>, many singles still view someone who&#39;s been vaccinated as a safer option.</p><p>The bottom line is if they&#39;ve got two choices to date - between the unvaccinated, meaning a date who can pass on COVID-19, and the vaccinated, someone who likely won&#39;t - it&#39;s pretty obvious who looks like a more attractive candidate.</p><h2><strong>People are eager to date again without the fear they might wind up on a ventilator</strong>.</h2><p>Safety isn&#39;t the only factor though. People also want to make the best use of their time.</p><p>I&#39;ve long considered video chats a smart screening tool, as they can help determine whether the person you&#39;re talking to is worth meeting in person. It&#39;s an easy and efficient way to advance a relationship, especially now that work has been reimagined and geography is no longer restrictive for most people. </p><p>This flexibility has made people more open to searching in different markets because they no longer have to board a flight and &#34;meet&#34; for the first time blindly. Technology is evolving the long-distance dating process in that respect. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">One of my clients was initially very skeptical about using video chat. She was excited to advance with someone and meet him in person, saying &#34;I think I like this one. He looks great.&#34; However, I told her she couldn&#39;t like him because she didn&#39;t even know him, and encouraged her to have a video chat first. A few days later, I got a text saying, &#34;Dodged a bullet with that one. Thank you!&#34;</p><p>While video chat features were available long before the pandemic, they were often underutilized. Since COVID-19, more people have come to understand their value, and I believe video chats are now here to stay.</p><p>At the end of the day, singles invest a lot of time, effort, emotions, and resources when it comes to dating, so when they aren&#39;t successful in terms of finding a match, it can leave them feeling frustrated and defeated. </p><h2><strong>After being isolated the past year, some singles are throwing their pre-COVID-19 requirements out the window.</strong></h2><p>People are ready to get back out there with a more open mind. Many didn&#39;t miss the pain points that come along with dating, but know they can&#39;t completely take themselves out of the market because they still want to meet someone. These types are re-entering the dating world with the mindset that dating is less of a priority than before. </p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">One of my clients who had a lot of pre-COVID requirements clearly reconsidered as she wound up telling me, &#34;If he&#39;s over six feet and vaccinated, count me in!&#34;</p><p>The pre-COVID-19 style of dating is still kind of a novelty at the moment. These early days and attitudes around dating will most likely be different six months from now or even by Labor Day, as people begin to make adjustments to their lifestyle and mindset.</p><h2><strong>Based on my work, while rejection may sting, the consensus is that singles would rather know a connection isn&#39;t moving forward than be ghosted. </strong></h2><p>It&#39;s typically the ambiguity and precariousness of dating that takes up a lot of brain space and creates anxiety. If you know the door is shut, your brain stops ruminating, the loop is closed, and you can move on. There&#39;s a lot to be said for closure.</p><p>The fact is, while many dating apps do their best to match people, they don&#39;t address common dating pain points, such as helping to provide appropriate feedback, a lack of manners, and a desire for closure.</p><p>After being a dating coach for more than five years, I decided to create a dating app called <a href=\"https://darmadating.com/\">Darma</a> that allows people to connect while also offering users the opportunity to receive confidential feedback and closure, something no other app does. Dating feedback can often reveal blind spots in dating or validate that you&#39;re doing everything right. Either way, it&#39;s helpful for a person to know.</p><p>If a single provides a cell number for their date, Darma follows up and asks for feedback from a series of pre-selected options ranging from your date&#39;s table manners and punctuality to their attire and personal hygiene. There&#39;s even a handy &#39;closure&#39; button that allows you to fire off a preselected note rather than ghost someone. </p><h2><strong>Everyone wants more matches on a dating app because matches create opportunities.</strong></h2><p>The dating industry will still evolve post-COVID-19, and while not everyone can afford to hire me or another dating coach, not everyone needs to. I&#39;ve learned through my work that many of the problems with dating can be easily solved with the assistance of technology.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/607442ae3e3fe7001882a11e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"42244b868f6c443fafaf52fb9476db26","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-18-567_9857c4b6c589d956.webp","destWidth":3537,"destHeight":2653,"sourceBytes":650820,"destBytes":650820,"author":"ljohnson@businessinsider.com (Lauren Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/607442ae3e3fe7001882a11e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-18-567_9857c4b6c589d956.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c110834af8d001859a208?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn73@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-23-473_58a21cad0c5a8985.webp","https://i.insider.com/608c0fce35c46f0018c0b74f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn62@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-27-889_b44051584e8414d9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ElVKhue-wCI:IDaG-oK2BAI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn29@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-22-711_3601275efa520c40.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ElVKhue-wCI:IDaG-oK2BAI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn63@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-25-017_aea46ad127b69dbb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ElVKhue-wCI:IDaG-oK2BAI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn71@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-27-459_2ae097e16e28ccf2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ElVKhue-wCI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-27-346_78dd91599f1cc547.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238426},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"I went on a Walmart 'treasure hunt' to find hidden deals on clearance items - here's what I found","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/walmart-app-hidden-clearance-shopping-deals-discounts-facebook-groups-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa18e4169331a0011bc6fd1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart new store format\" height=\"1315\" width=\"1754\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>&#34;Hidden clearance&#34; shoppers scour Walmart for deals and share tips online.</li>\n<li>Insider spoke to one shopper about her experiences, and then tried it out in person.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>With over 500,000 members, the Walmart Clearance Shoppers Facebook group is a community unto itself where shoppers share deals that seem implausibly good, with markdown prices as low as a few pennies. </p><p>Walmart has a huge amount of inventory in its stores and online. The community of clearance shoppers approaches finding these hidden markdowns as something of a &#34;treasure hunt.&#34; Click2Houston <a href=\"https://www.click2houston.com/news/local/2021/04/29/walmart-hidden-clearance-is-a-treasure-hunt/\">first reported</a> on the phenomenon on Thursday.  </p><p>The premise of the &#34;treasure hunt&#34; is that the in-store tag doesn&#39;t always match the actual price of an item. So these shoppers take matters into their own hands, downloading the Walmart app and scanning items&#39; bar codes directly to find hidden deals. </p><p><strong style=\"background-color: #ffff00;\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c649634af8d001859a5d9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart clearance\" height=\"666\" width=\"826\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Screenshot from Facebook</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>The Clearance Shoppers Facebook group is run by Kendall Motzny, who uses the name &#34;The Freebie Guy.&#34; Motzny is one of several administrators of the group. They enforce the rules - no selling, no calling corporate, no spam - and set the tone for the legions of bargain shoppers. </p><p>Shoppers share their deals and congratulate each other in Motzny&#39;s group, which is a surprisingly collaborative effort. Posters often share the codes for their items so that other shoppers can check availability in their own stores using the website <a href=\"https://brickseek.com/\">BrickSeek</a>, which tracks deals and inventory at major retailers like Walmart, Target, and CVS Pharmacy. </p><p>Another Facebook group run by Mama Deals has nearly 400,000 members and a similarly active community of bargain hunters - extreme coupons for the digital age. </p><p>Heather Robbins, a Walmart clearance shopper based in Kansas, recently left her job in a hospital to care for her children. </p><p>&#34;Between going through a pandemic, my husband working swing shifts, and myself staying home with the children all day, I needed a hobby,&#34; she told Insider. </p><p>She heard about the hidden clearance hunting through The Freebie Guy&#39;s social-media platforms. &#34;So, I decided to give Walmart hidden-clearance hunting a try, and turns out I&#39;m actually really good at it,&#34; she told Insider. </p><p>Her favorite finds are typically blankets, though she&#39;s also proud of snagging a crib that was originally $299 for $25. Even if she can&#39;t use an item right when she buys it, she&#39;ll donate it to someone in need or save it for a holiday gift.  </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608af9dd35c46f0018c0b4cf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart hidden clearance\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The clearance aisle at a Walmart in Philadelphia, PA\n<p class=\"copyright\">Annabelle Williams/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>What it&#39;s like to hunt for hidden clearance deals</h2><p>I went to Walmart in Philadelphia to check out exactly how the process works for myself. Once there, I made a beeline for the clearance section. All you need is a smartphone with a camera, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.walmart.com%2Fcp%2Fwalmart-app%2F1087865\">Walmart app</a>, and a bit of patience. Then, you want to scan, scan, scan. </p><p>Robbins had told me a bit about her strategy.</p><p>&#34;I look around on the Walmart app, I pay attention to the hidden clearance pages, and I scan the items when I&#39;m in the store. Once you get going and understand the process more, it&#39;s a lot easier to figure out,&#34; Robbins said.</p><p>The Walmart I went to was somewhat daunting - it had one small clearance aisle, but the deals weren&#39;t confined just to that area. Armed with the Walmart app and the BrickSeek website, I looked around for deals and scanned bar codes on my phone. Thankfully, turning on location services in the app allowed Walmart to register I was inside the story, which came in handy when looking for inventory.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608af9de34af8d0018599f86?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart hidden clearance\" height=\"1792\" width=\"828\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>When I entered the store and opened the Walmart app, it registered immediately.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Screnshot from Walmart app</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In a <a href=\"https://www.click2houston.com/news/local/2021/04/29/walmart-hidden-clearance-is-a-treasure-hunt/\">report from Click2Houston</a> that spoke to Kendall Motzny, a.k.a. &#34;The Freebie Guy,&#34; Motzny advises shoppers to focus on items on the top shelves, or tucked away on the sides: it&#39;s easiest for workers to miss these tags with price updates. From there, it&#39;s something of a game of chance.</p><p>The clearance aisle had good deals - and ones that were cheaper than the retailer&#39;s website, but I didn&#39;t spot any mismatched labels. Some labels, particularly those on the top shelves, didn&#39;t scan. When they did scan, the app came up with a price and a location in the store.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608af9df34af8d0018599f88?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart hidden clearance\" height=\"1792\" width=\"828\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>After scanning items, the information populated in the app.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Screenshot from Walmart app</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>So I followed the deals on BrickSeek, which led me to the jeans section. The Levi Strauss Signature jeans were priced at $21.94, but when I scanned them, they came up as $15 - not a life-changing steal, but a small victory nonetheless. </p><p>When I moved to candles and homeware, which BrickSeek listed as one of the most heavily discounted sections, I found that many of the deals were very specific: a particular scent of a candle, but not the whole line, or one color of a knife set. </p><p>Shoppers in the Facebook groups say that every trip isn&#39;t always a home run: some go to multiple stores to track down deals they&#39;ve heard about from fellow clearance shoppers. But the community is very collaborative, and the atmosphere in the Facebook groups is both congenial and helpful - shoppers celebrate each other&#39;s finds and share tips of their own to maximize savings.</p><p>&#34;It has been so addicting to get into,&#34; Robbins said, &#34;but it&#39;s a lot of fun and helps to save and make money!&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original
