11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"How to start 12 small businesses from scratch - whether you're into copywriting, urban farming, or food trucks","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-a-business-writing-farming-food-truck-more-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608c4de535c46f0018c0bade?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Examples of how to start your business, including dog walking, a food truck, urban farming, hair care, and dyed yarn.\" height=\"1125\" width=\"1501\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A record number of people started new businesses last year, including dog walking, urban farming, and food trucks.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iStock; Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The pandemic upended many lives, but it didn&#39;t overturn the entrepreneurial dream.</li>\n<li>Applications for an employer ID reached 1.1 million through September in 2020, a 12% increase from the prior year. </li>\n<li>Here are 12 guides on how to start any business, from a modest urban farm to a food truck. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The pandemic upended many lives, but it didn&#39;t overturn the entrepreneurial dream. </p><p>A record number of people started new businesses last year. New applications for an employer ID in the US reached 1.1 million through September 2020, a 12% increase from the same time period in 2019, according to an analysis of US Census data by <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/is-it-insane-to-start-a-business-during-coronavirus-millions-of-americans-dont-think-so-11601092841\">The Wall Street Journal</a>. </p><p>For those who want to chase their entrepreneurial passions, here are 12 guides on how to start a business, from a dog-walking empire, to a modest urban farm, and even a food truck.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t1. Copywriting business\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070a9b34943790018bb1b74?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sarah turner\" height=\"601\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sarah Turner Agency offers freelance copywriting for clients in the medical and health sectors, content marketing strategy, and training programs for future copywriters.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Sarah Turner)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Sarah Turner launched her eponymous copywriting agency in 2013, after leaving her job as a research assistant.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.writeyourwaytofreedom.co/\">Sarah Turner Agency</a>&#160;offers freelance copywriting for clients in the medical and health sectors, content marketing strategy, and training programs for future copywriters. Last year, Turner booked $2.6 million in revenue, according to documents verified by Insider.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-copywriting-business-from-scratch-2021-4\">Read more about how Turner launched her copywriting business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t2. Website flipping\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087fbb10da8f40018033a6f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chelsea\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Chelsea Clarke is the founder of Blogs for Sale.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Friday Eve Photo)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Chelsea Clarke is the founder of Blogs For Sale, a company that flips little-known websites into desirable online businesses that can generate $16,800 in a year.</p><p>Clarke said her startup took off last year as more people sought online revenue streams during the pandemic. In 2020, she earned $127,000 from flipping 13 websites and brokering sales for 50 more sites, documents reviewed by Insider verified.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-business-flipping-websites-blog-broker-2021-3\">Read more about how Clarke built her website-flipping business.&#160;</a></em></p><p>&#160;</p>\n\t3. Instagram side hustle\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6039430605ddb100195f6787?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PK.JPG\" height=\"1067\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Today, Plant Kween has 311,000 followers and collaborates with brands like Spotify on curated content.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Christopher Griffin)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Christopher Griffin's Instagram account, which is under the moniker&#160;<a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/plantkween/?hl=en\">Plant Kween</a>, is devoted to pictures of the 200 plants living in their Brooklyn apartment, tips on caring for the greenery, and useful botanical knowledge.&#160;</p><p>They started the account in winter 2016 &#8212; as a means of learning about something new after graduate school &#8212; grew it steadily to 311,000 followers and collaborates with brands like Spotify on curated content.</p><p>Griffin couldn't disclose what they earn with the music-streaming service but a partnership with the <a href=\"https://tonle.com/collections/plant-kween-x-tonle-collection\">fashion line Tonle</a>, that sold $42,000 of non-binary clothing last year, netted them around $8,400, according to Tonle.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/plant-kween-how-to-start-instagram-account-land-partnerships-2021-2\">Read more about how Griffin built their Instagram side-hustle.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t4. Urban farm\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/602e779331eb0600197c3f06?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joanna Bassi\" height=\"1067\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Here’s how Joanna Bassi built an urban farm from scratch and her advice for fellow farming entrepreneurs, including how to pivot during a pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Joanna Bassi)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Joanna Bassi turned her unused backyard &#8212; measuring 150 feet by 75 feet &#8212; into an <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-urban-farm-yard-sell-restaurants-host-events-2021-2\">urban farm that could grow fresh produce</a> for local establishments.</p><p>Bassi started from the ground up in January 2018, and by the following year, she netted nearly $6,000 in revenue from selling at farmers markets and local restaurants, according to documents viewed by Insider.&#160;</p><p>In 2020, the pandemic temporarily closed Bassi's restaurant clients and hurt business. She still managed to book nearly $7,000 by creating new revenue streams.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-urban-farm-yard-sell-restaurants-host-events-2021-2\">Read more about how Bassi built her urban farming business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t5. Pet care and dog-walking business\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60771805420615001817575a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"dog tricks\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can teach your dog to shake your hand with a simple command.\n<p class=\"copyright\">vgajic/ Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Jill Nelson took over her friend's 15-year-old dog walking and pet sitting startup&#160;<a href=\"http://hotdiggitypetsitting.com/\">Hot Diggity</a> in 2015. Since then, she's scaled the Seattle office, opened a Vancouver location, and purchased Hot Diggity's Portland, Oregon, outpost.&#160;</p><p>Revenue for Hot Diggity's three locations sank between 2019 to 2020 &#8212; Portland had the most drastic decline, falling from $2.1 million to $986,000, according to documents verified by Insider &#8212; but Nelson said the company weathered the storm and is already seeing an increase in bookings.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-dog-walking-pet-care-business-from-scratch-2021-4\">Read more about how Nelson built her dog-walking and pet care business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t6. Hand-dyed yarn business\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604b9db0fea127001886a747?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Jake 1\" height=\"601\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Kenyon shared his advice for launching a business around your passion, building community support, and how he stands out in a crowded market.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Jake Kenyon)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In January, Jake Kenyon left his full-time job as a speech pathologist to pursue his side hustle: A <a href=\"https://kenyarn.com/pages/meet-the-maker\">hand-dyed yarn business called Kenyarn</a>. The pandemic drove many consumers to crafts, like knitting and crocheting, which helped boost Kenyon's business.</p><p>Kenyarn's gross sales jumped from $33,000 in 2019 to $125,000 last year, and he's on track to surpass that figure this year, according to documents viewed by Insider.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-side-hustle-business-earn-6-figures-hand-dyed-yarn\">Read more about how Kenyon built his hand-dyed yarn business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t7. Food truck\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608744ce0da8f400180339b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"food truck\" height=\"683\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Alessio Lacco and Sofia Arango opened a pizza-focused food truck, tapping Lacco’s 15-year background making Neapolitan pies and the truck he already owned.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Atlanta Pizza Truck)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Alessio Lacco and Sofia Arango launched <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-a-food-truck-and-find-your-customers-2021-3\">Atlanta Pizza Truck</a>&#160;last August as way to make money during the pandemic.</p><p>In its first five months of business, the couple booked $82,000 in sales, according to documents reviewed by Insider. In the first three months of 2021, they netted $53,000 in sales and believe they are on track to at least double sales from 2020.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-a-food-truck-and-find-your-customers-2021-3\">Read more about how Lacco and Arango built their food truck business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t8. Hair care business\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087fc733f0560001881c360?format=jpeg\" alt=\"607494833e3fe7001882a2b7\" height=\"750\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Stormi Steele\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Stormi Steele)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Stormi Steele used to make hair care products in her kitchen while working in salon in 2012. She'd mix over-the-counter ingredients, such as flaxseed oil and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/what-is-vitamin-e-good-for\">vitamin E</a>, in an effort to create a solution that would help her hair grow.&#160;</p><p>Today, Steele is the founder of Canvas Beauty Brand, which booked nearly $20 million in revenue last year.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-hair-care-business-stormi-steele-2021-4\">Read more about how Steele built her hair-care business.&#160;</a></em></p><p>&#160;</p>\n\t9. Pop-up bakery\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608745080da8f400180339b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"abby love\" height=\"525\" width=\"700\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>On January 21, Abby Love opened her first bakery, Abby Jane Bakeshop, in Dripping Springs, Texas.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Abby Love)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>When the opening of Abby Love's bakery was delayed due to the pandemic, she launched <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-open-pop-up-bakery-food-business-2021-1\">10 pop-up bakeries</a> around Dripping Springs, Texas to keep her brand alive, attract new customers, and boost revenue.</p><p>Love partnered with local businesses for her pop-ups, choosing establishments that didn't sell baked goods and attracted the kind of customers who would appreciate her locally-sourced ingredients.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-open-pop-up-bakery-food-business-2021-1\">Read more about how Love built her pop-up bakery business.</a> </em></p>\n\t10. Craft brewery business\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608745da3f0560001881c2bc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chris and Avery_HTB_LittlePondDigital\" height=\"600\" width=\"799\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Christophe Gagne and Avery Schwenk are the cofounders of Hermit Thrush, a Brattleboro, Vermont-based brewery that exclusively makes sour beers.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Little Pond Digital)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Christophe Gagne and Avery Schwenk are the cofounders of Hermit Thrush, a 7-year-old Brattleboro, Vermont-based brewery that exclusively makes sour beers.&#160;</p><p>Today the brewery has 21 taps and its canned varieties are sold in 9 states, plus DC. The brewery's most popular concoction, Party Jam, is a collection of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.hermitthrushbrewery.com/shop\">fruit-forward sours</a>&#160;that typically sells for $19.99 on the company's website. What's more, Hermit Thrush booked $1.5 million in revenue last year, according to documents viewed by Insider.&#160;</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-turn-your-home-brew-into-brewery-6-months-2021-2\">Read more about how Gagne and Schwenk built their craft brew business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t11. Furniture maker\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087fcdf0da8f40018033a73?format=jpeg\" alt=\"furniture\" height=\"1000\" width=\"1333\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Matthew Nafranowicz, a master craftsman, started doing upholstery work more than two decades ago.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of The Straight Thread Co.)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In 2002, Matthew Nafranowicz opened his furniture upholstery storefront, The Straight Thread, in Madison, Wisconsin.&#160;</p><p>Furniture upholstery represents an estimated&#160;<a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/791781/upholstery-market-size-in-the-us/\">$1 billion market</a>&#160;in the US, and government data shows it employs roughly&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/oes/2018/may/oes516093.htm\">30,000 people</a>.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-furniture-repair-business-from-scratch-2021-2\">Read more about how Nafranowicz built his furniture upholstery business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n\t12. Self-published author\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608858273f0560001881c556?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sally\" height=\"525\" width=\"700\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">(Courtesy of Sally Miller)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Sally-Miller/e/B017HTJ65Q/ref=dp_byline_cont_pop_ebooks_1?tag=bisafetynet2-20\">Sally Miller</a> is a self-published author who's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-self-publish-amazon-make-extra-income-writing-2021-2\">written and co-authored 15 books</a> on Amazon. She made $9,000 in royalties in January, her highest amount to date, according to documents viewed by Insider.&#160;</p><p>\"It meets my two criteria, which is that I'm making money and doing something I really enjoy,\" said Miller, who built a following through her subject matter, which focuses on how people can make money through various entrepreneurial ventures, like Airbnb and ghostwriting.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-self-publish-amazon-make-extra-income-writing-2021-2\">Read more about how Miller built her self-publishing business.&#160;</a></em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-start-a-business-writing-farming-food-truck-more-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Chinese embassy deletes tweet of an antisemitic meme popular with Holocaust deniers and white supremacists","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/chinese-embassy-in-japan-deletes-antisemitic-meme-posted-on-twitter-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608e9e70f22c6b00185db271?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chinese embassy antisemitic tweet\" height=\"440\" width=\"587\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Chinese Embassy in Japan tweeted and deleted a meme popular with Holocaust deniers.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Twitter</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Chinese Embassy in Japan tweeted an image of the grim reaper wielding a scythe with an Israeli flag on it.</li>\n<li>The meme is popular with prominent Holocaust deniers.</li>\n<li>The embassy deleted the tweet after requests from two Israeli politicians, The Jerusalem Post said.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Chinese Embassy in Japan tweeted and then deleted an antisemitic and anti-US meme after Israeli officials reached out, according to <a href=\"https://www.jpost.com/diaspora/antisemitism/chinese-embassy-tweets-and-deletes-antisemitic-cartoon-666973\">The Jerusalem Post.</a></p><p>The tweet, posted on Thursday night, featured a cartoon image of a grim reaper wearing an American flag. The reaper appeared to be knocking on a door labeled &#39;Egypt&#39;  and to have left a trail of blood behind. The other doors in the image are labeled Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran, Libya, and Syria.</p><p>On the reaper&#39;s scythe was an Israeli flag with a Jewish Star of David centered. &#34;If the United States brought &#39;democracy,&#39; it would be like this,&#34; the caption read in Japanese.</p><p>The cartoon has been featured on several extremist websites and is popular with white supremacists and Holocaust deniers, the Jewish journal <a href=\"https://www.algemeiner.com/2020/05/26/white-supremacist-origin-of-antisemitic-anti-us-cartoon-promoted-by-chinese-embassy-in-paris-exposed/\">Algemeiner</a> reported.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/henry-kissenger-interview-politics-after-pandemic-china-europe-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">INTERVIEW: Henry Kissinger on the political consequences of the pandemic, China&#39;s rise, and the future of the European Union</a></em></p><p>On social media, people criticized the &#34;antisemitic&#34; post.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Tommy  (@TSmithRV) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388062718767284224?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 30, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Xy5Z89🇩🇪🇪🇺  (@Xy5Z89) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388081731622866947?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 30, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>But it was only deleted after interventions from high-profile Israeli politicians.</p><p>Israel&#39;s ambassador to Japan, Yaffa Ben-Ari, contacted his Chinese counterpart to point out that the image is offensive, The Jerusalem Post reported. The Chinese ambassador replied that he was unaware that Israel was featured in the image, the paper said.</p><p>Israel&#39;s Foreign Ministry Deputy Director-General for Asia and the Pacific, Gilad Cohen, also contacted the embassy to complain.</p><p>The tweet was deleted within the hour, The Jerusalem Post said.</p><p>The same image was posted by the Chinese Embassy in Paris last year, the Algemeiner reported.</p><p>It has also been featured on the websites of high-profile Holocaust deniers, according to French monitoring organization <a href=\"https://twitter.com/conspiration/status/1264662135805816834\">Conspiracy Watch</a>.</p><p>The Chinese Embassy in Japan has not publicly addressed the tweet. It did not immediately respond to Insider&#39;s request for comment.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a owners","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/watch-manchester-utd-fans-protest-us-owners-storm-old-trafford-pitch-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608eb4ecf22c6b00185db290?format=jpeg\" alt=\"fans manchester united protest storm\" height=\"2685\" width=\"3580\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Fans protest Manchester United&#39;s Glazer ownership outside the stadium prior to invading the pitch.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Manchester United fans have stormed the pitch at Old Trafford.</li>\n<li>The furious supporters are demanding new ownership following the club&#39;s failed bid to join the European Super League.</li>\n<li>Manchester United is due to play Liverpool later this afternoon.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Manchester United fans have invaded the Old Trafford pitch to protest against the club&#39;s American ownership.</p><p>About 200 individuals are believed to have gained access to the pitch via the Munich Tunnel after pushing down barriers, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2021/may/02/manchester-united-fans-invade-old-trafford-pitch-during-glazer-out-protests\">The Guardian</a> reported.</p><p>Supporters are demanding change at the top of the club, which is under the control of the Glazer family, following the failed bid to join the controversial and now-defunct European Super League.</p><p>Billionaire co-chairman <a href=\"https://www.manutd.com/en/news/detail/joel-glazer-writes-open-letter-to-man-utd-supporters-april-2021\">Joel Glazer apologized</a> to supporters on April 21 for signing up to the breakaway project but many United fans are not placated. Some carried placards at the protest reading &#34;apology not accepted&#34; and others chanted &#34;Glazers out.&#34; </p><p>Videos from the pitch invasion show supporters shooting flares.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-The Away Fans Videos  (@TheAwayFansVids) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388845927121801217?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 2, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Barstool Sports  (@barstoolsports) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1388846458640740358?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 2, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Speaking ahead of the protest, United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said: &#34;It&#39;s important that the fans&#39; views are listened to and we communicate better. My job is to focus on the football side and that we have the best possible team.</p><p>&#34;As I&#39;ve said before I&#39;ve been backed, I&#39;ve had great support from the club and the owners and I&#39;m sure I will get the backing again to go one step further. When the protests are on, it&#39;s important they go in a good fashion and that we keep it peaceful.&#34;</p><p>The club is due to play Liverpool later this afternoon but the game has been delayed by the protest. The Premier League was hopeful that the game would still kick off at 4.30 pm, according to the <a href=\"https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/manchester-united-glazer-protest-live-20509557\">Manchester Evening News</a>. </p><p> </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original Munger.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SCOTT MORGAN/REUTERS</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Charlie Munger said bitcoin&#39;s development and rise has been &#34;contrary to the accepting bitcoin as payment.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Berkshire Hathaway&#39;s Warren Buffett and his right-hand man, Charlie Munger, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/warren-buffett-charlie-munger-berkshire-hathaway-annual-meeting-live-updates-2021-5-1030373616?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">are no fans of cryptocurrency,</a> but on Saturday Munger doubled down on his critique of bitcoin.</p><p>&#34;Of course I hate the bitcoin success,&#34; Munger said in response to a question during <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-slams-spacs-robinhood-market-speculation-berkshire-hathaway-meeting-2021-5-1030373638\">Berkshire&#39;s annual shareholders&#39; event. </a>&#34;I don&#39;t welcome a currency that&#39;s so useful to kidnappers and extortionists, nor do I like just shoveling out a few extra billions and billions of dollars to somebody who just invented a new financial product out of thin air.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I think I should say modestly that I think the whole damned development is disgusting and contrary to the interests of civilization,&#34; he added. </p><p>Buffett, who has previously called cryptocurrencies, &#34;worthless,&#34; and &#34;risky&#34;  was more evasive.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;ve probably got hundreds of thousands of people watching this that own bitcoin, and we&#39;ve got two people short,&#34; Buffett said. &#34;Angering the former group to make a couple of people happy wouldn&#39;t be worth it,&#34; he said.</p><p>The pointed remarks come during a headline-grabbing year for cryptocurrencies. </p><p>Bitcoin, the world&#39;s largest cryptocurrency, broke consecutive records above the $63,000-level before tumbling below $50,000 last month. It has regained some of its value as it struggles to define its utility from being a <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/elon-musk-tesla-bitcoin-holdings-sold-good-cash-alternative-personal-2021-4-1030350083?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">potential currency</a> to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/bitcoin-vs-gold-experts-cryptocurrency-precious-metals-analysis-2021-2-1030103905?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a store of value</a>, among others.</p><p>Despite the volatility, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-companies-accepting-bitcoin-cryptocurrency-paypal-starbucks-2021-4\">a number of companies and investors</a> jumped in on the action. In February, Elon Musk <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-tweets-you-can-buy-a-tesla-with-bitcoin-2021-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"781f03244f46782ae88c6eed16eb9a32\">announced</a> that Tesla would accept bitcoin as a form of payment for all models of its cars in the US.</p><p>Yum Brands, which operates KFC, Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, and The Habit Burger Grill, also began accepting cryptocurrencies. So too did Xbox and PayPal. Meanwhile, Twitter&#39;s CEO and founder, Jack Dorsey, teamed up with Jay-Z for a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-ceo-dorsey-partners-with-jay-z-on-bitcoin-endowment-2021-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"36b4335d075c65751f5cfb67f8c84bec\">bitcoin endowment</a> in India and Africa.</p><p>Coinbase, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the US, listed on the Nasdaq in April. After a <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/coinbase-stock-price-ipo-direct-listing-trading-debut-cryptocurrency-platform-2021-4-1030304997?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">volatile first trading day,</a> it boasted a valuation on a fully diluted basis of about $86 billion by the end of the day.</p><p>But Munger and Buffett aren&#39;t alone in their hesitation about crypto. </p><p>Peter Schiff, Euro Pacific Capital&#39;s chief economist and global strategist, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/bitcoin-critic-peter-schiff-blasts-cryptocurrency-federal-government-us-dollar-2021-4-1030365316\">last week called bitcoin &#34;worthless.&#34;</a></p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t think these bitcoin collections are going to be worth anything when the music stops. People have told me that when the bubble burst in Beanie Babies, they were able to use them to insulate their homes,&#34; he said.</p><p>He added: &#34;They could shove them in between the walls, and they made good insulation. You can&#39;t do anything with a bitcoin. Once nobody wants your bitcoin, it&#39;s completely worthless.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/berkshire-hathaway-charlie-munger-doubled-down-bitcoin-criticism-disgusting-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2021 13:48:37 (Victoria Cavaliere )","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608ea60f34af8d001859a759?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn59@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-18-579_9018902c6d3be5ad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nz8GKrkfClw:xWaIs_gnTnE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn49@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-29-686_f166fd15797794b0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nz8GKrkfClw:xWaIs_gnTnE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn99@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-25-871_337cdb42dee68332.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nz8GKrkfClw:xWaIs_gnTnE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn84@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-167_48aa18a51f4c5c6e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nz8GKrkfClw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn57@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-23-363_23eb3c35a07c9cb2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238430},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Twitter will reportedly launch an ad campaign to help local journalists and news outlets gain more followers on the platform","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-launching-ads-in-support-of-local-journalism-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608edbccf22c6b00185db2b9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Twitter HQ in San Francisco\" height=\"1441\" width=\"2883\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Twitter&#39;s San Francisco headquarters.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Chiu/AP Photos</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Twitter announced an ad campaign in support of local journalists and their work.</li>\n<li>According to <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/twitter-national-campaign-local-news-fce2f4e9-d539-4e7b-8bdd-3aaa6f585fba.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter=twitter\">Axios</a>, Twitter will take out 28 full-page ads in newspapers across the US.</li>\n<li>The ads will point people to Twitter Lists of local reporters created the newspapers and Twitter.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Twitter will take out advertisements in 28 local newspapers across the US to encourage readers to support local journalists and news outlets, <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/twitter-national-campaign-local-news-fce2f4e9-d539-4e7b-8bdd-3aaa6f585fba.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter=twitter\">Axios</a> first reported.</p><p>The ads will begin appearing Monday in 28 newspapers across the US, including USA Today and the McClatchy networks of local newspapers. The Cincinnati Enquirer, the Miami Herald, the Detroit Free Press, and the Kansas City Star, are among the local papers that will run the ad, according to the Axios report, published Sunday.</p><p>&#34;Local journalists are so incredibly important to the conversation on Twitter,&#34; Niketa Patel, the head of print and digital news partnerships at Twitter, told Axios. &#34;We&#39;re viewing this as a way of ensuring that Twitter is giving local journalists a national spotlight.&#34;</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/googles-resistance-to-going-fully-remote-is-frustrating-employees-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">Google&#39;s push to bring employees back to offices in September is frustrating some employees who say they&#39;ll quit if they can&#39;t be remote forever</a></em></p><p>The advertisements will point users toward public Twitter Lists - the social-media platform&#39;s feature that allows users to create lists of profiles and publicly share them - that feature local reporters and newspapers, according to Axios. The advertisements will also run on the local papers&#39; websites.</p><p>Twitter will also promote the hashtag &#34;FollowLocalJournalists&#34; and ask national journalists with large followings and other prominent journalism advocacy organizations to use it to share stories authored by local journalists and published at local outlets.</p><p>The company will also host several <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/11/17/21570150/twitter-spaces-clubhouse-voice-rooms-testing\">Twitter Spaces</a> - the company&#39;s live audio feature that aims to rival the live audio platform Clubhouse - with journalists from around the world from countries that include India, Thailand, and Brazil, according to the report.</p><p>&#34;We think these two products in particular are a powerful part of the way journalists can have great conversations on Twitter and build a following,&#34; Patel told Axios of Twitter&#39;s List and Spaces features. </p><p>The campaign will continue for the rest of the year, Twitter said, according to the report. </p><p>The news industry, and in particular already struggling local news outlets, have been hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic, as the <a href=\"https://www.cjr.org/business_of_news/journalism-crisis-in-2020.php\">Columbia Journalism Review</a> noted last year.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-launching-ads-in-support-of-local-journalism-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=a1ASl-X3k08:udPoY2gV2CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=a1ASl-X3k08:udPoY2gV2CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/a1ASl-X3k08\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 17:35:16 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608edbc434af8d001859a792?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7d4b3680f85262df51a1fd2ca5d1bbde","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn2@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-21-573_ac731f5a51d738c5.webp","destWidth":2637,"destHeight":1978,"sourceBytes":77940,"destBytes":77940,"author":"insider@insider.com (Connor Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608edbccf22c6b00185db2b9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn20@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-26-013_7561092dc3afc7db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=a1ASl-X3k08:udPoY2gV2CE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn33@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-25-266_372c55ce2f09d2cd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=a1ASl-X3k08:udPoY2gV2CE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn71@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-320_9af89930b5b08c5e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=a1ASl-X3k08:udPoY2gV2CE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn79@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-25-007_6b7c7e8883e7b2b2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/a1ASl-X3k08":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn23@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-23-660_864963ef9e49025c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238427},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"America hasn't addressed its brutal gun violence crisis because of cowardly, callous leadership. It's time for someone to be courageous.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-many-gun-deaths-before-congress-does-something-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608d91e5f22c6b00185db21b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"moms demand acton gun violence protest\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Moms Demand Action hosted a Recess Rally and community gathering at Foley Square to honor the victims of gun violence\n<p class=\"copyright\">Erik McGregor/LightRocket/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The US has been plagued by an epidemic of gun violence, and deaths have been soaring recently.</li>\n<li>Despite this our political leaders have done nothing substantial to curb the decades-long problem.</li>\n<li>It&#39;s time for Joe Biden and the Democrats to be courageous and tackle gun safety once and for all.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Two months ago <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-democrats-must-tackle-gun-violence-crisis-before-too-late-2021-2\">my column</a> focused on the need to take action to address America&#39;s gun crisis. I was worried mass shootings would speed up as the COVID pandemic slowed down. But none of us could have imagined how tragic the following weeks would be. </p><p>There is not enough room in this column to do justice to the <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/16/us/mass-shootings-45-one-month/index.html\">45 mass shootings</a> we have experienced in the United States over the past six weeks. This outbreak of violence <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/03/17/us/shooting-atlanta-acworth\">started in Atlanta</a> and the shootings have not abated since then. <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/04/16/us/indianapolis-fedex-shooting\">Eight people</a>, including four members of the Sikh community, were killed in Indianapolis on April 15. On April 6, a <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/phillip-adams-kills-5-then-himself-south-carolina-aaf71f2618f139ab3781592634c8e37c\">respected community doctor and his family were killed</a> in South Carolina. On March 26, <a href=\"https://www.denverpost.com/2021/03/27/boulder-shooting-king-soopers-58-minutes-how-unfolded/\">10 people</a> were murdered while grocery shopping in Boulder, Colorado. The list goes on, and on, and on. </p><p>So far, our lawmakers have provided the usual pablum. The Republicans have, as usual, offered their <a href=\"https://twitter.com/RepBoebert/status/1374118705701941248?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1374118705701941248%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.huffpost.com%2Fentry%2Flauren-boebert-boulder-colorado-mass-shooting_n_6059968bc5b6bd95117fbc0fbc0f\">thoughts and prayers</a>, while offering nothing substantive besides <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/24/democrats-press-national-gun-control-republican-states-expand-firearm-access/6966823002/\">making it easier to obtain a gun.</a> While Democrats from various states have proposed and <a href=\"https://www.denverpost.com/2021/04/19/colorado-gun-bills-safe-storage-lost-or-stolen-guns-bills-signed-boulder/\">even passed</a> gun control measures in the wake of these shootings, and Joe Biden has <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/07/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-announces-initial-actions-to-address-the-gun-violence-public-health-epidemic/\">released a list of proposals</a> to help curb the violence, nothing has been done to truly end the epidemic of gun deaths ravaging this country. </p><p>What level of tragedy would finally force this country to make real change?</p><h2><strong>What&#39;s it going to take?</strong></h2><p>Since the first modern mass shooting at Columbine High School, the US has failed to move in a substantial way on gun safety. While there have been <a href=\"https://www.denverpost.com/2019/04/14/columbine-high-school-shooting-gun-control/\">red flag laws passed</a> in some (mostly Democratic) states, just as many states have loosened their firearm laws to allow for open and concealed carry. Federal legislation has <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2019/4/19/18412627/columbine-anniversary-gun-control-mass-shootings\">gone nowhere</a>, and the Supreme Court <a href=\"https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/analysis-opinion/what-supreme-courts-latest-second-amendment-ruling-means-future-cases\">has ruled in the District of Columbia vs. Heller</a> that Americans have a fundamental right to possess firearms. </p><p>We&#39;ve had Newtown, Parkland, and many others - anyone of which should&#39;ve spurred us into action. We have had <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2019/07/us/ten-years-of-school-shootings-trnd/\">180 shootings in schools alone over the past 10 years</a>, with 356 victims who all had long and happy lives ahead of them. Yet we have done nothing. And there is no reason for hope that the Supreme Court will make our children any safer as it pledges to take on <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/26/politics/supreme-court-second-amendment-case/index.html\">a new Second Amendment case.</a></p><h2><strong>The opportunity of crisis</strong></h2><p>As people across the US have started to get vaccinated against COVID, the veneer of protection against gun deaths is fading and there is no vaccine-like solution on the horizon.</p><p>And much like misinformation that drove up the case and death toll during the pandemic, the increase in mass shootings and corresponding inaction of Congress tie directly back to the rise of the extreme right media on cable and social media.</p><p>Tucker Carlson <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/opinion/tucker-carlson-biden-gun-control-disarm-trump-voters\">claimed that Biden wants to take guns away from law-abiding citizens</a>, which is a claim more at home at a Republican rally than a purported news site. The GOP&#39;s official position is that <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/23/politics/background-checks-republican-resistance/index.html\">background checks are outrageous</a> and evil, despite <a href=\"https://morningconsult.com/2021/03/10/house-gun-legislation-background-checks-polling/\">84% percent of Americans supporting them</a>. There is hardly an issue in 2021 that most Americans agree on, but expanded background checks is one of them. Yet Republicans continue to stand in the way. </p><p>Other countries don&#39;t have the same problem. After a horrific mass shooting in 1996, <a href=\"https://fortune.com/2018/02/20/australia-gun-control-success/\">Australia outlawed assault-style weapons</a>. Despite what Republicans might have you believe, Australia has not turned into a despotic dictatorship over the intervening 25 years. In fact, most every other country on Earth has fewer guns and <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2019/08/05/743579605/how-the-u-s-compares-to-other-countries-in-deaths-from-gun-violence\">fewer gun deaths</a> than the United States.</p><h2><strong>Now or never </strong></h2><p>President Joe Biden has juggled a number of crises in his short time in office, but he has not prioritized gun safety. He <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/04/28/joe-biden-urge-action-gun-bills-address-congress/4865622001/\">urged Congress</a> to reinstate a ban on assault weapons and high capacity magazines, which like background checks is very <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/story/2019/08/07/poll-most-voters-support-assault-weapons-ban-1452586\">popular with voters.</a> Perhaps he can come up with a different, uniquely American solution to this uniquely American problem. </p><p>It is understandable that Joe Biden doesn&#39;t want to lose his frighteningly narrow majorities in Congress, but his party must take action now while they have the opportunity to get it done. The Democrats have the ideas, they have the public&#39;s support, and they have numbers. The only thing, it would seem, that they are missing is the political will to make a change. </p><p>After a full year of one kind of devastating tragedy, we have been faced with a month of another. One that in some ways feels more tangible than a virus. In the 100 days since Biden&#39;s inauguration, he has shown he is up to the task of fighting the invisible killer that has been plaguing America for the past year. Now he must step up and fight the killer that has damaged and taken the lives of thousands of Americans for the past 30.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-many-gun-deaths-before-congress-does-something-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2021 13:34:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608d91cdf22c6b00185db21a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"6c9483a14d56699c640c4a1232a0c3af","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn41@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-21-733_0c04d17b1c88d010.webp","destWidth":2276,"destHeight":1707,"sourceBytes":315598,"destBytes":315598,"author":"insider@insider.com (Michael Gordon)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608d91e5f22c6b00185db21b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn87@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-27-334_ec338f7760c3f672.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iJvrSrdcgag:0lWFmIwRvCY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-073_036a32cf877e1f9b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iJvrSrdcgag:0lWFmIwRvCY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn43@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-22-690_264afe95950ccc08.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iJvrSrdcgag:0lWFmIwRvCY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn16@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-966_64b56a1db255faae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/iJvrSrdcgag":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn45@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-27-834_84c8e8e32298fdd0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238431},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"I tried Walmart and Target's competing grocery pickup services, and Walmart is by far the better option for weekly shopping trips","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/walmart-vs-target-grocery-pickup-apps-walmart-wins-2021-5","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c267e47bd77305fd15468cf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"775\" width=\"1033\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption> \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>I tried Target's grocery pickup service to compare it to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-its-like-to-use-walmart-grocery-review-2021-4\">Walmart's version.</a></li> \n <li>Walmart is better equipped for large shopping trips, while Target could replace a last-minute trip.</li> \n <li>Grocery delivery and pickup services have exploded over the last year.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n  Curbside pickup has boomed in the year since COVID-19 made customers less comfortable going inside of stores. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608717953f0560001881c1c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"774\" width=\"1032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Experts predict that the shift to online grocery delivery will continue even as the pandemic subsides, and COVID-19 advanced the industry several years. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c642ae3342cca397c68ffe5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"760\" width=\"1013\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> I've been doing curbside pickup at Walmart since the summer using Walmart's app, and I think it's the best way to shop for groceries. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5be48985b73c28744a774654?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"1794\" width=\"2392\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption>\n    eople talk outside a Wal-Mart Pickup-Grocery test store in Bentonville, Arkansas, June 4, 2015. \n    <p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Rick Wilking</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The Walmart app prompts you to select the closest location for pickup, or enter your address for delivery. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d02a44f454001920726e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart Grocery pickup app\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> You select a one-hour time slot, at least one day in advance but up to more than a week in the future. There's a specific time just for at-risk customers. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d08b44f4540019207270?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart Grocery pickup app\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Walmart's app is centered around groceries and divides them by category, which makes going through a list of what I need easy. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60871faf0da8f40018033905?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> It's easy to add items to your order and adjust quantities quickly. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087201c0da8f4001803390c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Once your order is created, you have until about midnight the night before to continue adding to your list. For me, this is one of the most useful features, because I almost always realize we need something else before it's actually time to pick up groceries. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d24844f4540019207280?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Because groceries are ordered a few days in advance, sometimes the exact brand of an item isn't available on pickup day. Walmart suggests a substitution and gives the chance to approve it. I've always had good luck with this. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d43674da0300181e2300?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup app\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> When the order is ready, Walmart sends a text alert and asks you to check in so a worker is ready to bring it out when you arrive. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d44d44f4540019207297?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup app\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> A side area of the parking lot was marked for grocery pickup. When you pull into a spot the app knows you've arrived and prompts you to enter your spot number and color of your car. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087229d3f0560001881c23b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Walmart shoppers use small carts to pull crates with grocery orders. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d4ee74da0300181e2308?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"1879\" width=\"2505\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> My Walmart has about ten spots, and they're occasionally full when I show up to get my order. While I've sometimes had to wait, it's still much faster than I shop in-store. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d4aa74da0300181e2306?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Masked shoppers come up to the driver's window to double-check the name on the order with a handheld tablet that they carry. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d51074da0300181e230a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"2268\" width=\"3023\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Once they've confirmed that you're the right customer, a worker loads groceries into the trunk. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608725240da8f4001803393d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"2757\" width=\"3676\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Shoppers will usually bag groceries in your reusable bags if you bring them, but I usually just ask them to load groceries into my trunk to save time and bag them myself at home. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6079d54e74da0300181e230c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> I also tried Target's version of the same service to see which is better. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c741ff90d15f564036380f2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target\" height=\"2141\" width=\"2854\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Getty/Boston Globe</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target calls their equivalent service \"Drive Up,\" and it's free with no minimum order, compared to Walmart's $35 minimum. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60871c880da8f400180338e0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target orders are ready in two hours, so this service can be more of a last-minute shopping trip with less planning required than a Walmart order. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608725970da8f40018033940?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target divides products into nearly 20 different categories, with grocery as only one of them. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60871e8b3f0560001881c1ff?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Groceries are further categorized into produce, meat, and other groups that make finding them easier, although I found it took more time to find what I needed than on Walmart's app. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608725c73f0560001881c24e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target's app seems more oriented around showing coupons and deals in the store, rather than suggesting staples I'd need to buy. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608726133f0560001881c24f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The Target app also offers more information about each individual item, including reviews and where it is located in the nearest store. Walmart's app is more minimalist, with bare-bones information about items. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608726790da8f40018033944?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> One of my frustrations with Target was selecting an item only to find out it was out of stock at my store. Walmart's app makes it clearer when an item isn't available without having to click on it and go to a separate page. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608726c40da8f40018033948?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pickup\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> When it's time to check out, Target gives a summary of all your savings and coupons. It's much easier to use coupons in Target's app compared to Walmart. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087272a0da8f4001803394c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> My order was ready in about an hour, which was very convenient. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608727740da8f4001803394e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The pickup process was almost identical to Walmart's. I put my car type and color in the app and told Target when I arrived. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608727980da8f4001803394f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target had a few clever additions I liked that I'd like to see Walmart implement. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608727c83f0560001881c259?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> For example, the app asks you to choose where you'd like your bags. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6087282a0da8f40018033953?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target drive up grocery\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Target</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The other really smart feature on Target's app is&nbsp;giving each order a unique code, which can be shown to the employee through the window. This does away with the small amount of face-to-face contact in Walmart's pickup system. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872a683f0560001881c271?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"620\" width=\"827\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Like Walmart, Target has a few designated parking spots for pickup. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872ac53f0560001881c272?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> At my Target, the spaces are near the entrance to the store, while at Walmart they're over on the side and workers have a separate store entrance. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608728cb3f0560001881c265?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target's pickup was definitely faster than Walmart's, both in the time between ordering and picking it and how quickly the worker put it in my car from the time we arrived. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872bd83f0560001881c279?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Despite that, I still prefer Walmart and will continue to use that service over Target. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ffdf8e1f3df630018cc16b6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"683\" width=\"910\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Yichuan Cao/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Walmart's pickup is more conducive to the way I order groceries: I can set an order up a few days in advance and add to it as I realize things I need. My grocery order is pretty similar week to week, so this works well. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872c540da8f4001803396a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"661\" width=\"881\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Walmart</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target's service might be more useful as a last-minute stop on the way home from work to pick up ingredients for dinner, rather than a replacement of a weekly grocery trip. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872cb33f0560001881c27c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"2649\" width=\"3532\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Walmart also has better prices and a wider selection, including in its Great Value store brand. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872cfd3f0560001881c280?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart grocery pickup\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Target's app is just not as centered on groceries as Walmart's, and it makes the shopping experience more difficult and tedious. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60872d270da8f40018033970?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target grocery pick up\" height=\"2994\" width=\"3992\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Do you have a story to share about a retail or restaurant chain? Email this reporter at&nbsp;<a href=\"mailto:mmeisenzahl@businessinsider.com\">mmeisenzahl@businessinsider.com</a>.</em></p> \n</div>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"The Biden Administration continues the White House's long history of personalizing everything, from pens to cookies to shovels","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/brief-history-personalized-white-house-items-candies-shovels-president-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608eac04f22c6b00185db289?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Jill Biden&#39;s Air Force One Jacket\" height=\"1067\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>First Lady Jill Biden’s Air Force One embroidered jacket\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/51130183873/\" target=\"_blank\">Official White House Photo by Cameron Smith via Flickr</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Joe Biden finally got his own M&#38;Ms, marking a tradition that dates back to the Reagan era.</li>\n<li>It&#39;s far from the only branded perk that the president (and vice-president) are gifted with.</li>\n<li>Insider rounded up other personalized presidential items spotted by photographers. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Leadership in Washington flips from red to blue every so often, but one thing always seems to remain the same: a dedication to personalization.</p><p>Many of the items have been useful, like the White House cocktail napkin one of Insider&#39;s reporters kept as a souvenir from President Barack Obama&#39;s administration. Here are a few other personalized presidential items spotted by photographers. </p><h2><strong>Pens featuring President Joe Biden&#39;s signature were ready for use on his first full day in office. </strong></h2><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ede1cf22c6b00185db2bf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joe Biden Pens\" height=\"2657\" width=\"3543\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Complete with a presidential seal.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Brandon/AP Photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><h2><strong>Here&#39;s a behind-the-scenes shot of photojournalists capturing the pens.</strong></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ede7f34af8d001859a796?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Photojournalists Shooting Biden Pens\" height=\"2674\" width=\"3566\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Shooting Biden&#39;s pens.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Brandon/AP Photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>In March, the White House slapped its seal on shamrock cookies for visitors to the Outer Oval Office for St. Patrick&#39;s day.</strong></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ede8ff22c6b00185db2c1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Shamrock Cookies at the White House\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>St. Patrick&#39;s Day cookies at the White House.\n<p class=\"copyright\">White House/Adam Schultz</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>This week, M&#38;Ms arrived on Air Force One</strong></h2><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Ashley Williams  (@ashwilliams46) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1387762775758446599?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 29, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>It&#39;s a longstanding tradition: presidential M&#38;Ms were first created in 1988 for Ronald Reagan - with Bill Clinton later starting the tradition of adding the leader&#39;s signature.</p><p>As noted by Ashley Williams, the deputy director of Oval Office operations, Biden didn&#39;t have his own M&#38;Ms at the beginning of his presidency, although last month, Air Force One got special transitional M&#38;Ms with no signature. But now Biden can rest easy.</p><p>Williams posted a photo on Twitter of the candies arranged in the shape of a &#34;100,&#34; to mark Biden&#39;s 100 days in office. The Air Force One M&#38;Ms have long been a favorite among reporters, as <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-us-canada-36109209\">BBC News</a> pointed out.</p><h2><strong>The personalization extends beyond the Oval Office. Here, Vice President Kamala Harris greets her husband, Second Gentleman Doug Emhoff, with a coffee cup bearing the Presidential Seal between them.</strong></h2><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608edf8c34af8d001859a799?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kamala harris doug emhoff\" height=\"682\" width=\"911\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Kamala Harris, Doug Emhoff, and a personalized coffee cup.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Official White House Photo by Lawrence Jackson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><h2><strong>President Donald Trump had &#34;45&#34; monogrammed on his shirt cuff.</strong></h2><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ee023f22c6b00185db2c2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"President Donald Trump&#39;s Monogram\" height=\"3648\" width=\"4864\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trump&#39;s &#34;45&#34; monogram.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Brandon/AP Photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><h2><strong>Back in 2012, President Barack Obama&#39;s staff photographed him in his &#34;The President&#34; chair.</strong></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ee04ff22c6b00185db2c3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"obama presdient chair\" height=\"2730\" width=\"3641\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>&#34;The President.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/4331404882/in/album-72157623233916237/\" target=\"_blank\">The White House</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>In Biden&#39;s White House, even the shovels used on Arbor Day come with personalized plaques.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608ee06df22c6b00185db2c4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joe and Jill Biden Shovels\" height=\"2831\" width=\"3774\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Shovels used on Arbor Day.\n<p src=\"https://i.insider.com/608eb63bf22c6b00185db292?format=jpeg\" alt=\"small business owner bakery\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jorge Sactic is the owner of Chapina Bakery in Langley Park, Maryland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Sarah L. Voisin/The Washington Post via Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>About 64% of investors and business owners see Biden&#39;s policies aiding the global recovery.</li>\n<li>A majority also said Biden&#39;s measures will support global markets, according to a UBS survey.</li>\n<li>The optimism comes as Biden preps another $4.1 trillion in spending to boost the economic recovery.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Biden boom is in full swing and people like what they see.</p><p>Investors and business owners around the world are largely optimistic that the Biden administration&#39;s economic policies will fuel a robust recovery and leave them on better footing, according to a recent UBS survey. Some 64% of respondents view the administration as having a positive impact on the global economy. Six in 10 believe the White House&#39;s policies will support global markets.</p><p>Roughly 57% of investors and business owners said the Biden administration has benefitted their personal finances, and 54% of business owners said the policies benefitted their companies.</p><p>In just the first 100 days of his time in office, President Joe Biden has embarked on one of the most ambitious policy strategies in modern history. The president <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-biden-signs-trillion-covid-relief-package-checks-direct-payments-2021-3\">passed a $1.9 trillion stimulus measure</a> - the second-largest in history - on March 11 and has since unveiled <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/major-takeaways-biden-economic-spending-infrastructure-package-2021-4\">follow-up packages</a> that include roughly $4.1 trillion in additional spending. Economists have largely linked soaring retail sales and stronger economic growth to the stimulus measure.</p><p>To be sure, President Joe Biden&#39;s policies aren&#39;t the only cause for optimism. New COVID-19 cases in the US sit at their lowest seven-day average since October, and state and local governments have been slowly rolling back lockdown measures for weeks. And while the vaccination rate has slowed, it still sits at an average 2.5 million doses per day. At the current rate, the US will reach herd immunity over the next three months, according to <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/\">Bloomberg</a> data.</p><p>In the US specifically, seven in 10 investors expressed hope about the path of the economy. That compares to just 52% three months ago and makes US investors the most positive globally, UBS said.</p><p>The share of US investors growing positive toward stocks rose to 71% from 59%. The shift underscores a broader move toward riskier assets as investors ditch the safe havens they held at the start of the pandemic and position for a swift recovery.</p><p>The responses join other sentiment gauges that have turned stronger in recent months. The University of Michigan&#39;s consumer sentiment index rose to a fresh pandemic-era high in April, according to a Friday <a href=\"http://www.sca.isr.umich.edu\">release</a>. That level is the highest since March 2020. Separately, the Conference Board&#39;s consumer confidence measure rose to its highest level since February 2020 as the healing labor market and latest round of stimulus checks boosted outlooks.</p><p>UBS interviewed 2,850 investors and 1,150 business owners around the world from March 30 to April 18. Responses were sourced from 14 markets including the US, the UK, Mexico, mainland China, Japan, Italy, Brazil, and Mexico.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-boom-stimulus-economic-policy-investor-business-owner-optimism-ubs-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
