border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/TAAwhaW9WE0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 14:54:51 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ff478bb3793140019e2858b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"563d80d7b39916a43e703acd452cae41","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn77@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-21-682_43883f486c4f6df2.webp","destWidth":2666,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":507094,"destBytes":507094,"author":"insider@insider.com (Carla Mozée)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/600f279767a6bc0019d9ae34?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TAAwhaW9WE0:XiGshrth5Og:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn65@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-22-095_affc467423a41bf2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TAAwhaW9WE0:XiGshrth5Og:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn34@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-26-592_044e63e67b9f9207.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=TAAwhaW9WE0:XiGshrth5Og:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-24-889_67e3f0c44d7db8f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/TAAwhaW9WE0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn95@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-24-209_f49a1b32c70cf3ad.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238430},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"China's new digital currency will be another tool for its police state","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-china-digital-currency-another-tool-for-police-state-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/53b977fdecad04d1158d82b6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"yuan dollar \" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">China Photos/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>China&#39;s central bank is currently conducting trials for its digital currency.</li>\n<li>Privacy advocates worry that Chinese authorities will be able to collect even more data through the new digital yuan.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>China&#39;s central bank is currently conducting trials for its digital currency, which it hopes to have available for <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/19/investing/china-digital-yuan-us-dollar-intl-hnk/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">widespread use by the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing</a>.</p><p>But many privacy advocates are alarmed at the amount of data that Chinese authorities will be able to collect through the new digital yuan, and the resulting potential for abuse.</p><p>On <a href=\"https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/podcast/29609/the-myths-and-realities-of-the-chinese-digital-currency\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the Trend Lines podcast this week</a>, WPR&#39;s Elliot Waldman discussed the implications of China&#39;s new digital currency with <a href=\"https://www.cnas.org/people/yaya-j-fanusie\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Yaya Fanusie</a>, a senior fellow at the Center for a New American Security.</p><p><strong>WPR: By now, most everyone is familiar with cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, which are decentralized. And of course, digital payments have become pretty much ubiquitous. But I think it&#39;s fair to say that the concept of a central bank digital currency has yet to seep into the mainstream. So could you first enlighten us about how China&#39;s new digital currency works - what it is and what it&#39;s not?</strong></p><p><strong>Yaya Fanusie:</strong> As you said, people are used to Bitcoin and people know a lot about digital payments, because we all pay for things digitally. But a central bank digital currency is something a little bit different. Bitcoin is a decentralized digital currency that no one controls; it&#39;s independent of any government and anyone can participate.</p><p>Digital payments, as we know them, basically involve private banking infrastructure where private banks have central bank money, and then they allow you to transact, but it&#39;s really their infrastructure that you&#39;re participating with. So, you have a relationship with that private bank. You don&#39;t really have a relationship with the central bank.</p><p>But now, with the advancement of technology, governments see Bitcoin and are expressing interest in it, because Bitcoin solves some interesting problems around how to move value digitally. Central bankers also see that private companies are really involved in people&#39;s commerce and everyday transactions.</p><p>This is especially the case in China, which has wanted to figure out a way to have a digital currency that was run by the central bank. So, not like Bitcoin, which is independent and decentralized.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/chinas-digital-payments-revolution/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Beijing was concerned about the digital payment space</a>, which you may know is very big in China. The central bank has felt that private digital payment companies are way too powerful. So years ago, they started to think about how they could create infrastructure where the money is actually digital, but it is run by the central bank. Now, what does that look like? We don&#39;t know the details.</p><p>In fact, the central bank has been pretty clear that a lot of this is still being worked out. But what we do know the general framework: The People&#39;s Bank of China is going to create the digital currency, and then it&#39;s going to distribute it to banks and to private companies. Those banks and companies will basically have wallets, they&#39;ll have software, and people will transact with the digital currency through those wallets.</p><p>But the big difference is that unlike regular digital payments, the thing that they&#39;re transacting with is going to be the central bank money itself, digitally. Not just the applications that they were transacting with through the private companies.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608f35a4f22c6b00185db2e6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 1293705147\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Signage for the central bank-backed digital yuan, or E-CNY, at a coffee shop in Beijing, December 29, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">VCG/VCG via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>WPR: How far along is China&#39;s digital Yuan relative to similar initiatives in other countries? Because this isn&#39;t something that China is alone in working on, right?</strong></p><p><strong>Fanusie:</strong> Lots of governments are actually looking at <a href=\"https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/econographics/the-rise-of-central-bank-digital-currencies/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">exploring and researching the idea of a central bank digital currency</a>. They&#39;re looking at the pros and the cons, but China is probably the foremost of big economies in terms of actually developing something. They started researching back in 2014, and then roughly a year or so ago, they actually got to the point of doing trials.</p><p>What they&#39;ve done over the past few months is they&#39;ve distributed this digital currency via a lottery system to certain citizens in certain cities. And they&#39;ve given them the equivalent of, let&#39;s say, 31 US dollars in the digital yuan, or digital renminbi. They have actually just done these trials - I think it&#39;s maybe half a dozen or more cities that are participating - and I think <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/05/chinas-digital-yuan-what-is-it-and-how-does-it-work.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">millions of dollars worth of this currency has transacted</a> over the past few months.</p><p>They&#39;ve also taken certain municipal government workers and they&#39;ve allowed them to get some of their salaries paid in this digital currency.</p><p>So, I&#39;d say it&#39;s relatively far along, but the key milestone that China is looking at is the 2022 Winter Olympics, which will be held in Beijing next February. The government is saying that they would like to roll out more of this digital currency by then. Not that it will be out universal, but that&#39;s certainly a milestone that they&#39;re looking towards.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607d4f8544f45400192075d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Digital yuan red envelope\" height=\"2453\" width=\"3680\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A consumer uses a digital yuan red envelope in a mobile phone to buy goods at a digital yuan cashier&#39;s desk.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Costfoto/Barcroft Media via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>WPR: I believe I&#39;ve read some testimonials of people who have been selected for this lottery, and they&#39;ve said that the currency is pretty easy to use and that they like the utility of it so far.</strong></p><p><strong>Fanusie:</strong> Yeah, I think so. And that&#39;s probably because it&#39;s not that different than mobile payments that they&#39;re already using, since most people in China are not using cash that much. They&#39;re already using digital payments, so it&#39;s possible that for them, it doesn&#39;t make that much of a difference. But for the central bank, it makes a big difference.</p><p>You may wonder, if it&#39;s not so different for the consumer, why would the central bank want to do this? Well, the reason is that it&#39;s really about data, and there are a couple of ways to look at this. One is maybe a very positive way, and one is a little bit more cynical.</p><p>When you have a central bank digital currency, if you&#39;re a central bank, what this means is that if you create the currency, as people transact, you can actually observe the data. You can have insight as to when people are spending and what&#39;s happening. How much is this currency circulating? What happens when you implement a certain monetary policy? How does that change consumer spending?</p><p>The data is available, because people are using the currency that is connected to your infrastructure. In today&#39;s digital payments, that access doesn&#39;t exist. Let&#39;s take an example from the US, with Square or Venmo. All of those transactions are happening, but the government here in the US doesn&#39;t have access to that data immediately. There&#39;s a multilayered process where companies would report back to the government.</p><p>But in China, the digital currency is going to allow for a lot more collection of data, which goes with the Chinese Communist Party&#39;s desire to have a more data-driven economy, to collect more data and to use it for monetary policy, but to also to use it for analysis and even surveillance.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db65a11dee019097f2516b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: People walk past the China Bank headquarters building in central Beijing October 15, 2008.  REUTERS/David Gray (CHINA)\" height=\"2256\" width=\"3200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The China Bank headquarters building in central Beijing, October 15, 2008.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>WPR: It&#39;s incredible to think about because China&#39;s already such an advanced surveillance state, probably the most advanced in the world. What kind of new data do you think Beijing would be able to collect with this digital currency?</strong></p><p><strong>Fanusie:</strong> Some of it is new data, but probably most of it is not necessarily new. It is the efficiency of collecting the data. What is different is that we&#39;re talking either real time or near-real time observance of people&#39;s spending. In the current system, obviously the Chinese government is strong, and it can go to companies - and it does - and say, &#34;Hey, show us the transactions of person X, or company X, and hand over this information to us.&#34;</p><p>That&#39;s how the government gets its access to financial data now. But what would be different is that the government wouldn&#39;t necessarily have to go to all these different banks and all these different companies to compel them to hand over the information. The payment instrument that people would be using would be within their data house, in a sense.</p><p>The Chinese government is now saying that it&#39;s going to anonymize this data, which I wouldn&#39;t take at face value. But even so, the big plus for them is going to be that they&#39;ll be able to see all of these transactions happening, even individual wallets. Whoever is using this, their activity will be seen in at least real time, or maybe relative real time. This is access that doesn&#39;t exist anywhere.</p><p>As much as people think about big brother, and they think that they&#39;re always being watched by their government, it&#39;s honestly just not possible technologically for governments to track everyone&#39;s digital payments in real time. because the infrastructure is set up in such a bifurcated way. So this is a huge barrier breaker in terms of collecting financial transaction data.</p><p>One thing I should probably also mention is that what this also does is it gives the Chinese government more levers to pull. If the government has access to this digital currency and it&#39;s held with the central bank, you&#39;d be transacting with it, but it&#39;s really a central bank instrument that you&#39;re holding and that you&#39;re transacting in.</p><p>If you think a few steps in advance, I think what this means logically is that it would be easier for the central bank to turn off access to that. Right now either the government has to go to companies and say, &#34;Block off this person, close their account.&#34;</p><p>But I think the way this is going to work is that they&#39;ll have centralized access. They&#39;ll be able to say, &#34;All these digital Yuan, let&#39;s make them inactive.&#34; Or, &#34;Let&#39;s stop transactions from being able to go into these particular wallets,&#34; or &#34;these particular digital bank nodes are going to be null and void.&#34;</p><p>Logically, I think that&#39;s what this infrastructure is going to lend itself to. It then gives the government maybe more power to influence citizens, to take punitive measures and to even look at party members and see exactly how they&#39;re spending. There are lots of implications for domestic control that this technology lends itself to.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/512fee39eab8ead276000023?format=jpeg\" alt=\"China Renminbi\" height=\"2654\" width=\"3894\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://pictures.reuters.com/C.aspx?VP3=SearchResult_VPage&#38;VBID=2C04WNV8GNTAG&#38;SMLS=1&#38;RW=1291&#38;RH=809#/SearchResult_VPage&#38;VBID=2C04WNV8GNTAG&#38;SMLS=1&#38;RW=1291&#38;RH=809&#38;PN=2\" target=\"_blank\">Reuters</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>WPR: It wasn&#39;t long ago that digital payments and digital currencies were being viewed as maybe one of the best tools to fight corruption in the world, given that with each payment, there was a digital footprint that could be traced. But I don&#39;t remember anyone at the time saying, hold on a second, let&#39;s take a step back and imagine what might happen if one centralized authority is able to collect and monitor all of this data at the same time around people&#39;s payments.</strong></p><p><strong>Fanusie:</strong> It&#39;s funny, because that sentiment has actually been growing in private circles, especially in the tech community, because of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies. These decentralized cryptocurrencies are usually public, and all of the transactions can be read and accessed on a public online ledger.</p><p>So even though it&#39;s pseudo-anonymous, people can look at a Bitcoin wallet or a Bitcoin address and they can see all the transactions. There&#39;s really no barrier, they just don&#39;t necessarily know who is making the transactions.</p><p>For a while, a lot of people have been concerned that if you attach identities to the Bitcoin blockchain, then that could really ruin privacy. Because if you know my address, now you can look and you can see how much I&#39;m spending. You could see how much is in my account. So, there&#39;s actually been a push for privacy within the cryptocurrency community.</p><p>What&#39;s interesting is that now that central banks are thinking of a digital currency, even though it&#39;s not going to be public, there is maybe even more of a concern about privacy. If a central bank has a digital currency and all these transactions are on a record, then that central bank could track and maybe see your transactions forever, depending on how you&#39;re going to design this and what privacy safeguards you put in place.</p><p>There are all these concerns that the government could have access to someone&#39;s past, present and future transactions, depending on how they design privacy in a central bank digital currency. So, this issue is not going away.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/new-china-digital-currency-another-tool-for-police-state-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/IBFoUu758uQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 02 May 2021 23:34:25 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608f3620f22c6b00185db2e9?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"80e241e544cce544c6c82abf91d3c73e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-690_777183dde729f09f.webp","destWidth":2618,"destHeight":1964,"sourceBytes":278286,"destBytes":278286,"author":"insider@insider.com (The Editors)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/53b977fdecad04d1158d82b6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-23-116_18ef1fcc4a2e5fc2.webp","https://i.insider.com/608f35a4f22c6b00185db2e6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn41@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-330_31647fa017369113.webp","https://i.insider.com/607d4f8544f45400192075d1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn32@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-786_89d872aea0899989.webp","https://i.insider.com/5db65a11dee019097f2516b3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn69@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-457_b9d02e1e6cd53db7.webp","https://i.insider.com/512fee39eab8ead276000023?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-736_ab6c1485e938d2b1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IBFoUu758uQ:t0AbkATYwsY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn14@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-22-918_99203dc4639451ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IBFoUu758uQ:t0AbkATYwsY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn13@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-536_c12f0d996845014d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IBFoUu758uQ:t0AbkATYwsY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn10@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-886_4fb9ca5fe8a71f63.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/IBFoUu758uQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn56@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-297_510e6bad1e422aae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238434},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Japan is rethinking how to use its tanks to prepare for a potential clash with China","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/japan-rethinks-tank-use-to-prepare-for-potential-china-clash-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a0f3635c46f0018c0b289?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Japan Self-Defense Force tanks\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Japanese tanks during a live-fire exercise at the foot of Mount Fuji, August 22, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tomohiro Ohsumi/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Japan built a large and capable armored force to counter the Soviets during the Cold War.</li>\n<li>But a rising China poses a new challenge, and Japan is changing how it designs and uses its armor.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Despite a few successes early in World War II, Japanese armor was hopelessly outclassed by Allied tanks as soon as they arrived in large numbers.</p><p>Those experiences and the threat of a Soviet invasion led the Japanese to put much more effort into post-war tank designs. By the 1990s, Japan had a large and capable armored force.</p><p>But the Japan Self Defense Force (JSDF) has had to recalibrate in recent decades.</p><p>The threat from a rising China has forced Japan&#39;s Ground Self Defense Force (GSDF) to shift from an armor- and artillery-intensive force based in its north - where it would&#39;ve responded to a Soviet invasion - to a more mobile one able to reach southwestern Japan at a moment&#39;s notice.</p><p>To do this, the JSDF is making a <a href=\"https://www.mod.go.jp/en/publ/w_paper/index.html\" target=\"_top\">number of changes</a>, including investing heavily in transportation capability, new armored vehicle designs, and reforming the GSDF&#39;s tank arm.</p><h2>Fending off the Soviets</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a080b35c46f0018c0b283?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Japan Japanese Type 61 tank\" height=\"1331\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Type 61 main battle tanks during an exercise at Camp Fuji in Japan, November 18, 1985.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Defense Department</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Japan&#39;s tank force was actually quite <a href=\"https://www.historynet.com/why-japan-armored-warfare-failed.htm\" target=\"_top\">modern and innovative</a> during its development between the world wars. But while Germany and the Allies had the industrial capacity to update or create new tanks during World War II, Japan&#39;s industry was comparatively limited.</p><p>Moreover, since Japanese plans in that war involved pushing south into areas where massive tank battles were unlikely, most funding and resources went to its navy and air services.</p><p>After the war, Japan - now with access to Western technology and designs and convinced of the importance of tanks - focused much more on developing a capable armored force to fend off the Soviets.</p><p>For most of the Cold War, Japan&#39;s tank force was made up of the <a href=\"https://www.militaryfactory.com/armor/detail.asp?armor_id=294\" target=\"_top\">Type 61</a> and <a href=\"http://www.military-today.com/tanks/type_74.htm\" target=\"_top\">Type 74</a> main battle tanks, armed with 90 mm and 105 mm guns, respectively. They were both capable designs for their time and were fielded in large numbers.</p><p>In 1990, the GSDF introduced the <a href=\"https://weaponsystems.net/system/167-Type+90\" target=\"_top\">Type 90</a>. At 50 tons and with a 120 mm gun, it is by all accounts a first-rate tank. Equipped with modular composite armor, a laser rangefinder, fire-control computer, thermal and night vision, and an autoloader, it is similar to Germany&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.army-technology.com/projects/leopard/\" target=\"_top\">Leopard 2A4</a>.</p><p>The Japanese believed Hokkaido, the northernmost of the home islands and the closest to Soviet territory, would be the frontline of any invasion, and most of Japan&#39;s tanks were stationed there.</p><p>By 1976, the GSDF had some 1,200 tanks and about 1,000 artillery pieces, mostly in Hokkaido, where much of that armored force is still stationed.</p><h2>Lighter and more mobile</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a0ce135c46f0018c0b286?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Japan Self-Defense Force Type 74 tank\" height=\"1343\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Type 74 main battle tanks during a live-fire exercise at the foot of Mount Fuji, August 24, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tomohiro Ohsumi/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The threat of Russian invasion was virtually nonexistent after the Cold War, and the JSDF decided to cut down on the overall number of tanks, which fell from about 900 in service in 1995 to about 570 now.</p><p>The JSDF plans to reduce the total to 300 in the coming years.</p><p>The GSDF continued acquiring Type 90s to replace the older Type 61 and Type 74s, and Japan has continued developing new armored vehicles, fielding the <a href=\"https://nationalinterest.org/blog/what-makes-japans-type-10-tank-so-good-17981\" target=\"_top\">Type 10 main battle tank</a> and the <a href=\"https://weaponsystems.net/system/1015-Type+16+Maneuver+Combat+Vehicle\" target=\"_top\">Type 16 Mobile Combat Vehicle</a> in the last decade.</p><p>Introduced in 2012, the Type 10 is meant to replace the Type 74 and compliment the Type 90.</p><p>At 48 tons fully loaded, the Type 10 is lighter and more maneuverable than the Type 90. Whereas the Type 90&#39;s size limits it to operating in Hokkaido and around Mt. Fuji, the Type 10 can operate anywhere Japanese law allows.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a0bcb35c46f0018c0b285?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Japan Self-Defense Force tank armored vehicle\" height=\"1300\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Japanese Type 10 tank, top left, a Type 90 tank, top right, and Type 16 Maneuver Combat Vehicle, bottom, during an exercise, January 12, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">KAZUHIRO NOGI/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Type 10 has modular ceramic composite armor with nano-crystal steel. The modules can be added or removed depending on mission or damage. It also has a 120 mm gun and an auto loader.</p><p>The electronics suite is perhaps the Type 10&#39;s most impressive feature, with an advanced command-and-control system that allows it to communicate and share information with nearby JGSDF tanks and units.</p><p>The Type 16 was introduced a few years after the Type 10. Although it is wheeled, it has a tank turret and functions as a light tank, conducting close combat, counterattacks, and direct-fire infantry support.</p><p>Armed with a 105 mm rifled gun and weighing just 26 tons, the Type 16 can operate safely on Japan&#39;s entire road network and be carried in Air Self Defense Force aircraft.</p><h2>A new southern threat</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a0fe535c46f0018c0b28a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Japan Self-Defense Force Type 16 Maneuver Combat Vehicle\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Type 16 during a live-fire exercise in Japan, May 23, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CHARLY TRIBALLEAU/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Adopting lighter tanks may seem counterintuitive, but it actually fits perfectly within the force the JSDF is building - one capable of dealing with the new threat posed to Japan&#39;s southwest by China.</p><p>&#34;As we got farther from the Cold War and different threats arose, Japan started to shift overall defense thinking about where the real threat is emanating from,&#34; said Jeffrey Hornung, an expert on Japanese security and foreign policies at the RAND Corporation.</p><p>&#34;It starts to crystallize, really in the last decade, decade and a half, [to] where it&#39;s the China threat,&#34; Hornung told Insider.</p><p>That threat is primarily <a href=\"https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR2574.html\" target=\"_top\">in the air</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/chinas-coast-guard-ships-worrying-japan-scrambling-to-keep-up-2021-2\" target=\"_top\">at sea</a>, and centers on the Senkaku Islands, which Japan administers but China claims, calling them the Diaoyu Islands.</p><p>Japanese leaders believe that since China is not trying to export global revolution like the Soviet Union and is focused on just the Senkakus, a large-scale ground invasion of its home islands is unlikely.</p><p>&#34;They don&#39;t anticipate China doing any sort of amphibious invasion of Japanese territory, and so in that environment they don&#39;t see a need for the heavy artillery and tanks.&#34; Hornung said.</p><p>&#34;Instead, they see that you have all these islands in the southwest island chain that if the GSDF are going to be involved in, they have to rapidly get there, and they have to have the capability to fight in that environment,&#34; Hornung added.</p><h2>A need for rapid deployment</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608a0d694fac4f0018de865f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 2447119\" height=\"1337\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Japanese troops exit an armored vehicle during an exercise, August 30, 2003.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Koichi Kamoshida/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Tanks would still be essential if China were to attack Japan&#39;s larger offshore islands, where thousands of people live. As a result, the GSDF is developing rapid-deployment divisions and brigades, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-chinas-marine-corps-compares-to-japans-amphibious-force-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">including a new unit trained specifically in amphibious warfare</a>.</p><p>It is also acquiring more transportable armored vehicles and <a href=\"https://weaponsystems.net/system/510-Type+19\" target=\"_top\">artillery systems</a>, emphasizing anti-ship and anti-air capability, and buying V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft to help transport its soldiers.</p><p>But the GSDF still faces problems - namely its lack of sealift capacity.</p><p>Despite the main threat seen as facing Japan&#39;s southwest islands, half of the GSDFs rapidly deployable basic operational units are still <a href=\"https://warp.da.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/11591426/www.mod.go.jp/j/approach/agenda/guideline/2019/pdf/20181218_e.pdf\" target=\"_top\">based</a> in Hokkaido.</p><p>While the Type 16 can be deployed by air, the Type 90 and Type 10 would have to be transported by sea. The majority of its soldiers and hardware would also likely need to be deployed by ship, especially if they are headed to Japan&#39;s outer islands.</p><p>The only vessels capable of such tasks that Japan&#39;s Maritime Self-Defense Force has are its three Ōsumi-class tank landing ships. Japan <a href=\"https://www.navalnews.com/naval-news/2021/04/japan-to-introduce-3-new-transport-vessels-by-2024/\" target=\"_top\">plan</a><a href=\"https://www.navalnews.com/naval-news/2021/04/japan-to-introduce-3-new-transport-vessels-by-2024/\" target=\"_top\">s</a> to acquire three new transport vessels by 2024, but these are considerably smaller, and the total number of capable vessels would remain dangerously low.</p><p>&#34;They developed these [rapid deployment] capabilities without more coordination on the airlift and sealift from the other services that&#39;s required, and that&#39;s where there&#39;s a problem,&#34; Hornung said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/japan-rethinks-tank-use-to-prepare-for-potential-china-clash-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2021 22:42:26 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608a10a935c46f0018c0b28c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"884900be987ec071ebf8399a0d7f2ccf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn77@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-21-719_6cdc28878f1e10b4.webp","destWidth":1812,"destHeight":1359,"sourceBytes":122688,"destBytes":122688,"author":"insider@insider.com (Benjamin Brimelow)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608a0f3635c46f0018c0b289?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn16@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-24-317_191faee541a5cf0c.webp","https://i.insider.com/608a080b35c46f0018c0b283?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/608a0ce135c46f0018c0b286?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_2/2021/05/03/03-57-27-921_d5919d9b336f2c96.webp","https://i.insider.com/608a0bcb35c46f0018c0b285?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-23-219_d4a877004c2d7775.webp","https://i.insider.com/608a0fe535c46f0018c0b28a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-25-735_02a1ef44250e66c7.webp","https://i.insider.com/608a0d694fac4f0018de865f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn49@2020_3/2021/05/03/03-57-23-366_a0b296f53f8e647d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2021/05/03/03-57-26-516_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Z4zzkUQDjR4:iSAjhpQianE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn63@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-753_9a825e5d806a3ee4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Z4zzkUQDjR4:iSAjhpQianE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn93@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-22-183_dbc76c7a5d360372.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_4/2021/05/03/03-57-24-468_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Z4zzkUQDjR4:iSAjhpQianE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn28@2020_6/2021/05/03/03-57-23-728_02d8e911d7841941.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Z4zzkUQDjR4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn99@2020_1/2021/05/03/03-57-24-611_286d61e93e06b805.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1620014238426},{"createdTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","updatedTime":"2021-05-03 11:57:18","title":"Ex-national security adviser Michael Flynn, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his contact with Russia, doesn't know the Pledge of Allegiance, video suggests","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/michael-flynn-doesnt-know-the-pledge-of-allegiance-video-suggests-2021-5","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608f37d634af8d001859a7b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"michael flynn\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>In this Feb. 11, 2014, file photo, then-Defense Intelligence Agency Director Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn testifies on Capitol Hill in Washington.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Lauren Victoria Burke, File</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former national security adviser Michael Flynn appeared at a campaign event for Lin Wood on  Sunday.</li>\n<li>Flynn began reciting the Pledge of Allegiance for the crowd but stopped after starting the wrong word.</li>\n<li>Flynn plead guilty in 2017 to lying to the FBI about contact with Russia, but was pardoned by Trump.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It appears former national security adviser Michael Flynn doesn&#39;t know the words to the Pledge of Allegiance.</p><p>On Sunday, Flynn appeared at a campaign event for Lin Wood, a pro-Trump attorney, held at the Honkeytonk Saloon in Ladson, South Carolina, <a href=\"https://www.postandcourier.com/politics/pro-trump-attorney-lin-wood-draws-hundreds-michael-flynn-to-ladson-bar-in-bid-for/article_60dc4b2e-ab5b-11eb-910e-7b80465f00a2.html\">The Post and Courier</a> reported. Hundreds of supporters attended the rally, including the Bikers for Trump group.</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/RonFilipkowski/status/1388931637170352138\">video of the event</a> shared on Twitter, Flynn appeared on stage and announced he was going to say the pledge of allegiance and that the audience was going to say it along with him.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/qanon-into-the-storm-cullen-hoback-ron-jim-watkins-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">&#39;QAnon: Into the Storm&#39; director Cullen Hoback talks about how 2 random guys trolled the entire world and inspired a deadly insurrection</a></em></p><p>&#34;I want you to hear, not just listen, I want you to hear every single word of the Pledge of Allegiance,&#34; Flynn said. &#34;That is our pledge to each other, that is our pledge to this country.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America,&#34; Flynn began. He then started to say what sounds like &#34;indiv-&#34; before cutting himself off as the crowd continued.</p><p>After a moment, he picked back up with the crowd to finish it off: &#34;under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.&#34;</p><p>The full Pledge of Allegiance is: &#34;I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.&#34;</p><p>Flynn served as national security adviser for President Donald Trump from January 2017 to February 2017 before resigning over reports he had lied about contact with a Russian official. In December 2017, he pleaded guilty to lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigations about his communications with Sergey Kislyak, Russia&#39;s ambassador to the US at the time.</p><p>He later accused the Justice Department of entrapment and moved to withdraw his guilty plea. In November of 2020, he was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-pardons-former-national-security-advisor-michael-flynn-2020-3\">pardoned by Trump</a>. Flynn has become a prominent figure in the QAnon conspiracy theory, <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/michael-flynn-trump-pardon-qanon-2020-12\">Insider&#39;s Rachel E. Greenspan</a> reported, deepening his ties with conspiracy promoters like Wood and Sidney Powell.</p><p>The event Sunday was in support of Wood&#39;s campaign for South Carolina GOP chairman.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/michael-flynn-doesnt-know-the-pledge-of-allegiance-video-suggests-2021-5'>Business Insider</a></div><div href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=shbA8FLiecs:gePvUwLymAU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=shbA8FLiecs:gePvUwLymAU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"
